PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is a need for an Independent and Multi-Cultural Broadcasting Corporation to give a firm legislative and financial basis for the SBS Network.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should pass Senator Vigor's Bill with all expediency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 217 citizens), Gietzelt (from 248 citizens) and Sibraa (from 186 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Australian Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned residents of Western Australia, object strongly to the fringe benefits tax which is a further and unnecessary burden on the average working person. We your petitioners humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Identification Card System
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned concerned Australian citizens hereby petition the Honourable Senators to totally reject the current proposals for an I.D. Card and the proposed Data Protection Agency.

We believe that they represent potentially undesirable interference in the lives of honest Australians. Provisions for protection of individual privacy cannot be guaranteed as Statutes are easily altered by future Governments.

We believe that there are more efficient methods to prevent fraud in the areas of taxation and social security without the use of these two proposals, which go well beyond the reach of the true role of democratic government, i.e. That citizens may live quiet and peaceable lives. The I.D. Card and Data Protection Agency have strong potential under this or future administrations to interfere with the quiet and peaceable lives of its subjects.
We your humble petitioners in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Vouchers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, wish to protest about the guidelines set by the Department of Community Services and approved by Senator Grimes, as quoted in The Sun newspaper on 1st October 1986, inter alia:

`In a September 16 letter to Mallee MP Mr Peter Fisher, Senator Grimes said: ``I have recently approved guidelines which state that food vouchers should not be endorsed in any way which restricts the client's freedom of choice (e.g. No Alcohol, No Cigarettes, No Pet Food). Only in exceptional circumstances and with the express approval of the Commonwealth Department of Community Services will such practices be sanctioned.'' '

We believe the guidelines distort the true aim of the food voucher, the issue of which as emergency relief surely is to ensure the provision of food for human consumption for a person in necessitous circumstances. To enable the drugs of nicotine and alcohol to be provided must be detrimental to the health of that person and the welfare of any dependents and we believe that taxpayer's money should not be used to increase the drug problem in the community.

We urge the Government to support those Agencies providing food vouchers and to revise these guidelines so that such vouchers will be for the provision of food only. Any person has freedom of choice to accept or reject such a voucher.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescriptions for Drugs: Cost
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully showeth:

That we are vigorously opposed to the Governments intention to double the cost of prescriptions from $5.00 to $10.00. This will cause extreme hardship to a great many Australians already struggling to meet the high cost of medicines and medical services.
We request that you seek revenue elsewhere and leave the cost of prescriptions at an affordable cost to every Australian.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the President and honourable members of the Senate of Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

By cutting ESL funding and eliminating funding for community languages and multicultural education you have attacked tens of thousands of Australian children. You have condemned these children with limited English to gross educational inequality and very dim prospects for their future.
On behalf of these children we call on your to remove this new discrimination which your budget has guaranteed by immediately restoring ESL and Multicultural education funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Treasurer agree with Senator Graham Richardson that access to low interest loans by Commonwealth Bank employees has compensated them for the fact that the average salary of $18,000 a year is below the level of average weekly earnings? Is Senator Richardson correct in saying that the current wage regime does not permit pay increases which would make up for losing such a loan; that is, if the bank were to cash out the benefit? Will the Government, as urged by Senator Richardson, do something about these employees who are suffering from the fringe benefits tax and yet, as he points out, are at the lower end of the salary scale, or does the Minister lump these workers in with those he describes as the `bleaters, whingers and former tax evaders', whom he claims are the only real opponents or victims of the fringe benefits tax?
—I heard the Treasurer answer a question like that on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation news last night and I have nothing to add to what the Treasurer said.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen a report in the Australian today which refers to comments made by the Chairman of Austec International Ltd, Mr Leslie McNeill, about comparative taxation rates in Australia and the United States of America? Does the Minister agree with Mr McNeill that the much higher corporate and personal taxes in Australia mean that shareholders are losing out on benefits that could be obtained if the company moved its operations to the United States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The remarks made by Mr McNeill have been drawn to my attention. In fact, as the Press reports indicate, I had a discussion with Mr McNeill some time ago about these matters. But I would like to use the opportunity of his public comments to correct some misapprehensions. Australia's business tax regime compares favourably with those of other industrial countries. Taxation paid as a proportion of gross operating profit is 18 per cent below the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of 21 per cent. A major reform of the Australian taxation system is being introduced, which includes new measures to encourage productive investment. This reform has enhanced Australia's attractiveness to foreign investors at a time when other countries, such as the United States and Canada, are taking away tax concessions currently enjoyed by business.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government is responsible for the most significant reform in taxation in Australia-company profit tax. State and local governments in Australia impose only minor charges compared with what is charged elsewhere, particularly in the United States. The most significant of those is State payroll tax based on salaries of employees. Australia's corporate tax rate will, of course, be increased next year to a flat rate of 49 per cent but the overall burden of taxation on the corporate sector will fall with a number of factors accompanying that increase to 49 per cent. Those factors are: Firstly, the introduction of an imputation system to abolish double taxation of company profits; secondly, the abolition of a 15 per cent withholding tax on dividends repatriated overseas; and thirdly, the abolition of branch profits tax. These reforms offer particular benefits to overseas investors. Other attractive features are an extremely generous 150 per cent research and development taxation concession, and favourable depreciation allowances providing a write-off for most plant and equipment over five years, with that being accelerated in respect of certain equipment, such as computers, where depreciation has accelerated to three years.

The overall impact of the Australian system is highly attractive for investments in manufacturing industry and the results of a hypothetical investment case study comparing the taxation regimes of Australia, Japan, Canada and the United States show that, under existing arrangements, Australia ranks second to Canada. With the introduction of planned changes to the tax system, of all the countries, Australia takes the top position. I put those matters on the record because, as I say, they have been a matter of public comment by Mr McNeill. I will certainly write to him in relation to the matters which I have dealt with in this question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to comments by the Treasurer on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Perth last week when, after claiming that the Government had made all the changes it thought necessary to the fringe benefits tax, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: But if there were some issue to come up which we have not seen in this review and have not seen in the original design of the thing, well of course, like any other piece of law, we're prepared to amend it.

Has the Government completely closed the door on the prospect of further change or modification to the fringe benefits tax, as the Treasurer's thumbs down to Senator Richardson's comments seems to indicate, or is the situation as described by Mr Keating in Perth; that is, if further unintended consequences are identified, the Government will be prepared to consider change?

TALK.START.PARA: —The emphasis on what the Treasurer has said at all times is on the expression `unintended consequences'. In his answer given in Perth the Treasurer was probably referring to the fact that in reviewing the fringe benefits tax the Government revitalised a review body which was established, I think, for the first time in 1984 and which is a consultative mechanism between tax consultants and accountants representing the peak bodies of those professions and the Australian Taxation Office. That is an ongoing mechanism to review details of tax administration and so on. I think that is what the Treasurer was referring to. Anything the Treasurer said on Thursday of last week-I think that is the date the honourable senator referred to-cannot in any way be assumed as involving the Government in a review of the principles of the fringe benefits tax in any way.

—Has the attention of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters been drawn to comments on administrative reform by the present Leader of the Opposition over the weekend at his poorly attended and totally inappropriately named `Preparing for Government' conference at Thredbo? If so, can the Minister provide an assessment of the economies which could be achieved if Mr Howard's proposals for an economic super- ministry were implemented? Was it in fact the Fraser Government which split the then Department of the Treasury into the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the comments referred to. Senator Maguire is, of course, correct that when the previous Labor Government was in office there was a Treasury department which encompassed all the functions which Mr Howard now proposes that four Ministers altogether should deal with. When the Fraser Government was elected, the functions previously performed entirely within Treasury were divided into Treasury and the Department of Finance. I gather from Mr Howard's half-baked proposals which he released at Thredbo last weekend that he proposes to double that number again. At that rate we would have 1,000 economic departments after another nine new Liberal governments had been elected, but I expect it will take a very long time for one new Liberal government to be elected, let alone nine.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is worth noting that the policy which Mr Howard was floating in a half-baked form, which is typical of most of the policies which the Opposition has or does not have, was obviously not very well thought through. He said there was going to be an economic supremo who I presume will be Mr Carlton-it is difficult to imagine Mr Carlton as the commanding officer of any battalion but apparently that is what he has in mind-with three other Ministers, a Minister for expenditure, a Minister for taxation and a Minister for, would you believe, other bits and pieces. What the other bits and pieces are is a matter on which anybody can speculate for his own satisfaction, but it demonstrates just what a half-baked proposition the beleaguered Leader of the Opposition produced for the two-thirds of his troops, or whatever it was, who turned up for the Thredbo weekend.

I certainly hope that the group which Mr Howard has working on his version of the fringe benefits tax has thought through its policy position somewhat more coherently than he obviously has on public administration and the administrative orders. It can be presumed that Mr Carlton will be the commanding officer of this little squad of economic Ministers, and I suppose that Senator Messner will be one of the sergeants-that is, unless Senator Michael Baume manages to displace him from the front bench before that happens. I do not think there is really much more that I need to say. I think the point is made quite adequately out of Mr Howard's mouth; that is, he envisages setting up as one of the sergeants in this little squad, of which Mr Carlton will be the CO, a ministry for looking after bits and pieces. I think that really says it all.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. Given the fact that National Estate listed, environmentally sensitive forest areas near Jackeys Marsh, Tasmania, are being logged at this very moment, I ask: Firstly, will the Government take immediate action to protect this part of the environmental heritage which belongs to all Australians? Secondly, if not, when will the Government take action? Thirdly, what action will the Government take? Fourthly, how will it implement this action, that is, through the courts or by other means? If it is done through the courts, on what grounds? If by other means, what are they?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The memorandum of understanding on Tasmanian woodchip exports establishes a process of consultation designed to promote the conservation and development of forests, ensuring that the industry operates efficiently while recognising proper environmental concern. On 21 October this year the Australian Heritage Commission announced its decision to list Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff on the National Estate register. This important decision triggers consideration of how National Estate values will be taken into account by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission. This point is acknowledged by Mr Gray in his telex to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment on 7 November in which he refers to steps taken by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission under clause 27, namely, that the Forestry Commission has sought further advice on registered values. The fact is that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission did not seek that information until logging had recommenced in Jackeys Marsh. The Tasmanian Government, therefore, has authorised logging and the possible destruction of National Estate values before the process of discussion on how those values might be protected has had a chance to take its course. The Tasmanian Government's action is pre-emptive and highly provocative, and shows a blatant disregard for the environment.

ANSWER.PARA: The National Estate values identified by the Australian Heritage Commission include great diversity of plant communities, rare threatened plant species, outstanding aesthetic value, archaeological sites and rainforest. These are the criteria that need to be explored. Mr Cohen has called upon Mr Gray to stop logging in the area until the process of consultation has been allowed to take its full course. That is the first step we have taken. The Commonwealth's Advisory Committee on Tasmanian Forestry Operations is due to report on Jackeys Marsh within three weeks, and the Australian Heritage Commission is expected to complete its detailed work on National Estate values within two weeks. In the view of our Government, Mr Gray should cease logging in this area while the process of consultation and dispute settlement outlined in the memorandum of understanding takes its course.

Senator Sanders's question concerned itself at some length about what further steps we would take. At this stage I will say that I have outlined our position on it, and we hope that now Mr Gray will respond to our requests to cease logging and to have the proper process of consultation which is provided for in the memorandum of understanding and which is required as a result of the area being declared a part of the National Estate, and that it will not be necessary for the Federal Government to take further steps of a legal kind outlined in Senator Sanders's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Might I take it, then, that the Federal Government will not intervene to save the trees at Jackeys Marsh today, tomorrow or in the near future?

—Nothing in the answer I gave should leave Senator Sanders with the conclusion that we would do nothing, but at this stage we believe it is still possible to have the appropriate discussion, to receive the reports, to establish what the National Estate values are and then to proceed to agree on what logging, if any, can take place within the framework of those National Estate values. We have not got to that stage yet, but I hope that we will be able to resolve this matter in a co-operative fashion.

—I refer the Minister for Education to the implementation of the higher education administration charge. I ask: Is the Government making any attempt to assist in the implementation of the charge so as to avoid disruption to institutions and students? Secondly, can the Minister advise the Senate what steps have been taken by the Government to assist needy students, and is it true to say that any students unable to pay the charge will be denied access to an institution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the Government has taken a number of steps to ensure that the introduction of the administration charge and its administration are handled with minimum effect on students, particularly those who are required to pay the charge. That is not all students, of course, but some students will be required to pay the charge. We hope that the administration of the charge will be such as to minimise the impact on them. My Department and the Tertiary Education Commission have had discussions with the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals in Advanced Education, following which guidelines have been developed and forwarded to all higher education institutions to assist them in the smooth introduction of the administration charge. In particular, institutions have been informed of the fact that they should not take any steps to collect the charge until the legislation has passed through both Houses of Parliament and has received royal assent. It was necessary for us to instruct the institutions in that fashion because some institutions had, in a pre-emptive fashion, started to require the charge. They cannot do that until the legislation is passed and has received royal assent.

ANSWER.PARA: The legislation does not specify any timing for the payment of the charge, so I am encouraging institutions to defer collecting the charge from students who are eligible for Austudy until they have received their Austudy payment with the $250, which will be probably February for continuing students and March for newly-enrolling students. There is, as far as I can see, no reason why institutions cannot defer the levying of the charge until that point. This would certainly assist all of those students who are in fact needy enough to have the $250 given to them in their Austudy payment. It is also important that honourable senators know that I have informed institutions that the legislation will not prevent them from providing a refund where a student has enrolled and has subsequently withdrawn or transferred to another institution. As well as that, I have informed the Senate on a number of occasions-and, of course, the institutions are very well aware of this-that the institutions have received from the Commonwealth quite substantial loan funds, about $11m in all, covering higher education institutions, and we have asked them to make loans available to needy students who are eligible to pay this charge but who are not able to get the $250 together at the beginning of the year. In this way, if the institutions co-operate with this measure, there should be no real obstacle in the way of any student enrolling in a course for which he or she is eligible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the two recent admissions by the Treasurer that the Government did not impose the fringe benefits tax directly on those who received the benefits because it feared the response of unions to such an action. How can the Government justify imposing the tax directly on small businessmen, farmers and other self-employed people when it declines to do so for the vast bulk of wage and salary earners?

—I have not seen that comment by the Treasurer, and it would be helpful if Senator Messner could draw my attention to where it appears. In respect of most large employers, the administrative difficulties which would be encountered with the fringe benefits tax would be encountered even if the tax were imposed directly on the employee. It is the most satisfactory method of collecting the tax in the case of large employers. In regard to small business, as a result of the review of the tax and the ironing out of the so-called unintended consequences, which lifted the ceiling from $200 to $500 in respect of matters which had to be taken into account, I believe that the burden on small business is probably considerably alleviated. Insofar as it is an administrative matter, as I indicated in answer to an earlier question, the Government will continue to monitor the position.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It relates to the confusion in the minds of some members of this Parliament, and, if the correspndence being received in my office is any indication, in the community as well, relating to Budget decisions regarding defence force retirement and death benefits. Will the Minister outline the changes announced in the Budget to the defence force retirement and death benefits pension and to the service pension and what steps he is taking to minimise the concern of recipients now and in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, as Senator Coleman suggested, that there is a degree of confusion about the terminology relating to service pensions and I have drawn this to the attention of the Armed Forces Federation as well as some ex-service bodies. The confusion often arises when statements are made on defence force retirement and death benefits, which come under the Minister for Defence and not under the Veterans' Affairs Department, because of the somewhat casual use of the words `service pension' in Press statements and generally in the media. This occurs from time to time when changes are made to defence force retirement and death benefits payments which the media may refer to as reductions or increases in service pensions. Confusion then arises about the service pension which is paid by my Department to some 400,000 people. They are, of course, two separate pensions. Confusion is created and alarm and anxiety result from the use of the words `service pension'.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of an examination of problems that have occurred recently, I have discussed with the Secretary to my Department whether service pensions paid by my Department should be referred to as war service pensions to distinguish them from service pensions paid to servicemen who have retired from peacetime service. There is confusion in the area. Of course, the service pension is related to war service and is paid only to those persons who have faced hostile forces. Consequently, perhaps there is a need to define the term more clearly. We are now examining the possibility of changing the terminology in the legislation so as to define my service pension, which is still growing, as a war service pension as distinct from the service pension paid under the DFRDB legislation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer to the appendix in the memorandum of understanding signed by the Tasmanian Premier and the Minister for Primary Industry concerning the conditions of approval for woodchip export. I specifically refer to the section which covers the Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff area in these terms:

QUESTION.PARA: Forest operations will be in accordance with management guidelines as indicated in the environmental impact statement on woodchip export and in the Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff EIS.

In its dispute with Tasmania over logging at Jackeys Marsh, does the Commonwealth Government claim that operations are not being carried out as stipulated in the EIS? If not, why does the Prime Minister claim that the memorandum of understanding is being breached?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ryan has already given a pretty comprehensive answer on this question. On the actual specifics of what is in the memorandum of understanding, I do not think that it will surprise anyone to hear that I am unable to recite that from beginning to end. Therefore, I do not know what is in the particular section to which Senator Watson refers. If there is anything to add to the answer that Senator Ryan has already given, I will contact the Minister for Primary Industry and ask him to supply it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. No doubt he is aware of the results of the United States elections which have given the Democrats control of the Senate. Amongst the newly elected senators there appears to be a strong sentiment for trade protection and subsidy which could be very damaging to Australia. What steps will this Government take to point out to the United States Government and the Senate the effects that such policies will have on allies such as Australia? Does the Government believe that a renewed effort must be made in the light of the United States elections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that a conclusion which can be drawn from the United States election is that it is likely that the United States Congress will, for the time being at least, become more protectionist as a result of the Democrats having control of the Senate. This is a view which is held by the Australian Government, although it is too early yet to say whether legislation in support of these policies will emerge. It is a view which is also held by the Japanese Government and which was conveyed to me last week when I was in Japan.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I should point out that it is probably too early to rush to a judgment on these issues. For example, the United States textile and clothing industry Bill, which was brought into the House I think 18 months ago, was dealt with in May of this year for the second time. Since that measure was last before the Congress, the new version of the multi-fibre agreement has been ratified internationally, which may well offer some comfort to the United States industry and may result in that Bill not being pursued. It is too early to make a judgment on a number of issues relating to these matters. Senator Foreman points out in his question that Australia has a lot at stake in the trade policies which the United States Congress adopts. We, as a government and as a people, will have to remain very active and vigilant and try to maintain as high a profile as possible in Washington in order to ensure that our trading interests are taken into account as much as possible. The Minister for Trade will visit the United States again in February, particularly in relation to the wheat question, and there is a program for an inaugural meeting of the proposed Australia-United States ministerial consultations on trade which will be held in Australia in March. By that time we should be in a better position to judge the future direction of United States trade policy and the policies which might be adopted to counter any moves that are contrary to the interests of Australia.

As well as direct problems in our bilateral trade with the United States, we have the general long term objective to moderate United States agricultural trade policies by negotiation of effective international rules governing agricultural trade. Then we would hope to see an end to the farm subsidies war between the United States and the European Economic Community, which is having such an adverse effect on world prices and on Australian commodity prices in agriculture generally. The meeting of trade Ministers at Punta del Este in Uruguay was in a sense a step in the right direction in terms of trade liberalisation generally. In summary, let me say that, while there is ground for concern as a result of the United States elections, it is probably too early to make a definitive judgment about the directions that the United States will follow. In the meantime, the Government and industries in Australia have to keep a very close watch on what is taking place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Government considering a change to the eligibility criteria for the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme? Is the Government looking at ways of using the scheme as a lever on Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd, as suggested by Minister Kerin and currently being investigated by Minister Morris and Attorney-General Bowen? Does Senator Button not agree that this must lead to great uncertainty and instability for all investment and all employment in Tasmania? Will eligibility in future depend upon the political pliability of applicant companies to the will of the government of the day?
—The answer to the last part of the question is no. The answer to the earlier parts of the question is that I do not know; I will make some inquiries and provide an answer as soon as possible.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Is the Minister aware of an article entitled `Queensland Government woos the outback with TV', published in the Australian Financial Review of 28 October, in which the Queensland Government outlined its plans to spend $250,000 on a currently illegal plan to provide a commercial television service to outback Queenslanders? Does the Minister agree with comments made in this article by the Queensland Minister for Northern Development, Mr Katter, that the Federal Government might meet half of the cost of the $500,000 project? Can the Minister explain why the proposed project would not meet Federal Government legal requirements? Further, does the Minister regard this project as feasible or does he agree with the assumption made in the article that the proposal is nothing more than meaningless electioneering?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last line of the question is yes; it was clearly a piece of election stunting by Mr Katter. I heard him directly a couple of weeks ago at Kununurra pulling the same stunt. But no submission has been received by the Government on this issue; so any answer given presupposes that the report in the Australian Financial Review was completely adequate and accurate. With that caveat, I am advised by Mr Duffy that the article suggested that the Queensland proposal is illegal. Of course, the Federal Government would not have anything to do with illegal activities, whatever the Government of Queensland might do.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that Senator Colston is aware that the remote areas of Queensland will soon be served by a remote commercial television service provided by the Aussat satellite; that is, a properly licensed broadcasting service. The licensee, Queensland Satellite Television, is expected to commence transmissions about the middle of next year. Queensland Satellite Television has already lodged planning proposals for the rebroadcasting facilities that will be established in some 25 locations. The remote commercial television service will be available to all people in remote areas of Queensland, including those homesteads and stations. In addition to those towns that will be provided with rebroadcasting facilities by the RCTS licensee, other communities may establish their own licence facilities under the Government's self-help broadcasting reception scheme. Whilst the proposal described in the article is technically feasible, I am advised by Mr Duffy that he has not received a proposal from the Queensland Government and that, therefore, he is unable to comment on it in any more detail. I do not expect, actually, that he will receive a proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who is responsible for the Australian Customs Service. I draw his attention to the Australian Customs Service proposal to centralise Customs clearances at Sydney and Melbourne at the expense of the port of Brisbane. Is the Minister aware that, if the proposal for importers to clear cargo in Sydney goes ahead, total job losses of some 405 personnel will occur in the Brisbane port region? Does he appreciate the fact that such a proposal would prove a serious threat to the long term prospects of the Brisbane port facilities at Fisherman Island and the Hamilton wharves? What are the Minister's comments on suggestions that the move would cause a serious cost and trading threat to Queensland industry through unacceptably long delays in the movement of cargo ex-Sydney as the level of congestion in that port escalates? What is the Government's intention in this very important matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am fully aware of the proposals relating to the integrated cargo control and clearance system. I am also aware of all sorts of wild allegations that have been thrown about on this issue by Customs agents in Brisbane. I can only utter a word of caution about relying on the figures which are in Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question. The purpose of the integrated cargo control and clearance system is to enable Customs and Customs agents to process goods coming through the ports of Australia much more quickly than they have ever been able to do in the past. It is to enable advance notice to be given by shippers, by telex or other electronic means, of goods coming through ports, and to enable the clearances to be made very quickly on a more centralised basis. When I say `a more centralised basis', that does not mean that the centralised port will necessarily be Sydney, for example, as alleged in the question. In fact, it is quite likely that it will make no difference to ports such as Brisbane, and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that, as with any change to a system such as this, which is, in the Government's view and in the view of a committee which has examined the question, of great significance to Australian industries as a whole in improving our competitive performance, nonetheless there are fears and concerns about the introduction of a changed system. I would also add that, because of these concerns, nothing will be implemented in any great haste. Indeed, the Australian Customs Service will be providing all interested organisations with a discussion paper and an opportunity to comment on that paper before any further steps are taken along the course which has much to recommend it in terms of the services which can be offered to Australian industry generally.

I summarise my answer to the question by saying that there are many concerns which I believe to be misplaced and many concerns in relation to which there will be time to work matters out and these will be expressed in the course of comments on the discussion paper regarding this matter which the Customs Service will distribute.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Community Services. It relates to nursing home benefits payable in Victoria. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an organised campaign being conducted in Victoria, in which nursing home patients and their families are being urged to put pressure on the Government for an increase in nursing home benefits? Is there any justification for such a campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a copy of the material which has been circulated in the last couple of weeks to residents of Victorian nursing homes and their families. The material urges patients and their families to send form letters to me and to other Ministers and members of parliament. I do not believe that the campaign has any relevance; I do not think it ever had any relevance, but certainly it has none now. It is almost three weeks since I announced in this place an increase in the nursing home benefit payable in Victoria. That nursing home benefit in Victoria is the highest in Australia. Apart from the fact that I disapprove strongly, and I think most honourable senators would, of elderly people in nursing homes being used in campaigns of this type, having one's campaign so badly organised that the material does not go out until at least a week and in some cases two or three weeks after the end one is trying to achieve has been achieved seems to be a little strange and a little stupid, and it demonstrates the incapacity of those organising the campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said before in this place, it is absolutely routine for governments to review the nursing home benefit in November of each year and to increase it. This year that review resulted in a substantial increase. The review was based on a thorough examination of all factors affecting the costs of operating a nursing home, and that included in Victoria the fact that as a result of budgetary activity last year we had a freeze on the nursing home benefit. The freeze has now been lifted in part, in recognition of the fact that the Government in Victoria has co-operated with the Commonwealth in developing more cost efficient nursing home care in that State.

We have announced increases in fees in Victoria. They have risen by in excess of $5 a day, or $35 a week. The net benefit in Victoria remains the highest for any State, despite the freeze. One may say that the campaign actually succeeded before it started. To continue putting this sort of literature around and expecting these sorts of form letters to have an influence on government policy making, no matter who the government is, is a little naive and a little stupid, apart from being quite heartless in the way it affects residents of nursing homes.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RECOGNITION OF STUDIES, DEGREES AND DIPLOMAS IN HIGHER EDUCATION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I am pleased to see that she finds the National Party colours becoming to wear. I remind the Minister that in 1985 the Government ratified the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Regional Convention on the Recognition of Studies, Degrees and Diplomas in Higher Education in Asia and the Pacific, and this recognition was extended to the European region in 1986. The Department of Foreign Affairs advised the session Secretary-General:

QUESTION.PARA: The instrument of acceptance does not incorporate any qualifications in the terms of Australian acceptance.

Will this allow holders of degrees from universities with inferior standards to practise in Australia? Does the Minister agree that by ratifying this Convention the Government would be in a position to use its powers under an external treaty to force its will upon doctors or, for that matter, any professional organisation which disagrees with it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from dissociating myself from the imputation that I am wearing National Party colours--
—You had better get it off.

—I will not take Senator Grimes's advice. I am surprised that Senator Sheil has asked in such suspicious and negative terms a question about our recognition of the UNESCO Regional Convention on the Recognition of Studies, Degrees and Diplomas in Higher Education in Asia and the Pacific and the extension of its recognition to the European region. In my view it is a great step forward in our relationships with the region that we have actually acceded to this Convention, and certainly it is one of the more important achievements of former Ambassador Whitlam during his period as Australia's Ambassador to UNESCO. The kinds of fears that Senator Sheil articulated in his question are quite unjustified. The process of reaching the recognition was one carried out after thorough consultation with the States, which in turn had consulted with various professional boards and so forth. A statement was made at the time of accession which referred to the shared responsibilities of the Commonwealth and the States under the Constitution and these are certainly being taken into account in implementing the treaty. The statement also refers to the responsibilities in Australia of higher education institutions, registration boards and professional associations, such as doctors' associations, for determining the qualifications that they will accept. Commonwealth authorities will transmit the text of the convention to those bodies.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian accession to the European convention should assist students and graduates from Australian institutions who want to work and study further in Europe-I hope that that is something Senator Sheil and all other honour- able senators accept-and it should improve the assessment of Australian qualifications in Europe. It should also benefit migrants from Europe to Australia and those wishing to come to Australia to study. Ratification of the European convention complements Australia's accession in 1985 to the UNESCO Regional Convention on the Recognition of Studies, Degrees and Dip- lomas in Higher Education in Asia and the Pacific.

In conclusion, in no sense will any Australian standard be undermined by this, nor will any inferior standard degree from the region or the European region be given equivalent recognition to an Australian degree. Rather, we have set up processes so that overseas degrees can be properly assessed and, reciprocally, Australian qualifications can be appropriately assessed. Certainly there will be no lowering of standards by this process. Indeed, I think all participants will benefit from the conventions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it a fact that a recent Qantas Airways Ltd flight to London was denied entry into Syrian air space, therefore disrupting the scheduled service? If this is so, what steps are being taken by the Australian Embassy in Damascus to ensure that there is no repetition of these events?

—My brief on this matter is in the following terms: Qantas has advised the Department of Foreign Affairs that its flight QF10 from London to Australia was initially denied entry into Syrian air space on 9 November. The aircraft diverted and intended to use Egyptian air space but was refused entry there too. It again sought and was granted entry into Syrian air space. As a result of these manoeuvres the aircraft then made an unscheduled stop at Bahrain to take on fuel. It does seem that the denial of entry into Syrian air space was only of short duration. Denial of entry to Egyptian air space may have been caused by a misunderstanding on the clearance procedure. Clarification of these matters is being sought by the Department of Foreign Affairs in co-operation with the Department of Aviation. If any further information comes to hand I will be happy to pass it on to Senator Sibraa.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of media reports that the Remembrance Day poppies worn by honourable senators today were manufactured overseas despite every effort on the part of the Returned Services League to find an Australian company willing to make the poppies here? Can the Minister say whether these reports are correct? If they are, can the Minister say whether the apparent lack of interest in this entrepreneurial activity indicates a lack of patriotism by some Australian companies? Further, can he say whether this attitude is likely to diminish the value of the Government's buy Australian campaign?

—I do not accept, and I will not start accepting now, responsibility for the commercial decisions of a whole range of Australian companies. I was not aware that the Remembrance Day poppies were made overseas; so I am unable to say whether that claim is correct. The honourable senator asked: If that is so, does it mean that there is a lack of interest by Australian companies in making Remem- brance Day poppies? The answer to that question appears to be yes. The honourable senator then asked whether this was a blow to the buy Australian campaign. I think the answer to that question is no.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, relates to the alleged desecration of Australian war graves in the Kanchanaburi war cemetery in Thailand recently. It was reported on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation news that human remains were exposed during some work in the vicinity of the cemetery. If this is a fact, what steps are being taken to rectify the situation and to ensure that this unfortunate incident does not occur again?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that in the Asian-Pacific region there are war graves in a number of countries, some of which come under the jurisdiction of the Australian War Graves Commission and others which come under the responsibility of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission, of which we are a part, but for which the responsibility lies principally with the organisation in London. I am specifically aware of the desecration of war graves that took place recently in Kanchanaburi in Thailand. The Government views this very seriously. Consequently Mr Clarke of the Australian War Graves Commission immediately contacted the Commonwealth War Graves Commission in London, which is responsible for the maintenance of the war graves in that country, and it was notified of Australia's very genuine concern about what was taking place.

ANSWER.PARA: We have been advised that the remains that were disturbed have now been replaced and the area has been completely refurbished. I am assured that the Commonwealth War Graves Commission war cemeteries throughout the world-I had the opportunity to look at them last year in the European scene-are meticulously cared for, with appropriate reverence for those who lie in them. It is a matter of regret that the remains were treated as they were in Thailand in recent times. This particular incident was very unfortunate. It occurred during the upgrading of the cemetery without sufficient care being given to the fact that it was a very important and sacred piece of ground. Our concern has been expressed to the authorities in Thailand. I assure those Australians who have expressed their considerable disquiet with what has taken place that it will not happen again and that the maintenance of those war graves is being constantly kept under review by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. In view of the massive incidence of acquired immune deficiency syndrome among the general population of certain African nations, is the Minister able to advise the Senate of the degree of monitoring progress of AIDS in foreign countries and whether it is proposed that short term visitors from badly affected nations should undergo some form of screening before being allowed entry to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Knowles has said, I am aware that AIDS is endemic in some African countries, but it is not necessarily exactly the same virus as we have here. I certainly am aware that the two committees set up by the Minister for Health and the Minister and his Department are monitoring the development of AIDS in overseas countries and the incidence and developments occurring in this disease in overseas countries.

ANSWER.PARA: I will get some details from the Minister for Health as to exactly what plans are afoot in this area. I point out in answering the question that AIDS is not a disease which is readily communicable under normal circumstances. It would be wrong to suggest-I hope Senator Knowles is not suggesting this-that we should take any drastic measures to inhibit the passage of people from countries where AIDS may have a bigger incidence than ours on the grounds that it is easily communicable. This is not so. As I have said in this place many times before, it is a public health problem which so far we have managed to cope with very well in this country and without the hysteria which is associated with it in some other countries. I will get the details sought by Senator Knowles and give them to her as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to an article in Monday's Sun newspaper reporting the Leader of the Opposition as saying that a coalition government's priorities in its first six months of office would be to abolish the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax, the tax on lump sum superannuation and the assets test and that it would also introduce changes to industrial relations legislation, change Medicare to allow people to opt out and abolish bulk billing? Has the Minister any idea of the cost of these measures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only one of those high priority items that Mr Howard identified would not have a significant and direct budgetary consequence-the consequence of blowing out the deficit, a task for which Mr Howard trained himself well in that period in which he was Treasurer. Indeed, when he left that office he had blown out the deficit to almost $10 billion, and apparently--
—Rubbish. That's not true; that's a lie.

—I struck a raw nerve there. He had blown out the prospective deficit to almost $10 billion, so he is well trained to implement the sorts of policies which he says he would implement were he to become Prime Minister. The only one which would not have an adverse and direct budgetary consequence is the proposed industrial relations legislation. That would have an indirect budgetary consequence because if we had a free-for-all on wages outcomes out there in the industrial jungle, which Mr Howard wants, there would be so much industrial strife that gross domestic product would fall and taxation, of course, would fall with it, and the Budget deficit would blow out again.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator McIntosh referred to four items. At this stage the abolition of the capital gains tax would probably cost about $25m; the abolition of the fringe benefits tax at this stage would cost about $520m; abolishing the lump sum tax on superannuation payments at this stage would cost about $80m; and the abolition of the assets test would cost about $150m at this stage. What any of those measures would do to address the country's paramount economic problem-that is, the size of our current account deficit-is a complete mystery. None of those things would in any way address it. More importantly, or equally importantly probably, is the fact that the cost of the abolition of those items-in particular, the fringe benefits tax-would grow rapidly in subsequent years. If, as Mr Howard said, a coalition government were to abolish the fringe benefits tax lock, stock and barrel, the green light would then be given to every employer in the country to evade as much tax as possible by converting to the maximum degree possible income that is presently or prospectively being paid as wages into income paid in kind, thereby evading taxation; that is, unless Mr Howard is to accept the policy of Mr Sinclair, reiterated again last week, which is to enforce section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act and require employers to provide all the details of the fringe benefits that they pay to their employees but make the employee directly responsible for the payment.

If a coalition government were to adopt Mr Sinclair's policy as distinct from Mr Howard's policy, which policies appear to be completely contradictory on the surface, that then raises the question of for what period a coalition government would strictly enforce-it claims that it believes it can be enforced-section 26 (e) of the taxation Act. If a government were to go down that course, on the presumption that section 26 (e) can be effectively enforced, it should be enforced retrospectively for a considerable period. That is a very big slug that the wage earners of Australia can count on getting from a coalition government, should one be elected.

I note also that the Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia in Western Australia said that the Liberal Party is totally opposed to the fringe benefits tax legislation because it is immoral and evil that one person should have to pay tax on payments that he makes to another person. Precisely that has been done with payroll tax for the last 40 years or so, so one must presume that if a coalition government were to be elected payroll tax would be abolished and the pay as you earn taxpayers would be hit with another $4 billion a year slug to cope with the revenue losses.

The other specific item to which Senator McIntosh's question referred was Mr Howard's half-baked proposal for people who choose to take out private insurance to opt out of the Medicare levy. That is about as well thought through as his ministerial arrangements and the establishment of a Minister and ministry for bits and pieces. If that were to be done, it could be reasonably assumed that the taxpayers with taxable incomes above $22,000, which is about 39 per cent of all taxpayers, would opt out and the levy collection would be reduced by some $938m. The final effect of that policy would be not to lead to any savings, of course, but to induce a large extra dollop of non-funded expenditure. The direct effect in the first year of his capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax and lump sum payments measures and the abolition of the assets test would be $775m. That sum would balloon very rapidly should those policies be implemented and in no time at all the coalition government would be back to the same sort of $10 billion deficit that the last coalition Government left this Government with.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TRADING HOURS ORDINANCE

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 October Senator Lewis asked me a question in respect of the Trading Hours Ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister for Territories has provided me with the following response: The Government, the retail industry and the relevant unions have made substantial progress in discussing changes to the Trading Hours Ordinance 1962. However, the Minister for Territories has agreed not to introduce amendments to the Ordinance until he has examined a decision just handed down by Mr Justice Macken, Chairman of the Retail Trade Industrial Tribunal, which addresses the issue of working conditions for employees in the retail industry in New South Wales. The Minister's Department will be providing him with advice on this matter shortly. The Minister is confident that, once the parties and the Government have considered the Macken decision, agreement will be reached on amendments to the Ordinance.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 11 November, from Senator Archer:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
``That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to uphold the Memorandum of Understanding between the Commonwealth and Tasmanian Governments on forestry operations in Tasmania which is being overridden by the Prime Minister who is ignoring the bipartisan opposition to his cynical political grandstanding from both the Tasmanian Premier Robin Gray and the Leader of the Opposition and former ALP Federal President, Neil Batt.''
Senator for the State of Tasmania
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to uphold the Memorandum of Understanding between the Commonwealth and Tasmanian Governments on forestry operations in Tasmania which is being overridden by the Prime Minister who is ignoring the bipartisan opposition to his cynical political grandstanding from both the Tasmanian Premier Robin Gray and the Leader of the Opposition and former ALP Federal President, Neil Batt.

The debate we are now having is not a conservation debate. The debate that we are having is about the politics and the intergovernmental relations, not about conservation. It is a classic piece of Hawke's political grandstanding. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has deliberately lit this political fire in the interests of his Government, obviously to arrest its declining popularity. The Government has become just as good as anybody else at reading the figures in the papers. It knows what its mail is full of; it knows what everybody in the electorate is saying; so it has decided that it has to try to do something about it. In searching around for an issue it thought it ought to go to the popular issues. Senator Richardson was good enough to produce a list of those popular issues. Amongst other things, of course, he spotted the Tasmanian hat stand, as I would call it. He said: `We have to give the young people and the women something in the conservation area to hang their hats on'. I do not see Tasmania as just a political hat stand, but that is the way that he sees it. In looking for this hat stand it was decided to go for Tasmania. The Government thought: `We cannot lose any seats in Tasmania; we have none to lose. So what can we trump up?' The Government also tried to gain a bit of cheap publicity at the same time. What a miserable mistake it made. If the Government had bothered to read the agreement, to check the facts, to take a simple step such as that, things might have been different. This was a classic Whitlam era `crash through or crash' approach-another stupid, useless, heavy-handed, belligerent move. The Prime Minister or any of his staff who had been around him for four or five months-I realise that he has had trouble with his staff, nearly all of whom have gone of late-would surely have remembered the arrangement that had been made. But no, there is nobody like that, and nobody on his staff can read. The position is perfectly clear.

The actions taken by the Prime Minister clearly demonstrate what happened. When he wanted to get something flaring, he wrote to the Premier. If he had bothered to get anybody to glance at the legislation, he would have found that that is not the way to go about things if there is a problem. The problem-solving mechanism is clearly laid down in the memorandum of understanding. It says nowhere in that memorandum that the Prime Minister should go off half-cocked and write to the Premier. The memorandum says that the matter shall be dealt with between officers, and should the officers be un- able to get an agreement it should fall into the hands of Mr Kerin, specifically named, representing the Commonwealth, and Mr Ray Groom, Minister for Forests, representing the Tasmanian Government. That is fairly simply and straightforward. Anybody who reads the document could clearly follow clause 30.

The document also goes on to state specifically that there is no place for gratuitous and unjustified threats and the use of coercive powers by either the Commonwealth or the States. As there are no coercive powers, how is it that on 3 November we saw the leaking of a letter from the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) asking for advice regarding the use of the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme as something that the Government could hold over those miserable Tasmanians to make them do something it wanted them to do that was outside the agreement? The Government looked to see how it could cut off the freight equalisation scheme, but found that that course did not look very good. Then the Government considered revoking export licences. Where is that covered in the gentleman's agreement, this memorandum of understanding, this dealing between two governments at the highest level? Is this not a great way to go about it? It certainly seems coercive to me and is a clear breach of the agreement. Clause 30 does not provide that that is the way one goes about trying to solve a problem if one believes a problem exists.

Tasmania was a party to this memorandum of understanding and it has upheld its terms. The ink is barely dry. The agreement has been around only since 12 June, and already the Federal Government has forgotten what the document said or has not been able to find somebody to read it. It is hardly out of date, but the Prime Minister's advice on it has been bad. Perhaps it is just that he has lost all his senior staff and cannot find anybody else about at the moment, but one would have thought somebody would have straightened him out after his first mistake, except that he has gone on repeating it. If he would get out of it, we might discover that there is no problem and that both parties up to this time are still satisfactorily following the memorandum of understanding. Mr Gray is a little perplexed. First, he is not a party to the agreement nor to the problem solving, but he has had to come into this and has deliberately written to the Prime Minister pointing out the facts, making sure that there will be no further problems. I wish to quote parts of a letter that passed between these two gentlemen:

The Jackeys Marsh Quamby Bluff area was, at the time of the signing of the Memorandum of Understanding on 12 June 1986, already subject to current operational planning within the meaning of clause 27 of the Memorandum of Understanding. Indeed, the harvesting of logs has been taking place in this area for some years.

In his very fragmented advice, the Prime Minister was not told that clause 27 has proviso clauses in it. It specifically mentions that clauses 23 to 26 do not apply where certain other things have occurred. The quotation continues:

The current operations represent a scheduled resumption of logging under the 5-year Plan of Operation in conformity with the Working Plan for the Crown Forests of North and North-East Tasmania, 1983. Logging operations will comply with the special conditions for protecting the environment set out in the ``Proposed Forest Operations in the Jackeys Marsh Quamby Bluff area EIS'' reprinted in August 1984.

Clause 27 of the memorandum of understanding provides that clauses 23 to 26 specifically list those conditions. If we continue from there and start to look in the appendix, we find that this particular area is listed in the appendix as being accepted by the parties as complying with that particular set of circumstances. What more can we have than that? Yet the Prime Minister still goes on about the matter. The Tasmanian Premier has absolutely no desire to get into an argument over an issue which is a non-issue in the first place. I do not see, any more than the Premier does, why Tasmania should be a staging ground for a losing government in Canberra just so that it can try to win a few cheap votes somewhere else.

It is not as if the comments that are being made have all been put forward from one side. Let me quote from yesterday's Australian Broadcasting Corporation program The World Today in which the following comment was made:

Yes, but let me say that on this particular issue the Federal Government are wrong and there is no point in being in politics unless you are prepared to speak the truth. The truth on this occasion is that the Federal Government are wrong and I intend to say so.

I did not say that; Premier Gray did not say that. Those comments were made by Mr Batt. Mr Batt is a former President of the Australian Labor Party and he held that position when many honourable senators were members of the Party. They know that on an issue such as this Mr Batt can at least read a document. We come back to that point. Mr Batt was asked by the interviewer a question about the attitudes of conservationists. He said:

The logging there ought to continue for three reasons. One is because it was part of the agreement that was signed previously between the Commonwealth and the State and therefore logging was, of course, seen in that. The second reason is that the logging proposal is part of a management plan which preserves environmental values. And the third reason is that forestry has been going on there for some time and in particular, for the last four years.

I am not saying that; Mr Gray is not saying that. Those were the comments of the State Leader of the Opposition. That is the view of the Labor Opposition in Tasmania-the people who are there to oppose, to try to get rid of, the Tasmanian State Government. What are they doing? They are saying that the Tasmanian Government is right. Let us look at the local Press, which does not have the problem of having to oppose. In the Hobart Mercury on 5 November there was this headline: `State Labor blasts federal forestry ploy'. On 7 November that same paper ran this headline: `Batt slams Hawke's ``cavalier approach'' '. This is the sort of thing that is going on. How can anyone here defend the Prime Minister when he goes on in this way? The National Times on Sunday ran an article under the heading `Skin deep as a greenie, that's Hawke', in which Robert Haupt made this comment about the electorate:
They are not going to be convinced by pictures of Hawke in the Kakadu or a stand against the Tasmanians that cost his Government nothing, for they have memories.
That is the voters that he is talking about-not the forestry people or the townies. He is referring to the voters in general. He also stated that Mr Hawke had said:
I would have serious reservations with any proposal that would result in the imposition of a more restrictive framework on political mineral exploration development . . .

That is a quote from the same article. He refers to the Prime Minister holding up Kakadu as the ultimate. But only a week or two earlier the Prime Minister had written to Mr Barry Cohen saying that the nation's current account deficit was the reason that he did not want a no-mining clause. It is just extraordinary how a couple of weeks later the deficit was no longer supreme and heritage had been notched up the list. When the statements are so blatantly shallow and so consistently inconsistent, how can we take them seriously?

The agreement covers a very wide range of issues and was prepared jointly. It was done by agreement; there was no coercion. It covers a range of matters such as land use management and the Commonwealth's export powers. It mentions with pride the competency of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission. It covers sustained yield harvesting, regeneration, rare and endangered species and so on. Senator Richardson was trying to be helpful when he made his suggestions but clearly he also had not read the agreement. It was unfortunate that he made the suggestions that he did, which put the Prime Minister out on a limb and led him to state things that were incorrect. With the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) also involved, it is fairly difficult to try to keep the facts straight.

I noticed that one of the editorials referred to the memorandum of understanding and stated that it was very clearly being dealt with specifically as a memorandum of misunderstanding and that the Federal Government could certainly be accused of doing everything possible to make sure that the facts did not come across. I have already quoted the Attorney-General. An editorial in the Examiner of 7 November stated:

There is a growing suspicion that the whole confrontation has been politically orchestrated by the Federal Government in an effort to win back the conservation vote which it has alienated by its policy on Kakadu national park and the export of uranium to France.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that is right.
—It surely is right. The editorial in the Mercury of 7 November quoted the memorandum of misunderstanding and stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In this instance, it appears that most of the misunderstanding emanates from Canberra. The light of recognition that such a blunder may have been made appears to be shining now on the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke. On Wednesday, Mr Hawke, in a most presumptuous manner, ordered the State Government to halt logging at Jackeys Marsh. Yesterday, the Federal Government was more circumspect, far more conciliatory. Instead of orders, it was suggesting that in a spirit of co-operation, its Minister of Primary Industry and the Tasmanian Minister for Forests meet under the auspices of the Memorandum of Understanding . . .
At last they got around to reading the document. When all else fails, read the instructions: That is a famous maxim that has held good for a long time and I recommend it now to the Government.

We have to wonder when we hear talk about agreements and memoranda. Over the last few years we have had all sorts of agreements, undertakings and understandings. We had an agreement on land rights. We had an agreement and an undertaking on the sale of uranium to France, and in fact on uranium mining. We have had undertakings on student fees. We even had an undertaking about capital gains tax-`In words that even members of the Opposition can understand, there will be no capital gains tax'. We have had these sorts of undertakings, and so on. but what is the value of undertakings? How can we cope with a government that produces a memorandum of understanding and then tries to read into it something that just is not there? The whole thing is absolutely clear.

One of the things that worry Tasmanians a bit is that a funny mixture of drop-ins and drop-outs turns up there from time to time. They usually stay for a short while or even for a year or two, and then they do what is best-that is, ultimately, they leave. In the meantime, they presume to tell us how to run Tasmania. We Tasmanians know more about Tasmania than they do. No State in Australia has a greater appreciation of, or places greater value on, its natural gifts than does Tasmania. No State has a more active parks regime or a greater concern for the beautiful things than Tasmania. No State goes to the trouble that Tasmania does to balance its natural values with its community needs. We do not need the sort of `help' that we get from more and more of these people, because it just gets worse and worse. As I say, the best thing, fortunately, is that most of them leave before too long.

We must also remember that one in seven of all Tasmanians derives his living from forests and forestry. They are the true conservationists. Without conservation, they have no livelihood. The reafforestation taking place at present is vastly ahead of forest use, and the future of the State depends very heavily on keeping it that way. That is the way in which people are working at present in Tasmania. The agreement was made to work. It can work provided that the Government in Canberra does not try to renege on it. Let is go ahead with that agreement. That is the thing to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very unfortunate that Senator Archer has brought this motion to the Senate today in the terms in which he moved it. In the Government's view, it concerns a serious matter. The question of the preservation of the natural heritage in Tasmania or, indeed, in any part of Australia is important and an appropriate matter for debate by honourable senators. But the particular terms in which Senator Archer has chosen to cast his motion demonstrate that he is interested not in the conservation of the natural heritage of his State nor in the legitimate needs for employment of Tasmanians, but rather in some sort of garbled, petty, party-based point scoring. I listened very closely to what Senator Archer said, but I found it most unconvincing. I could not be convinced even of his basic seriousness in raising this matter here today. He really seemed to want to make derogatory comments about the staff of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and a few matters such as that and generally to waste the time of the Senate. That is unfortunate, because the issues of the conservation of our environment and heritage are of compelling concern and interest to most honourable senators. Certainly they are so to our Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I may respond-although it is almost not worth doing so-to the suggestions in Senator Archer's comments that somehow the Prime Minister has just discovered the environmental issue, or somehow our Government has, whimsically and erratically, taken up an interest in this fashion. I find it absolutely extraordinary that these claims can come from Liberal Tasmanians, since surely they will remember, as the rest of Australia remembers, and as the environmental movement remembers very well, that one of the first acts of the Hawke Government was to take dramatic steps to fulfil an electoral promise, which was to save the Gordon and Franklin rivers and the wilderness area in South West Tasmania. It seems incredible that that event could have slipped the minds of Opposition senators. They were very raucous-as they are being today-and very vociferous in their opposition to that course of action, which we took, as I have said, as one of our first major acts on being elected to govern Australia by the people of Australia. We saved the wilderness in the south-west of Tasmania; we saved the Gordon and Franklin rivers; we prevented the building of an unnecessary dam that would have had a destructive effect not only on the wilderness area but also on the overall economic development of Tasmania. So any suggestion that we are Johnnies-come-lately in these issues is incredibly wrong and silly in the light of our record. The issues, relating to the conservation of our environment and heritage are of importance, but it is most unfortunate and regrettable that Senator Archer has chosen to pursue them in such a sniping, irrelevant and quite disorganised fashion.

In relation to the issue of logging in the Jackeys Marsh area and the memorandum of understanding covering it, both in terms of its role as an area that has been nominated and recorded as part of the National Estate and as part of the logging industry in Tasmania, let me make one basic point as firmly as I can: The Commonwealth Government is not overriding the agreements reached with the Tasmanian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's news.

—It is news to Senator Watson, and I think he should pay attention to this because he is a serious senator, unlike some of his colleagues. I think he does take quite seriously the employment and environmental issues affecting his State. Let me explain the matter to him. Logging in the Jackeys Marsh area is governed by the Commonwealth-State memorandum of understanding and by subsidiary environmental impact statements. We are simply asking that the procedures and requirements set out in those agreements be adhered to, and they have not been.
—So are we.

—At least Senator Watson is paying attention. Last month Jackeys Marsh was listed on the National Estate register as the result of the independent decision of an independent body-the Australian Heritage Commission. The decision was taken without any interference or influence from our Government. The decision to list Jackeys Marsh has logical and legal consequences. The Commonwealth and the State are meant to discuss the heritage value of the area. That is one of the main elements of the memorandum of understanding.
—Would you tell me where?

—Let me be more specific, since there is a great deal of ignorance on the other side of the chamber. The process of consultation is outlined in the memorandum of understanding, in particular in clause 27, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Forestry Commission will advise ways in which registered values have been taken into account and, if planning so allows, will take account of comments from DPI.
