Of course, that process has not occurred, owing to the pre-emptive action of the Tasmanian Government. Clearly there is now disagreement between the two governments. The Commonwealth Government therefore draws attention to clause 30 of the memorandum of understanding, which states:

In the event that any dispute arises over matters concerning forest operations and other export related matters which cannot be reconciled at officer level, the two relevant Ministers will meet and discuss the problem with the intent of reaching a mutually acceptable solution.

Senator Watson, who is following my argument, agrees. It is clear that those talks have not taken place. They ought to take place and we stand ready to have our Minister involve himself in those talks. We have not as yet been able to arrange such talks, although I am pleased that it appears that they will take place. They are an essential requirement of the memorandum of understanding and any delay in the holding of those talks has not been as a result of any defects in the performance of the Commonwealth; it has been as a result of a problem with the Tasmanian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's only because you backed off.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I know that Senator Walters is unable to contain herself but I am making a serious argument and I would appreciate some lessening of her constant babbling.
—Order! There are far too many interjections and I ask that they cease.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is an important matter, as I have said, but unfortunately one Tasmanian senator is prepared to treat this as just another opportunity for grandstanding. The memorandum of understanding requires that we should hold those talks. The Commonwealth wishes to hold them, and indeed it now appears that they are imminent. Until those talks are held the outcome in terms of the extent to which, if any, logging can continue in the Jackeys Marsh area compatible with the requirement to preserve the National Estate values cannot be determined. We are willing to hold talks as soon as possible and we are accelerating our own consideration of the issue. To that end I can assure the Senate that our advisory committee on the Tasmanian forestry operation will report on Jackeys Marsh within three weeks, and the Heritage Commission will complete its work on the National Estate values of the area within two weeks. I repeat those deadlines: Three weeks and two weeks. That is not a long time to wait; that is not a heavy imposition on the State Government, on the Tasmanian Forestry Commission or on the logging workers at Jackeys Marsh. The brief delay we have proposed will give the Commonwealth and Tasmania time to discuss the issues concerned. We will have time to follow due process; we will have time to meet our obligations and commitments; we will have time to make a responsible decision. In order that these matters can proceed, logging should cease now and the issues should be properly discussed. I know that is a particular concern of Senator Sanders. All we ask for is the cessation of an action which should not have been undertaken pre-emptively until due process can be followed. Unilateral decisions, pre-emptive strikes, media campaigns, from any source, and motions such as Senator Archer's motion simply do not assist the resolution of the issues concerned.
—But why did you make the threats to woodchip licences and to freight equalisation?

—There have been no threats on the part of the Commonwealth but there has been confrontationist behaviour on the part of the Gray Government, and that confrontation will only delay the resolution of our differences. It will only divert our attention from the wider issue of the conservation of the heritage involved. I remind the Senate that that is the Commonwealth Government's interest in this matter. Our attitude is not divisive or provocative. We simply want to weigh up the matters concerned and make a considered judgment, and we want that judgment to be made as quickly as possible. The Commonwealth policy does not in any sense at all reflect fundamental opposition to the logging and chipping industry in Tasmania. We recognise the vital importance of that industry for employment, for investment and for economic growth. We on the mainland recognise that we depend on products of that industry. We have seen the ways in which Tasmania is developing its forest industry. That industry, for example, is now the basis for a remarkable revival in Tasmanian crafts and design. The products of that revival are second to none in their quality and their value for export. The wood carving and turning industry in Tasmania is an example to the rest of Australia in relation to the refinement of our industry, the exploration of new products and techniques and making sure that we add value to what we produce.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention the forestry industry in that sense because I believe that we need to take account of the full range of issues before us today. We want to help accelerate and facilitate economic development in Tasmania. We also want to help encourage the preservation of Tasmania's environment and heritage. That environment and heritage is one of Tasmania's and Australia's greatest natural treasures. It is also one of Tasmania's most tangible and substantial economic assets, an asset which produces enormous revenue in tourism and related trades and industries. That revenue is also essential to the continued economic health and prosperity of Tasmania. Let us then look at the full range of issues at stake here, which is something that Senator Archer has conspicuously failed to do. Let us go on to implement our agreements with Tasmania-fully, formally and fairly. That will not take long to do and it is a sensible and straightforward way to proceed. Senator Archer's motion has quite different intentions and motives and ought to be rejected by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it difficult to support this urgency motion. I certainly support the first part of the motion, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to uphold the Memorandum of Understanding between the Commonwealth and Tasmanian Governments on forestry operations in Tasmania . . .
But I simply cannot agree with the second part of the motion, which states:

. . . which is being overridden by the Prime Minister who is ignoring the bipartisan opposition to his cynical political grandstanding from both the Tasmanian Premier Robin Gray and the Leader of the Opposition and former ALP Federal President, Neil Batt.
I was thinking of amending this motion but it is a long and convoluted process to amend an urgency motion; so I think I will be forced simply to vote against it when a vote is taken.

Senator Archer mentioned the gentleman's agreement between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Mr Robin Gray. The difficulty is, of course, that Robin Gray is no gentleman. He never was and never will be. The Feds will have to be hard-nosed in this matter, because Robin Gray has proved over the years that he will take whatever political advantage he can, personal or otherwise. The man is a demagogue. He has noted through history that the way of staying in office is to create a despised group and then to set the community against it. Throughout history all despots have done this. He has learned his lesson well. He is not a quick learner but he has learned that. So he created the greenies at the time of the Franklin Dam debate and he was successful in stirring up hatred, splitting families and splitting friends in Tasmania for his personal political gain. He created scars, some of which have not healed to this day.

Of course, lots of acrimonious statements were made at that time, but in retrospect historians will look back at Robin Gray's performance as strictly one of a self-seeking political manipulator. Incidentally, another person who was active in that area was Harry Butler. He came out against the dam at the time he was working for the State Government. We see that he is now doing the same thing as a biostitute, a biological prostitute, in working for the Northern Territory Government as a consultant and saying that Kakadu stage 2 should not be listed. So a lot of people in that day and age were seen to be less than sincere then and they are less than sincere now.
Let me go on to the second part of the motion, which states:
. . . bipartisan opposition . . . from . . . Premier Robin Gray and the Leader of the Opposition . . . Neil Batt.

What about Neil Batt? Neil Batt has always been a creature of the forestry industry of Tasmania. He has been owned lock, stock and barrel by the forestry industry of Tasmania. We need look no further than at a letter from David Bills, General Manager of Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd, Forest Products, Norton House, 190 Charles Street, Launceston, Tasmania 7250, which is dated 15 April 1986 and is addressed to Mr R. C. Bannister, Secretary of the Australian Timber Workers Union, 249 New Town Road, New Town, Tasmania 7008. The letter states:
Dear Cec,

Press reports recently have indicated that your union is withdrawing support from the Australian Labor Party because of the disappointing showing of the Tasmanian Parliamentary Labor Party over forestry issues in the past twelve months. I trust you will take my comments as following in the right spirit.
I think we have to appreciate the difficulty of the Tasmanian PLP-
that is, Parliamentary Labor Party-

in dealing with an issue which involves their colleagues in Canberra on `the other side'. Inevitably they had to give a public impression of reasonableness-of consultation-rather than the Tasmanian Government, which could show considerable aggression towards a Canberra government of a different colour.

Nevertheless in my dealings with Dr Amos, Michael Field and latterly, Neil Batt, I can assure you they have been staunch supporters of the forestry cause. They and Senators Aulich and Tate opened doors for us in Canberra and gave us continual feedback on the `state of play' there. They listened carefully to our comment on the State Labor Party forestry policy, and many of our comments were incorporated.
I have always made it clear to your members at our plants that we-
that is, APPM-
were never in any doubt as to the support for our cause within the Parliamentary Labor Party in Tasmania.
I trust that in the near future the differences can be resolved and a better understanding of the position of the PLP can be obtained, once again enabling you to give your support.
I have sent a copy of this letter to your stewards at our mills so that they can see our viewpoint.
Yours sincerely,
David J Bills,
General Manager.

Obviously Bills and Batt have done a deal: Batt supports APPM and Bills gets the ATWU to reaffiliate. Soon after this letter the ATWU did reaffiliate. As I have said, the ATWU is the Australian Timber Workers Union. So we see that Neil Batt is actually in the pocket of the timber industry. So there was not really bilateral opposition to this; there was unilateral opposition by the Liberals in Tasmania. The Federal Australian Labor Party has seen increasingly clearly that there are two Liberal parties and no Labor parties in Tasmania. If we look further into the history of Neil Batt and the forest debate we see an article written by Andrew Tilt in the Launceston Examiner of 20 July 1978. Andrew Tilt is now one of the chief advisers to Robin Gray. The article is headed `Government axes forestry industry probe' and it states:
A major investigation of the State's forestry industry-the Everett Board of Inquiry into forest royalties and charges-has been abandoned by the State Government.
The Premier, Mr Lowe, announced yesterday that the Government would now examine the forestry industry using information from woodchip companies and other timber-based industries.
The State Cabinet made the decision two weeks ago.
It was strongly opposed by the former minister in charge of forestry and the HEC, Mr Lohrey, and is the real reason for his removal from the portfolios.
It is understood that a new study of the forestry industry by the Treasurer Mr Batt-replacing the Everett Board-will be a much softer investigation.
The Everett inquiry was appointed earlier this year to look specifically into forest royalties and charges.
The Opposition Whip, Mr Pearsall-
who is now the Deputy Premier-
described the circumstances surrounding the abandoning of the Everett inquiry into forestry royalties as a sham.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long ago was that?

—That was in 1978 and Neil Batt has not changed because a leopard does not change its spots. Much has been said about interference by the Federal Government in the affairs of Tasmania, as if Tasmania is in control of its own destiny. What utter rubbish. Let us see whom we are talking about. Who is APPM? It is Associated Pulp and Paper Mills, which is owned by North Broken Hill Holdings Ltd-that is not a Tasmanian firm-and is sending its profits back to the mainland. Tasmanian Pulp and Forest Holdings Ltd is also--
—Go home, Yank.
—I just heard a senator say `Go home, Yank', which I take to be an ethnic slur. I demand that she retract that statement.
—I think the honourable senator should withdraw that.
—Is that an insult?
—Senator Sanders has taken offence at that statement and I ask the honourable senator to withdraw it.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, if he is a senator for Tasmania, perhaps he could go home.
—Order! The honourable senator must withdraw unconditionally.
—I withdraw.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I think it is time we recognised that we have here people from all over the world. Although it may be a joke to those who consider themselves to be native born Australians, those of us who come from elsewhere are sensitive about these issues. The Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd owns 50 per cent of Petersville Industries Ltd, which owns Forest Resources, another Tasmanian woodchipping company. Therefore, the Liberal Party of Australia, and I suppose the National Party of Australia, should really look further than their own statements if they want to see exactly who controls Tasmania. It is certainly not Tasmanians; it is people on the mainland and the transnationals overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the overall consideration of who actually controls the resources? The national parks in Australia should be truly national parks. National Estate areas should have control exerted by a Federal government because it is patently obvious that local governments are incapable of rational land use decisions. They are too easily influenced by big money and too easily bought off. Giving the local bodies control over a valuable national resource or a valuable national environmental area is a bit like handing over the crown jewels to a bunch of gorillas. The local politicians simply have no idea of the true value of these areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you reckon they are the best that money can buy?

—Yes. If we need to look at an example of this it is useful to draw attention once again to the Franklin Dam. The State governments of the day-there was really no difference between the Labor Government and the Liberal Government-wished to dam the Franklin. They said: `We need the power. We must have it. We must have the power or else Tasmania's development will come to a halt'. A few years later we find that the dam was not needed after all, that the Government was influenced by the Hydro-Electric Commission which had overinflated its demand curves, as we had said, by some 18 per cent. It will be worse in the future. It has no new power contracts and is not able to sell the power out of the Pieman scheme. The Hawke Government, to its eternal credit, intervened and saved the local government from a tremendous financial disaster as well as an environmental disaster. The Federal Government stopped a scheme which was patently unnecessary. In the same way the Federal Government will be taking action-soon, I hope-to stop the woodchipping of the National Estate areas of Tasmania, which would be a similar disaster not only financially but also environmentally. It would be a financial disaster because the forests are not being regenerated as was claimed earlier. The forests are being neglected.

SPEECH.PARA: The Legislative Council of Tasmania, which is not one of the more radical organisations, was quite critical of the actions of Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd in regenerating land. It indicated that from 1972 to 1982, 7,961 hectares were regenerated on its freehold land while only 4,532 hectares were regenerated on its public concession land. The Council was concerned about what appeared to be far greater regeneration on freehold land as opposed to concession land or government land. The APPM made some excuses, but the Council nevertheless felt that `this variation exposes a weakness in forest management under a concession act'.

It is imperative that the Federal Government does act to preserve these areas from woodchipping. I would like to see this action extended. Other areas in Australia are threatened by woodchipping-the Errinundra plateau in Victoria, the area around Eden in New South Wales and the area around Manjimup in Western Australia. I sincerely hope that the action which is to be taken soon by the Hawke Government in stopping woodchipping in the sensitive areas around Jackeys Marsh will be extended to other areas where the forests are threatened and that the Government will make this an ongoing process. The Federal Government must act soon and decisively to protect Tasmania from the rip-off artists who presently control the Tasmanian Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will start by quoting Mr Batt, the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania. He is the leader of the Australian Labor Party in Tasmania. He is quoted in a newspaper article which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Hawke Government was `clearly acting outside the MOU signed by the two Governments' by taking unilateral action over Jackeys Marsh.
The article previously stated:
. . . Mr Neil Batt, said the Jackeys Marsh area clearly was listed in a Memorandum of Understanding as an area which could be logged subject to proper management . . .
`It must be made clear that we strongly oppose what the Commonwealth is attempting to do in relation to our forest operations . . .
The article stated that Mr Batt objected to Mr Hawke's cavalier approach. It also reported Mr Batt as saying:
. . . there is no way that the Commonwealth can justify intervention . . .

In a nutshell, that is what all Tasmanians believe; not just the Liberal Party but both parties in Tasmania. Why has Mr Hawke taken this action? We have been told very clearly that Dr Brown, MHA, had a meeting with Mr Hawke about forestry in Tasmania just a couple of weeks ago. No doubt he said to Mr Hawke that this was a good issue for him to take up seeing he had lost the conservation vote over his uranium sales to France, over the Daintree Rainforest approach that the Government took in Queensland and over the decision that Kakadu National Park ought to be mined in stages 2 and 3. Remember when the Prime Minister was overridden in Cabinet on that matter? That is why Mr Hawke has taken this action. Dr Brown told him that it was a good way of attempting to get the conservation vote back. Senator Richardson made it very clear when he made a list of areas that the Labor Government should concentrate on to get its traditional vote back that conservation was one of the main areas.

While the Prime Minister was at Kakadu he made this idiotic statement that deeply embarrassed the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). This is very obvious by the fact that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), who has nothing to do with primary industry and nothing to do with the department that signed the memorandum of understanding, is in charge of this debate and not the Minister who should have been in charge of it. Senator Walsh has completely backed off and gone out of the Senate chamber altogether because of Mr Kerin's embarrassment. It was Mr Kerin who signed the memorandum.

I find Senator Ryan's speech most enlightening. She followed directions very clearly. In her answer to Senator Sanders at Question Time today she left him so confused that he said: `Can I take it that the Government is not going to do anything?' Senator Ryan has indeed played it down well. An editorial in the Mercury stated:
It seems someone may have read the Memorandum, and realised that the ground Mr Hawke was standing on was not quite as firm as first believed.

Let us look at that memorandum of understanding. I think it is important that the memorandum, which is what the matter of urgency is about, should be discussed. It certainly was not discussed by Senator Sanders in his speech. Let us look at the appendix to the memorandum. That is the area that Jackeys Marsh and Quamby Bluff come under. On page 15, under the heading `Type 3', it is stated:
Export licences will include a condition that . . .
The condition for the Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff area states:
Forest Operations will be in accordance with management guidelines as indicated in the EIS on woodchip export and in the Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff EIS.

Nothing at all in the memorandum states that any logging in the Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff area could be prevented, so long as those conditions are abided by. The Forestry Commission has taken great pains to follow this environmental impact statement and to monitor it. It will ensure that it is well abided by. Senator Ryan said that it existed in the appendix but that things had altered now that the Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff area had been listed in the register of the National Estate. I asked the honourable senator: Where does it say in that memorandum that, should an area be listed in the register of the National Estate, the situation would alter? The Minister was unable to show me where in that memorandum it is stated that, should an area be listed, the memorandum would be altered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you read clause 23?

—I draw type 3 to Senator Coates's attention. He really is the epitome of the Labor senators from Tasmania. He would no more stand up for his State than any of them. He is a hardline Left senator who will never stand up for any employment in his State. Of course, the other Tasmanian Labor senators have been out of the chamber during the debate. All the Tasmanian senators on the Liberal side have been here during the debate, but on the Labor side there is one senator who is renowned for never standing up for his State. Let us get back to type 3 because I believe it is terribly important.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I take offence at Senator Walters's accusations about my attitude to employment in Tasmania and standing up for my State. I ask her to withdraw them.
—Senator Coates has taken exception to Senator Walters's statement about him.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, can I talk to the point of order, please, because it is very important--
—I have ruled, Senator. You should withdraw.
—It is very important that parliamentary language be brought into this.
—Senator Coates has taken exception--
—That is not fair.
—It is fair.
—No, it is not. It is dreadful.
—Order! I am sorry, Senator Walters, but you must withdraw. Senator Coates has taken exception.

—I wish to speak to the point of order. I suggest that Senator Coates may well have a point of personal explanation if he wishes to speak on the subject, but clearly there is no point of order. None of the items in the Standing Orders concerning points of order is covered. I suggest that at the conclusion of the debate Senator Coates may well be able to make a personal explanation and demonstrate where Senator Walters is wrong.
—Senator Coates, do you find what Senator Walters said offensive to you?
—Yes, I did. That is what I said, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Sanders achieved a withdrawal.
—According to the Standing Orders, Senator Walters, I must ask you to withdraw.

—I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President. Obviously in this place anyone at all can take exception to anything and have it withdrawn from now on. That has set a precedent in this place, and it is absolute nonsense. Let us get back to the type 3 export licence. With regard to the Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff area it is very precise. Let us look at the other areas. The forestry operations at Douglas River have to have the views of the Minister for Primary Industry taken into account. The operations on the Tasman Peninsula have to have the views of the Minister for Primary Industry taken into account, as does the Tooms Lake conservation area, but the Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff area does not have to have the Minister's views taken into consideration. It is very important that we understand exactly what the memorandum of understanding is. As I said, it has placed Mr Kerin in a dreadful position. The Prime Minister has made threats to Tasmania that he will remove the benefits of the freight equalisation scheme from any company that logs in the areas that he wants left untouched. What a disgraceful situation that is. Companies wanting to set up business in Tasmania have hanging over their heads this threat that, should the Prime Minister of the day dis- agree with something they may do, he will withdraw their right to the freight equalisation scheme. That does not apply only to logging; that applies also now to every other area of industry in the whole of Tasmania, and it is really nothing more than blatant blackmail in the worst possible degree. It is, I believe, stupid and arrogant and a sinister way of going about it.

SPEECH.PARA: This has all happened while representatives of the company are preparing to depart for Japan for negotiations in regard to Japan's purchasing wood pulp. Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd is anxious to build a new pulp mill in Tasmania and is negotiating for Japan to purchase that wood pulp. There is now only one way in which that wood pulp mill will be set up; that is, if the climate is right. At the moment all we need is the right climate for a guarantee of resources. Because the value of the dollar is so low, all is ideal for the mill to be set up and our exports could be taken advantage of. It is an ideal time, the value of the dollar being what it is, for this to happen, yet we need very desperately the security of supply. The company has already received expressions of concern regarding the likelihood of the guarantee of continuity of its exports, and we find that the Prime Minister has now ruined that negotiating ability of the representatives of the company who are setting off for Japan.

Mr Hawke is acting against two things: He is clearly acting against the memorandum of understanding, and he is clearly acting against the recommendations and the general thrust of his own Forestry and Forest Products Industry Council. The Labor Government set up that Council to advise Senator Button and Mr Kerin, and its members are from unions, industry management and, indeed, the departments. That Council has advised the Government, firstly, that Australia has a future for pulp export and, secondly, that there is a need for reliability of resources. The Prime Minister has now put at jeopardy those two things on which his Ministers personally have been advised by their Council. Their Council has advised the Government that Australia's future is in this area, but the Prime Minister has put that at risk. Indeed, I hope that the editorial in the Mercury is true and that someone has now read the memorandum to him and said to him: `You do not have a leg to stand on'. The blackmail by this Government is underlined not only by Mr Gray but also by Mr Batt, by Mr Field, who is the forestry spokesman, and by every Liberal senator and member.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion of urgency in view of the fact that it contains a lot of nonsense about the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) overriding the memorandum of understanding. Of course, I agree with the first part of the motion about upholding the memorandum of understanding. It is a pity that Mr Gray has not done that. The State Liberal Government does not appear to be willing to uphold that MOU, and obviously neither does the Opposition here. They opposed this whole agreement in the first place. Mr Gray fought against it for months on end last year and earlier this year. Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industry, tried for months to get agreement with the State Government. Mr Gray refused time and again until he finally, reluctantly, agreed to sign. Now, of course, he is in a position of not wanting to go along with all the procedures. It is just part of Mr Gray's blatant disregard for the environment. Senators will recall that he cancelled meetings that were arranged in the hope of finalising the agreement for some specious reason-that he thought some newspaper report about his backing down had been placed by Mr Kerin. Throughout the whole negotiations leading up to the signing he just wanted to be confrontationist and capricious about the whole matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Gray-and now the Opposition in this place-has continually used the forestry issue to promote his excessively strong pro-States rights attitude. He says such things as `If the Federal authorities try to intervene in the future of Tasmania's forests they will have a fight on their hands', and other such confrontationist nonsense. Tasmanian newspapers, I know, say that the Federal Government should stay out of Tasmania's domestic affairs. But, of course, they are perfectly happy for the Federal Government to intervene when it suits them. Mr Gray does not mind the Federal Government providing money for the freight equalisation scheme, road developments and the redevelopment of the Launceston General Hospital, and for so many other projects which the Federal Government funds in the State. He does not object to that. The Commonwealth involvement cuts both ways. Mr Gray cannot accept one aspect and then jump up and down about States rights issues over logging.

Mr Gray, the Liberals in this national Parliament and the National Party of Australia in particular are just reverting to their true position of opposing any Commonwealth involvement in anything. They have a basic opposition to the Federal Government's performing its duties and responsibilities under the Constitution. They would like to deny that the Commonwealth of Australia exists. They would like to deny that there is any such Commonwealth responsibility as making decisions on export permits, which of course is how the Commonwealth must be involved in the Tasmanian forestry issue because export permits are involved. Those opposite would also like to deny that it is reasonable for the Federal Government to take environmental issues into account in making such decisions. Mr Gray and those opposite express no real concern for the environment, no feeling that they ought to care for it and no acceptance of the responsibility to take action to protect that which deserves protection. They fight against any such consideration tooth and nail. They fought against the Commonwealth's legitimate involvement in protecting the wilderness area of South West Tasmania and they went to the barricades over the proposed dam on the Franklin River-and they lost. Mr Gray, then and since, has been interested only in creating confrontation and maintaining a reactionary States rights attitude for his own narrow political purposes.

It is Mr Gray who is the political grand- stander on this matter. He is only trying to emulate Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen in his unrelenting attack on the Federal Government. He attacks the Federal Government whatever its colour, but especially a Federal Labor government. Mr Gray suggests that it is anti-Tasmanian to disagree with him, and that is just as offensive as the sort of comment which Senator Walters made to me earlier and which I asked her to withdraw, because of the extreme and absolute nature of it.

I come now to the memorandum of understanding which is the subject of this motion. The memorandum of understanding establishes a process of consultation. What happened in this area of Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff is that the Tasmanian Government authorised logging before there was full investigation and consultation. The Prime Minister called on the State Government, through a letter to Mr Gray, to stop in view of the Australian Heritage Commission's listing of the Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff area in the register of the National Estate. That triggered certain clauses of the memorandum of understanding which provide for consultation, as per clause 27, and I am pleased that Mr Kerin will raise the matter with Mr Groom, the State Minister for Forests, this week. Following that, there are dispute settling procedures provided for in clause 30 of the memorandum of understanding, which should also be allowed to take effect. Their purpose is so that National Estate values can be protected. The reason why Mr Gray and those opposite are unwilling to go along with these procedures is that they basically do not believe in upholding National Estate values.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. I found the remarks made by Senator Coates very offensive against the Premier of Tasmania. As he is not allowed to make offensive remarks about the Premier of another State, I take this point of order.
—I would like to speak on the point of order, Mr Deputy President. I did not make any unparliamentary remarks about the Premier and there is no need for me to withdraw.
—I didn't say that. I said `offensive'.
—That is right, and it was not offensive against you personally.
—If it was offensive to Senator Walters, I ask you to withdraw it.
—If that is necessary, I will withdraw, Mr acting Deputy President.
—A gracious act.

—I will get on with explaining the position to those opposite, and I appreciate the acknowledgment of my withdrawal by Senator Grimes. Senator Walters raised the question of the appendix to the memorandum of understanding which mentioned the area. But that appendix, in part 3, only sets out the conditions which will be included on the export licences for certain areas, including Jackeys Marsh. But one needs to look at clause 23 of the memorandum of understanding, which I will quote. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where any extractive timber operations (including but not limited to Forest Operations) are to the knowledge of the Forestry Commission planned for forests all or part of which are places listed on the Register of the National Estate, the Forestry Commission will advise the DPI.

The procedures go on from there. They include the responsibility of the Department of Primary Industry to get the Australian Heritage Commission's advice and so forth so that National Estate values can be taken into account. The Heritage Commission, as Senator Ryan said in her speech, is to report on those values and it expects to do so in a couple of weeks. There is also the advisory committee which is going to report in two or three weeks. The advisory committee was envisaged at the time of the signing of the memorandum of understanding and was appointed recently. Again on the details, Senator Archer raised a quibbling point about the fact that the Prime Minister had written to the Premier and not to the Minister for Forests as is specifically stated in the MOU. The Opposition, of course, would be completely upset at what it would say was the Prime Minister's lack of courtesy and non-observance of traditional procedures if he wrote to anyone other than the Premier. Of course the Prime Minister wrote to the Premier. To revert to the advisory committee, the fact that the advisory committee was to be established was announced by Mr Kerin on the day that the memorandum of understanding was signed, 12 June this year. Mr Kerin said that he believed the memorandum and the export licences:

. . . provide a means of ensuring that the issues raised by Mr Cohen in his assessment of the environmental impact statement on Tasmanian woodchip operations will be covered in a practical and effective manner.
As I said at the time of the decision, the Government's approach is to seek an appropriate balance between the interests of workers, industry and the environment.
The Memorandum enables industry and employment to be maintained, while the environment is protected and subject to continuing review.
Now the document has been settled I will be looking to quickly put in place the necessary supporting mechanisms including research arrangements and a consultative committee.

That consultative committee was announced on 15 October, and I shall remind the Senate of the members of the committee. The Chairman is Professor Henry Nix, Director of the Centre for Resource and Environmental Studies at the Australian National University, who has extensive experience in environmental and natural resource matters. Before his appointment to the Australian National University this year, he held a senior position within the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Division of Water and Land Resources. He has had a long association with the CSIRO and has been heavily involved in government research programs. The other members of the committee include representatives from the environment portfolio, the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Department of Primary Industry; an environmentalist in the person of Mr Jonathan West, who used to be on Mr Cohen's personal staff and is now associated with the Wilderness Society; Dr Murray Cunningham, who has extensive experience in Tasmanian forestry management and who used to be a commissioner of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission; and Professor Ian Ferguson, who has been appointed to advise the committee on resource economic issues, is currently with the University of Melbourne, and has a strong background in forestry and land use issues.

The State Government has said that it will have nothing to do with that committee and does not even recognise it, yet it was envisaged in the memorandum of understanding that the committee would be appointed at the time the document was signed. It is a legitimate means for the Federal Government to obtain balanced advice to help it make decisions. I remind the Senate that even the conservative Mercury in its editorial on 13 June welcomed the memorandum of understanding. That editorial referred to the memorandum in these words:
. . . the very stuff of a modern democracy. The document is a compromise. It allows no clear winners, no clear losers.
The editorial continued:

Of course, the document does infringe on States rights insofar as it does not give the Tasmanian Government unlimited control over what are Tasmanian assets. But the Premier, Mr Robin Gray, knows that the major victims in a full-scale States rights battle would have been the forestry industry, its employees, and the Tasmanian economy.
That comment indicates that Mr Gray finally gave in on this. As a matter of interest, the editorial also pointed out:
If breaches of the memorandum of understanding are detected, they should be reported to Canberra for Federal Government action.

That is what is happening in this case. Mr Gray on this whole issue has no credibility. His position is one of wanting to develop at all costs and he does not want to take a balanced approach to employment. He and his Ministers continually object to the whole issue of National Estate listing. Mr Groom was quoted in one of today's newspapers as again attacking National Estate listing procedures where decisions could be made at the whim of a few members of the Heritage Commission in Canberra. The procedures under the Heritage Commission listing involve the State and local governments being aware and advised of what is proposed. The nomination of this area was made months ago. They have an opportunity to put their opinions to the Heritage Commission, to object and to make sure that their view is heard. It is not a question of this being at the whim of a few members of the Heritage Commission. I defend that Commission in that it is a body of experts independently advising on what should be listed in the National Estate. It gives advice for Federal Ministers to take into account when making decisions, as they are obliged to do under Federal legislation, such as in approving export permits. The Jackeys Marsh-Quamby Bluff area, a beautiful area of our State, was nominated months ago and listed by the Heritage Commission, which triggered the application of clause 23. The State and anybody else can object to that listing if they wish.

The timber industry is important to Tasmania, and will continue to be. I am always offended by the suggestion that if one takes a position against, for instance, logging a particular area one is somehow or other against all forestry operations in the State and is being disloyal, anti-employment and so on. Of course that does not follow. One has to take a balanced view. Of course one must support the industry, but one must seek to ensure that the National Estate values are taken into account. So I reject that sort of notion. I return to the point that the memorandum of understanding provides a process of consultation which the Federal Government is willing to undertake but which Mr Gray apparently has ignored. Even if the State thought that it was within its rights to go ahead with logging at Jackeys Marsh in the first place, it should have responded to the Prime Minister's request by stopping logging pending consultation and the dispute settling procedures under the memorandum of understanding. Those procedures should be allowed to take their course before further logging of this area. I oppose the motion.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Archer's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Paper and Text of Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

The tax expenditures statement argues that revenues forgone through tax expenditures-that is, the current system of exemptions, deductions and rebates within the confines of the Income Tax Assessment Act, et cetera-are significantly less than the cost of direct outlays. I think that this is quite an interesting observation. While acknowledging that it is so, I must point out that it creates tax shelters. I find it strange that the Government supports such a statement in view of what is happening in the United States of America, which is trying to remove tax shelters. Whenever one provides a special exemption or deduction under income tax legislation to a special class of taxpayers, other people can take advantage of that and a tax shelter is created. In view of the recent emphasis on the need to eliminate tax rorts, it is rather surprising to see a Treasury statement taking this form.

The fact remains that expenditures by this Government are very high. This presupposes that there must be very high revenue to support those expenditures. Nevertheless, the fact remains that the Government's current taxation regime is the most punitive in Australia's history. In fact, I believe that 25.5 per cent of our gross domestic product is raised by taxation. We all know that since the Hawke Labor Government came to power the tax burden has increased quite dramatically-in fact, by 61 per cent over four years. On pages 15 and 16 of this statement, paragraphs 60, 64 and 65 highlight the fact that social security and welfare in particular, and superannuation and retirement benefits, make the large contribution to revenue forgone. I remind the Senate that when the Hawke Government first came to power its first attack was on superannuation lump sum benefits paid on retirement. This Government attacks any wealth creating scheme. While other countries in the Pacific region are trying to create wealth, this Government is interested in wealth redistribution to the detriment of any creative activity within the Government. This document is really an apology of a document. I quote from page 1, where it says:
While tax expenditures can be identified, their costing is either not feasible or not currently available.

So what is the purpose of producing a document when it cannot be substantiated in those terms? What is the worth of this statement when it is based on such uncertain figures and such constraints that operate within this domain? I think that the document has limited appeal and limited worth and I find very little to commend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

I wish to draw attention in particular to one or two sections of this paper, the 1985-86 annual report of the Policy Co-ordination Unit. It is interesting that almost halfway through its report the Unit makes a reference to the social security system and expresses the view that its initial concern is poverty alleviation and the reduction of income inequalities. While one cannot disagree with that objective-it has been the basis of the system in this nation-it is quite clear that that goal is really not being met in current circumstances. Perhaps one could say that it has never really been met. It is also evident from this report that some specific areas need particular attention. To back up those remarks, I point out that poverty alleviation has not occurred and in particular in recent years the position and numbers of people in poverty have worsened. For example, since March 1983 unemployed young people under 18 have dropped to a level of 60 per cent plus below the poverty line. These people are 6 per cent worse off than they were when this Government came to office. A married couple with four children who were below the poverty line have fallen 3 per cent further and perhaps, most significantly, single parent families are falling further and further below the poverty line. Their position has worsened by 2 to 3 per cent in the past three or four years. So it can be readily seen that, while the goal of the social security system might be the alleviation of poverty, the goal is certainly not being achieved. One of the major factors there has been the increase in unemployment.

The report goes on to a section which is headed `Rationalising tax and social security'. That section pays a great deal of attention to some of the inequities and makes some suggestions about potential rationalisation. On the issue of inequities, we have seen recently in the Senate actions which have served to increase those inequities. Those actions do no credit to the Parliament, in particular the Senate. They have reduced the marginal tax rates for those people in employment, in comfortable circumstances, and in particular those at the highest level of income in our society. At the same time they have ignored the position of people who, as is clearly outlined in this paper, have fallen further and further below the poverty line to the point where, as a chart in the report shows, some people on pensions are now paying an effective marginal tax rate of up to 75 per cent. These are all issues that need to be addressed.

When the Australian Democrats address these issues, which we so often do, it is often suggested that we are being irresponsible. That is not a worthwhile response when we are talking about people on very small incomes or with no income. It is not that the Australian Democrats do not have an approach to taxation which would cover some of the proposals that we have made. As I have said, taxation levels for people on high incomes have been reduced. In the recent Budget the Government could have done something to allow people to get out of poverty and to allow more to be done for the people mentioned in this report but it did not do so. We have estimated that the abolition of negative gearing for company takeovers could have brought in well over $1 billion, for instance. We have suggested that the Government could impose a duty on luxury imports for those people who can afford them. That would bring in roughly half a billion dollars. The elimination of transfer pricing is another of our suggestions.

I do not wish to debate this report for even the five minutes permitted to me. The Industries Assistance Commission report on reconditioned automotive engines recommends that imports of used and reconditioned engines be dutiable at a general rate of 15 per cent. My reason for speaking on the report at this stage is that I have had the unusual experience of having received a number of representations on this report hot on the heels of its having been brought down. What is unusual is not that I received representations but that those representations were in support of the IAC position. The representations came from people engaged in both the importation and the reconditioning of engines. In each case the people making representations were concerned that the Government would be put under pressure to ignore the Industries Assistance Commission's report and to grant a greater level of tariff protection than that recommended.

I thought it was worth putting on record the fact that there are those concerns about and the belief that some of the major companies which are concerned with the reconditioning of engines might seek to follow that approach, and perhaps to put those people on notice that there is an active concern in that regard. Certainly on the basis of the facts as set out in the IAC report and the facts which have been put before me by those who have chosen to come to me and who are making representations also to the Government, it appears that there is a reasonable situation with respect to the importation of engines and that the measured decline in the domestic reconditioned engine market is in part accounted for by factors beyond the importation of engines from Japan.

As I have said, I do not wish to debate the report now. I simply put on record the fact that there is some industry concern that the Government will not follow the IAC recommendations. I look forward to seeing whether the views which have been predicted, asking for much higher tariff protection, eventuate. I mention it because there is a general view in the community that we should avoid any level of tariff protection which is unnecessary, because any section of industry that is protected tends to raise the costs of other sectors of industry that use what is being imported as an input. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report underlines in poignant terms the crisis which is facing many of our rural industries. World-wide, there is an economic crisis which is affecting developing countries, and the people of those countries are suffering poverty and unemployment. The development programs which are being offered are suffering enormous setbacks, and commodity prices are plummeting under this regime. Australia is suffering like the rest of the world, but here the cities seem to be somewhat insulated from the worst effects of this type of depression. Just imagine the mutiny from unions if wages were cut by 50 per cent or by 75 per cent! That is exactly the type of thing that is happening to our rural producers. That is the sort of drop in income which is now being suffered by citrus growers, after deduction of the costs of picking and various other costs which arise in connection with fuel and marketing. Many of our country people-citrus growers, cotton growers, sugar growers, and wheat farmers, particularly in Western Australia-are facing desperation as they struggle to keep their land and their hope while their families undergo humiliating poverty in an attempt to meet rising costs with an income a fraction of what is needed to cover those costs.

It is a disgrace. The Government's policies are in large part the cause of this great rural depression. The costs of the world trade wars are being carried unfairly on the shoulders of a minority of Australians-namely, those in the export industries. Tariff protection of our import-replacing manufacturing industries becomes a cost on the whole of the community, but more than half of this cost ends up directly on the backs of exporters. Tariffs on imports are equivalent to taxes on exports. For this reason, I support the Government's efforts to cut tariffs, replacing tariffs with bounties on domestic production wherever there is a necessity for such help to the industry. However, the Government appears to be reluctant to pay bounties because bounties are a direct cost to the exchequer, whereas tariffs come directly into the Government's coffers.

The other great impost on our exporters is the Government's encouragement of foreign investment. This brings `money'-or paper money, capital, in the form of loans and guarantees-into Australia, and it forces up our exchange rate above the level at which our exports can compete on world markets. It seems to me reasonable and fair that importers and foreign investors should pay the costs of bounties to compensate exporters and domestic manufacturers for the damage that they cause to our export economy. A tax on moneys leaving the country could actually handle this problem and could be converted into bounties in relation to industries which are providing our local market and which could then develop into export industries. The IAC has proposed that tariff protection of the citrus industry should be progressively reduced according to the 1982 plan, but it has failed to produce any realistic alternative solution.

Australia is wide open to large scale currency manipulation and to foreign takeovers. The people who are paying the price are the exporters. The burden falls most heavily on our rural exporters, who are, for the most part, individual operators without any large financial reserves. In this report the IAC coldly recommends that they be `adjusted' out of business rather than receive the support they deserve, the support owed to them by those who prosper from tariff protection and by those who speculate in Australian dollars and make it impossible for them to compete on world markets.

It is important that we should consider our farmers. It is important that the Government should act to develop a new world economic order and to put pressure on other countries to support that economic order. In the meantime, the Government needs to give realistic support to our citrus industry, and that is what I urge it to do, rather than follow the wishy-washy type of proposals set out in this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

I wish to speak briefly on the September outlook paper for the aviation industry. These papers, which are very useful, have been produced on a regular basis since 1982. I see from the foreword that this is the sixth to be published. When one looks at all of the facts and figures, graphs and tables, the picture that emerges of the aviation industry is a complex one which has become even more complex in recent times due to alterations to aviation administration and charges and to Australia's economic problems. At the end of the paper on page 37 there is a summary of the outlook for the industry. I will focus on the conclusions reached regarding the domestic aviation industry, and in particular the future for the commuter segment of the industry.

The paper notes that, in spite of provisional data indicating an increase of 7.8 per cent in passenger uplift in 1985, performance in this sector is very uneven, with most east coast operators recording small declines or, in some cases, only modest growth. The paper states:

With current cost pressures (including recent large increases in air navigation charges) facing the commuter segment and the short term outlook for the rural sector, at best, only modest aggregate growth is likely to be achieved in 1986 . . .
The paper concludes:
With the slowing down of the Australian economy and the continued depressed conditions prevailing in the rural economy, the prospects for growth in general aviation activity are not encouraging.

While this does not augur well for commuter aviation services across the board, it will have a particularly detrimental effect upon the industry in the outback, where light aircraft and commuter services are heavily relied upon by many remote communities. The additional impost of the increased aviation charge, the cost recovery scheme, may be too much for the small commuter services to bear or they may be forced to pass on the increase in costs to consumers, which in turn brings about resistance from their clients and so a dwindling turnover. Financial viability then comes into question. This would not be such a bitter pill to swallow if it were not for the fact that in the Northern Territory, for example, the airport facilities for which the charge is supposed to pay do not exist, or exist in a very minor way.

The poor state of the two major airports at Darwin and Alice Springs is well documented. But they are not the only ones that are in bad shape. The Fokker Friendship service to Tennant Creek has been threatened-in fact it has gone now-by the fact that the main runway is in such a state of disrepair as to be unable to support the landing or taking off of aircraft. That airstrip was also unusable by all aircraft earlier this year when heavy rains produced extensive damage. This damage was eventually patched up, only to recur with the next tropical downpour. So the facilities that this levy is supposed to pay for are difficult to identify at a number of Territory airports and airstrips.

The burden that the increased levy imposes on private aircraft operators is even more onerous than that on commercial operators who at least have the option of passing on the increased costs to passengers and other customers, if those passengers and customers can afford it. A private pilot who flies for a hobby or who relies on his or her aircraft as a means of transportation from a remote station to the larger urban centres is hit very hard by this impost. Aircraft are used to fly to remote settlements and homesteads and are used for mustering, in mining fields, on Aboriginal settlements and for tourist air charter operations.

Recently I received a letter from a private pilot in Darwin who has a Victa Air Tourer; he has had it for some 12 years. His aircraft is based at Darwin Airport. He flies a maximum of 40 to 50 hours per year on average. In the past 12 months he flew for only 20 hours. His account for air navigation charges for the next 12 months is over $600, which represents an increase of 17 per cent on the previous year's account. His cost per flying hour in air navigation charges is $30, which is more than its costs to buy enough fuel to fly the plane for one hour. This pilot has pointed out, quite reasonably, that in return for that charge he receives very little. At Darwin Airport there are no special facilities available for private aircraft other than a parking spot and some degree of security. This applies also to Alice Springs where aircraft have to park on a gravelled area, causing damage to spinning propellors and to the skin of the aircraft. As with most other government airports the facilities, such as they are, are provided for commercial aviation.

The downturn is also likely to be reflected strongly in the Finance and Investment Services, including Banking, sectors.

The report refers to the impact of falling world commodity prices on profits and to the depreciation of the Australian dollar, which has had an adverse effect on profits in those industries heavily dependent on imports, including merchants and agents, the media-particularly television series costs-transport, automotive and high technology sectors, and some companies in the electrical and durables and light engineering sectors. It talks about the impact of record interest rates on costs and therefore on profits, and it also mentions that the announcement of the fringe benefits tax appears to have affected sales in the automotive section in the latter half of 1985-86. Of course that impact has continued. It is striking, in an environment of falling profits, that we find this statement:
The second full year of the Authority's operations was marked by a very substantial expansion of its activities. By year's end, the scope of surveillance had effectively doubled. . .

We have falling profitability and economic difficulty, and yet the activities of this organisation are doubling, while instruction from the Treasurer is that his direction to the Authority is intended as a general guideline and `is not intended to inhibit price adjustments in individual cases where profit margins are inadequate or where increases in profits will serve to attract additional resources into investment and employment'. The Treasurer himself is conceding there that profit is not a dirty word, that profit brings employment and investment, and that, partly as a result of the doubling of the activities of this organisation and its campaign against profitability, profits have been reduced. As a result we are facing the reduced levels of investment and employment, with rising unemployment, which are marring our economy at this stage. This is one of the reasons why this Authority will be disbanded by a Liberal government.

STATES GRANT (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986

In the Budget Speech and in a statement issued by me on 19 August 1986 details of the Government's tertiary education policies for 1987 were announced. The Government will maintain the momentum of its policies including the maintenance of growth, provision for disadvantaged groups, the development of stronger links with industry and the maintenance of rational steady planning as the basis for decision making.

To support continued growth in the system increased resources are required and as a result of budget decisions funds available to tertiary education institutions will increase by 2.6% in real terms in 1987.

In the budgetary circumstances outlined by the Treasurer, however, the Government has decided to introduce an administration charge of $250 per higher education student per annum from 1987 as a contribution towards the administrative costs of institutional budgets. This Bill gives effect to the Government's decision in respect of higher education students in institutions in the States and Northern Territory funded by the Commonwealth.

The charge will apply equally to all full-time, part-time and external students undertaking award courses or courses which could form part of an award at a university, college of advanced education or other institutions where the Commonwealth funds higher education places.

Institutions will be required to collect the administration charge at the time of each enrolment or annually where students formally enrol only once in a course that may extend over more than one calendar year. For each institution the Commonwealth general recurrent grant payable for a given year will be reduced by an amount equivalent to 90 per cent of the revenue estimated to be derived from the charge. The remaining 10 per cent of revenue (estimated at $9.306 million for the States and the Northern Territory in 1987) will be retained by the institutions for expenditure within the institutions for their own purposes. The Bill provides for an appropriate adjustment to be made to payments in the following year where the reduction in grant does not match 90 per cent of the actual administration charge revenue.
The charge will be indexed on an annual basis according to CTEC processes for adjusting administrative (non-academic) salary costs.

The Bill provides for exemption from the charge for institutions' own award holders, full fee paying overseas students and both full-time and part-time students who are pensioners and beneficiaries in the categories eligible for an education allowance for full-time studies.

Beneficiaries under the age related education allowance scheme (incorporating TEAS), Post Graduate Awards Scheme (PGA) and ABSTUDY grants, who are liable for the charge, will have their benefit increased by the value of the charge. Similarly the Overseas Student Charge applying to subsidised overseas students will be reduced by the amount of the administration charge.

Under these arrangements the Government estimates gross revenue collections by institutions in the States and Northern Territory at $93.064 million in 1986-87 of which the institutions will retain $9.306 million for their purposes. Adjustments to student assistance benefits and the Overseas Students Charge will cost $27.700 million. Revenue from the charge is therefore estimated at $56.057 million in 1986-87.
Consequential changes in respect of Commonwealth institutions are being made in other Bills being introduced today.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY AMENDMENT BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian National University Act 1946 to provide for the imposition of the higher education administration charge by the University as announced in the 1986-87 Budget. The charge is to apply to Commonwealth institutions from 1987 on the same basis as will apply in the States, with the payment of the charge as a condition of enrolment.
The Bill also provides for the exemption of certain categories of student from the charge as outlined in my statement of 19 August 1986 on Tertiary Education and the 1986-87 Budget.
Under these arrangements the Government estimates the gross revenue collection by the University in 1987 at $1,579,000 which will result in the recurrent grant for 1987 being reduced by $1,421,000.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Canberra College of Advanced Education Act 1967 to provide for the imposition of the higher education administration charge by the College as announced in the 1986-87 Budget. The charge is to apply to Commonwealth institutions from 1987 on the same basis as will apply in the States, with the payment of the charge as a condition of enrolment.
The Bill also provides for the exemption of certain categories of student from the charge as outlined in my statement of 19 August 1986 on Tertiary Education and the 1986-87 Budget.
Under these arrangements the Government estimates the gross revenue collection by the College in 1987 at $1,540,000 which will result in the recurrent grant for 1987 being reduced by $1,386,000.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MARITIME COLLEGE AMENDMENT BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Maritime College Act 1978 to provide for the imposition of the higher education administration charge by the College as announced in the 1986-87 Budget. The charge is to apply to Commonwealth institutions from 1987 on the same basis as will apply in the States, with the payment of the charge as a condition of enrolment.
The Bill also provides for the exemption of certain categories of student from the charge as outlined in my statement of 19 August 1986 on Tertiary Education and the 1986-87 Budget.
Under these arrangements the Government estimates the gross revenue collection by the College in 1987 at $69,000 which will result in the recurrent grant for 1987 being reduced by $62,000.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

On 6 June this year the Minister for Housing and Construction announced that the Government would introduce legislation to terminate the receipt of applications under the Fraser Government's Home Deposit Assistance Scheme.
That scheme only applied to homes purchased between 18 March 1982 and 30 September 1983 and is now effectively obsolete.
Only a small number of late applications have been received over the past 12 months.

Honourable members will recall that the previous government abruptly terminated The Home Savings Grant Scheme in a harsh and draconian manner which left hundreds, perhaps thousands, of people disadvantaged by its insensitivity.
This Government has taken a more enlightened approach in terminating the outgoing Home Deposit Assistance Scheme.
When we introduced the First Home Owners Scheme in 1983, we undertook not to wind up the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme immediately.

This was in order to allow sufficient time for people purchasing in the relevant period to lodge their applications. More than three years have passed since the scheme was superseded by the First Home Owners Scheme.
The Bill now before the Senate provides that 31 December, 1986, will be the last day on which an applicant can deliver a valid application under the old scheme.
Very few applicants, if any, will miss out on assistance because of the length of time we have allowed for lodgment of their applications.
Applications are now being received at the rate of only four or less each week.
In the interests of administrative efficiency, governments must set end dates for lodgment of applications under superseded schemes such as this.

Savings in terminating the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme, which are largely administrative, will amount about $150,000 in the first full year. The Bill also provides that 1986-87 will be the last financial year requiring an Annual Report to Parliament on the operation of the Act.
As the Act currently stands, the 1985-86 Annual Report was the last required. However, for the sake of completeness we propose an additional report for 1986-87.
The sensible way this Government has handled the termination of this scheme is one more indication of the priority we give to housing generally.
That priority is exemplified in our First Home Owners Scheme.
Almost $1 billion has been approved by the Labor Government under the scheme since its inception in October 1983.
$210 million has been allocated under the scheme this financial year which will assist more than 41,500 low and middle income earners in buying or building their first home.
This will bring to 245,000 by the end of 1986-87 the number of First Home Buyers helped under the scheme since it was introduced.
Unlike the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme, the First Home Owners Scheme realistically meets the financial needs of applicants through the choice of payment.
Recipients have three choices about the way they receive assistance under the first home owners scheme.
Over a five year period, recipients can choose to receive a monthly interest subsidy, a lump sum plus a monthly subsidy, or a larger lump sum with a smaller monthly subsidy.
The total benefit under the scheme is up to $6,000 depending on income and the number of dependent children.
The first home owners scheme is only one example of the high priority this government gives to housing.
We are committed to providing affordable and adequate housing for all Australian households.
Almost 500,000 Australians are employed in the housing and construction industry and the government's policies in this area make a major contribution to the nation's wealth.
Since this government came to office in 1983, federal funding for public housing has been increased by almost 130 per cent.
This indicates the priority we place on alleviating housing related poverty.
In 1986-87, a record $1275.9 million will be provided from this government to the states for public housing.
This is being provided under the Commonwealth-state housing agreement and as low interest loans under loan council nomination arrangements.
The Bill now before the Senate continues this government's real efforts in helping many thousands of Australians realise their home ownership aspirations.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
