DEBATE.TITLE: NURSING HOMES AND HOSTELS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill contains Budget measures that will amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974.

These measures will begin the process of redistributing resources for care of aged people away from nursing homes to alternative forms of residential care as part of the Government's objective to increase the range of both residential and community care services.

In recent years there have been a number of Reports, in particular, from the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes (the Giles Report), the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee (the McLeay Report) and the Auditor General, which have identified significant problems associated with the provision by the Commonwealth of aged care services. Prominent among the criticisms was that Government intervention in residential care programs for the aged had been largely unseen, unplanned and unco-ordinated and that there was an inappropriate mix of services between and within institutional accommodation and home and community care programs. In addition, there has been an inordinate increase in the cost of nursing home accommodation in the past 13 years compared to increases in the consumer price index and average weekly earnings.

Against this background, I commissioned a Review by my Department with the objective of developing a strategy for change. The Report of the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review, which I tabled in the Senate on 14 April 1986, made recommendations for the development of a restructured residential care program within the framework of four basic philosophical goals:
Aged and disabled people should as far as possible be supported in their own homes, in their own communities.
Aged and disabled people should be supported by residential services only where other support systems are not appropriate to meet their needs.

Services should be provided in an atmosphere and using processes which promote as far as possible rehabilitation and restoration of function. The manner in which services are provided should develop and enhance personal freedom and independent functioning of all residents.

Services should be based on a recognition that for many people, discharge to a residential service providing a less intensive form of care or to a community-based support service will be a possible and desirable outcome.

The Review made recommendations over the whole range of issues relating to the Government's programs for the provision of residential care for the aged, including assessment and rehabilitation, program structure, growth control, standards, funding issues and the need to promote innovation and flexibility.

When tabling the Review, I stated that the Government endorsed its broad philosophy, directions and strategy for change. Since April, the Commonwealth has undertaken extensive consultations on the strategy for change with State Governments, the nursing homes and hostels industry, consumer and other welfare groups and professional and staff organisations. A number of important matters were raised in the consultations which have influenced the overall strategy of changing the emphasis of the program from nursing homes to hostels, and indeed now form part of the basis of the decisions taken by the Government in the recent Budget process. These matters include:
ii(i) the requirement for flexible planning, which provides for monitoring, evaluation and changes where necessary, including more integration with community services;
i(ii) a publicised and better resourced hostel sector so that hostels can care for increasingly dependent aged people;
(iii) the extension of residential care services beyond hostels to other forms of accommodation such as group housing arrangements;
(iv) the expansion of community services to assist those elderly people most at risk of premature and inappropriate institutionalisation; and
(v) the importance of carefully developing the process of assessment so that it will gain support from consumers, professionals and service providers.

This Bill will implement decisions concerning two of these matters, namely, the need for a more flexible and integrated planning approach to the provision of residential services and a better resourced hostel sector. The other three matters are being addressed outside the context of this Bill.

While Australia overall has a very adequate provision of nursing home accommodation, its community care and domiciliary services have been traditionally underdeveloped, as have its facilities for hostel care.

In order to redress this imbalance, there is a need to moderate the historical largely uncontrolled growth in the nursing home sector and encourage further development of hostel accommodation for the aged. This change in emphasis must be implemented now because the current system, which emphasises the provision of the more intensive institutionalised care services provided by nursing homes, is not producing the range of care options which elderly people want and does not respect their drive for independence. It is also encouraging a significant level of inappropriate admissions of up to 25% of current nursing care residents.

Furthermore, it will be difficult to sustain rapid growth in expensive nursing home beds in a climate where there is a rapidly ageing population, both in terms of numbers and as a proportion of the total population.

In seeking to change the system there is a need to develop a total aged care policy with an expanded range of options that will achieve improved quality of care within residential institutions and will better match individuals' needs and the care provided.

On 17 September 1986, I tabled in the Senate a Statement on the Care of Aged People announcing the Government's planning strategy for the provision of residential care services over the next three year period. The strategy is to maintain growth in new services on the basis of the current national ratio of 100 residential care places per 1000 people aged 70 or over, and within this national ratio to limit the rate of growth of numbers of new nursing home beds to a maximum of 10 per cent of new approvals.

This Bill amends the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 to implement this strategy by introducing new growth control arrangements over the approval-in-principle and approval mechanisms for nursing homes. The new provisions will enable the maximum number of nursing home beds which can exist at any time during a financial year in each State and Territory to be specified. The maximum number of ordinary beds which may exist in a region in a State or Territory and the maximum number of special needs beds which may exist in a State or Territory will also be specified. The Bill also provides that the sum of the regional maxima in a State or Territory and the special bed maximum for that State or Territory will not exceed the relevant State or Territory maximum.

The State, regional and special needs maxima will each comprise the number of existing approvals-in-principle and approvals, plus the number of new beds to be approved during the financial year in each category. These maxima will be determined by a Gazette notice, and may be revoked or varied by later notices published in the Gazette. This gives the flexibility to vary the allocations between States, regions and special needs groups, whilst remaining within the national ceiling determined by Government. Approvals-in-principle, however, will only be granted if they are consistent with the State, regional or special needs maxima in force under a current Gazette notice.

In my Statement on Care of Aged People, I announced that the Government plans to approve 2750 new places in 1986-87, 4730 in 1987-88 and 5400 in 1988-89-12,880 additional places overall, of which up to 1295 places over the three year period will be for nursing homes and the balance for hostels.

In line with needs based planning principles, the allocation of resources within the State and Territory maxima to both regions and special needs groups will be determined on the basis of supply and demand data, and appropriate consultative processes. I am currently seeking the advice of relevant bodies in each State and Territory, and will both announce and gazette the regional and special allocations of beds later in 1986-87. In future years, new Aged Care Advisory Committees in each State and Territory will be providing me with planning advice so that State, regional and special needs allocations can be announced at the start of each financial year.

The Bill will introduce a mechanism to enable the approval of beds in relation to special needs groups. At this stage it is envisaged that special needs groups could include Aboriginals, ethnic communities and the aged disabled, including the deaf and blind aged. This is consistent with other Government initiatives in the Budget context, such as the introduction of funding of up to 100 per cent of the capital costs of projects for financially disadvantaged groups.

This Bill will also apply uniform conditions of approval to both government and non-government nursing homes. The existing provisions of the National Health Act 1953 exempt government nursing homes from statutory conditions which relate to the number of beds in an approved nursing home and the approval of patients for admission to a nursing home. However, government nursing homes have in practice been subjected to restrictions on the approved number of beds since 1981. The practice is formalised in this legislation, for both new government nursing homes and additional beds in existing government nursing homes. It is intended that assessment procedures will also apply in government nursing homes.

The new planning arrangements will mean that from now on there will be a limited number of nursing home beds available and the administration of the program will move from a submission-based unplanned approach with discretionary decision making on the selection of service providers, to a more needs based planning approach supported by a tendering process for the selection of service providers. Under existing provisions of the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974, we have the ridiculous situation whereby interested persons may be invited to apply for a certificate of approval-in-principle only where a person applies to have persons invited to so apply. This approach effectively prevents the needs based allocation of resources. This Bill accordingly omits these provisions. In future, advertisements would be placed inviting tenders for a certificate or certificates of approval-in-principle in a region, where the regional maximum allows, or for special needs beds, where the special bed maximum allows.

The change in the existing balance between providing intensive care through nursing homes and providing appropriate community services and hostel options will be gradual. It is essential that implementation does not affect residents who are already in nursing homes and that it is carefully monitored, evaluated and where necessary, adjusted.
The introduction of the new growth control arrangements is estimated to result in savings of $4 million in 1986-87 and $27.7 million in 1987-88.

The Bill will also make a number of minor amendments to the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974. These amendments will correct some minor drafting defects, up-date provisions and substitute a notice mechanism in the Acts for some of the regulations under the Acts.
None of these measures have expenditure implications, although some will result in small administrative savings.

Key elements of the Government's revised residential care program for the aged are to provide alternative residential care services to nursing homes in the form of hostels and to strengthen the role of hostels in the care of the more frail aged. The consultation process has confirmed the problem of hostels being under-resourced.

In the recent Budget and in response to concerns expressed by the hostel industry and consumer groups, the Government decided that steps should be taken now to provide a firm commitment to maintain the real level of hostel subsidies over time and to increase assistance for the care of more frail aged people. The Bill therefore will amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 to provide for:

an increase to the hostel care subsidy, respite care subsidy and personal care subsidy beginning 22 October this year-the hostel care subsidy will increase from $1.80 per day to $1.95 per day, the respite care subsidy will increase from $7.00 per day to $7.50 per day and the personal care subsidy will increase from $7.80 per day to $8.40 per day; and

an additional increase of $2.60 a day in the value of the personal care subsidy, to $11 a day from May next year to assist the hostel industry provide more adequate levels of personal care for dependent elderly people.
The Bill will also provide a mechanism for annual automatic increases in the subsidy rates for hostel care, personal care and respite care.
These measures will cost $5.6m in 1986-87 and $24.7m in 1987-88.

In addition the Government recognises that increased numbers of hostel beds will necessitate a significant strengthening of the resources available for capital funding. In particular, it has sought to address problems being faced under the current legislation by some financially disadvantaged groups.

Under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, the Commonwealth makes grants to eligible organisations towards meeting the capital cost of homes for aged or disabled people. The amount of a grant may not exceed 80 per cent of the capital cost of the home under the Act.

Some eligible organisations which represent financially disadvantaged groups in the community experience difficulty in raising matching funds. The Government, in this Bill, is introducing flexibility in matching arrangements to allow for up to 100 per cent of Commonwealth funds for special groups, including ethnic communities, Aboriginals and other disadvantaged groups.
This measure is estimated to cost $500,000 in 1986-87 and $2.8m in 1987-88.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: KAKADU NATIONAL PARK PLAN OF MANAGEMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 October, on motion by Senator Collard:
That the Kakadu National Park Plan of Management, prepared under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, and laid before the Senate on 18 September 1986, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is it that 150,000 tourists go to the Kakadu National Park each year? The answer clearly lies in its breathtaking sandstone escarpments, its majestic falls, its spectacular Aboriginal rock galleries, its wonderful wetlands, the breeding grounds for all manner of native fauna and its exquisite ecosystems. The unique beauty of stage 1 is well known; it was established by the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. The first plan of management quite properly proposed that it be placed on the World Heritage List and indeed it falls squarely within the requirements of Article 2 of the World Heritage Convention. Accordingly, stage 1 was declared a national park by the previous Government in 1979 and it was listed as a World Heritage site in 1981. Stage 1 must remain inviolate. To date, Australia has had an honourable history in this area. Stage 1 covers some 6,144 square kilometres. It is an area of priceless significance.

SPEECH.PARA: In August 1974 Australia became one of the first countries to ratify the International Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage, known as the World Heritage Convention, it having been adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation in 1972 and having entered into force in 1975. It has now been signed by some 85 countries. The Convention aims to ensure international co-operation for the safeguarding of the globe's irreplaceable heritage against the pressures of population explosion, resource scarcity, technological change, industrialisation and the changing of national boundaries.

To date the World Heritage List includes some 216 places-such world famous tourist resorts as the Grand Canyon, with its fossil evidence of the beginnings of life on earth, and great national parks such as Yellowstone in the United States of America, Serengeti in Tanzania and Sagarmatha in Nepal, which includes Mount Everest. Kakadu National Park takes its place as a worthy member of this exclusive club. Entry to the club has hitherto not been easy. Professional and respected non-governmental organisations are commissioned to assess each place and to make recommendations to the World Heritage Committee. The criterion of outstanding universal value is very stringent. Currently in Australia five World Heritage properties are listed on the register of the National Estate and, therefore, are protected under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. These are: The Great Barrier Reef, the Lord Howe Island group, the Willandra Lakes region, the western Tasmanian wilderness national park and Kakadu National Park. They have been declared by regulation to form part of the World Heritage pursuant to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983. Proposals are forwarded to the Secretariat of the World Heritage Committee and the 21 members of the Committee of experts assess each application. Currently, Australia is represented on that Committee. When a state becomes a party to the Convention it recognises an obligation to ensure:
. . . the identification, protection, conservation, preservation and transmission to future generations of the cultural and natural heritage situated on its Territory.

The Convention provides for buffer zones which should be determined through technical studies. A protracted procedure is specified. It is not to be undertaken lightly or quickly. Indeed, Annex 1 to the Convention sets out the operational guidelines, which require each party to submit tentative inventories of properties which it intends to nominate during the following five to 10 years. It is, therefore, a slow process. Paragraph 21 of the Convention makes it clear that a site must be wholly exceptional, that it must be `an outstanding example'; that it must contain `superlative natural phenomena', or areas of `exceptional national beauty' or `outstanding universal value'. As I have said before, hitherto it has been a leisurely process, somewhat akin, perhaps, to the path to beatification and sainthood in another arena. The five Australian sites were nominated in 1980 and 1981 and, in each instance, at the request of the State government concerned. It needs to be a very selective pro- cess. Otherwise these places of outstanding significance can very quickly become tourist meccas and the currency can be very quickly debased.

The first management plan expired in December 1985 and there was no great urgency to replace it with a second management plan. All was going along at a leisurely pace, with the preparation of a further draft management plan well in prospect, until 14 September last. That was a date of some significance. It was shortly after the decision to sell uranium to France had hit the fan. The Government was very much under pressure. The National Times on that date reported that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had written to Mr Cohen, the responsible Minister, or, as I will suggest later, the irresponsible Minister. The Prime Minister expressed concern about the absence in the draft management plan of `any provision for the possible future recovery of minerals within the park'. Of course, that was in defiance of the Australian Labor Party National Conference decision in Hobart in July 1986. But the Prime Minister nonetheless went on:

Given Australia's present current account deficit I would have serious reservations with any proposal that would result in the imposition of a more restrictive framework on potential exploration or development within Kakadu.

One might have thought that that was a perfectly proper and reasonable allocation of priorities. But, of course, the letter was leaked, not by hapless Hawke. Perhaps it is pretty obvious who was responsible. The Cohen plan was dramatically tougher than the Fraser plan had ever been. As I have said, that expired in December 1985 and it would have allowed general mining in the park. The new plan that we are currently considering restricts mineral activity to `pre- existing interests'. These were interests that were granted by way of leases before 1975, when the national park was first announced, and there are only 14 granted leases that fall within that category. Understandably and responsibly, not only the Prime Minister but also Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Walsh, Mr Keating and Mr Dawkins all opposed that position of Mr Cohen. Nonetheless, in the atmosphere of panic that prevailed on that day, Senator Evans's proposals simply went out the window. Mr Cohen wanted to declare all of stages 1, 2 and 3; Senator Evans wanted to have an assessment of the resources of the existing national park and he was certainly quite relaxed about mining in stage 3. But on 16 September the Prime Minister caved in.

The Caucus compromise resulted in a ban on all new mining and exploration in stage 1 and stage 2 but left open the way for mining in stage 3. It was agreed that immediate steps would be taken to nominate stage 2 of the park, to enlarge the boundaries, including the Gimbat and Goodparla pastoral leases, and perhaps to allow mining at a later time, with the minimal concession that Coronation Hill, with its extensive gold and platinum reserves, the mining of which was already under way, should be excised. Otherwise the three-mine policy of the Labor Government was to be retained, with only Peko's Ranger mine, the Queensland Mines Ltd mine at Nabarlek and the Roxby Downs mine in South Australia being allowed to continue with uranium mining. The rationale was incomprehensible. It was clearly a classic, shabby, political compromise.

Of course, there is now very widespread dissatisfaction, and I will deal later with the respectability of that dissatisfaction. Suffice it to say that, until 16 September this year, the Government was prepared to acknowledge the validity of the findings of the Department of Resources and Energy which had assessed that at least one-third of stage 3 was highly prospective for minerals, especially for gold and platinum. By contrast, it has not assessed stage 2 other than to say that it was highly prospective for uranium but it was probably only moderate for gold, platinum and base metals. Of course, in the ideological fervour that recurrently grips the Australian Labor Party, that was sufficient for it to ban all forms of mining in stage 2, irrespective of the merits. Senator Evans's position is on the record. We know that he wrote to Mr Copeman, a key figure of the demonology of the Labor Party in this area, in these terms:

It is my view . . . that it would be premature to pursue the World Heritage listing of Kakadu Stage Two until related questions about mineral activity in the Kakadu region have been addressed by the Commonwealth. You can be assured that I am following these issues carefully with the long-term objective of establishing a multiple land use policy in the region . . .

Of course, that is now a complete anathema to the Government. No doubt Mr Hawke would throw in the word `obscenity' if he got half a chance. Of course, Senator Evans had to concede his position in those classic words of the Nixon Administration, that it was `no longer operative' and that he `no longer held that long term objective'.

Let us revert to 16 September, which I suggest in this debate is a day of infamy. It was the very day when, at 8.30 in the morning, the Cabinet meeting had cobbled together a thoroughly dis- honourable and discreditable compromise. It involved the agreement to seek World Heritage listing as soon as possible. Indeed, the documentation was sent to the World Heritage Committee the following day nominating stage 2 for inclusion in the World Heritage List. It is not at all clear whether that documentation is in the appropriate form or that it was accompanied by the necessary data and report. In that regard I refer to the evidence of a public servant who appeared before Estimates Committee D on 7 October last. He was asked about the position and he said he thought the letter had been signed before the disgraceful Press release, which we will come to shortly. He stated:

The National Parks and Wildlife Service has prepared, in effect, information along the lines of a new nomination, although it is not regarded as a new nomination, and that has been transmitted to Paris.
We have had an acknowledgment from the World Heritage Committee. This information has been examined . . . and it will be considered at the World Heritage Committee in November.

It is my submission that that process is in flagrant violation of the requirements of the Convention and the guidelines. It is therefore an illegal attempt to secure World Heritage listing. In fact, the requirements under the Convention are that any listing that is forwarded after 1 January must be considered only in the following calendar year. This was submitted shortly after 16 September. It will be brought before the World Heritage Committee in mid-November. Quite clearly it is in breach of the guidelines and is all part of the disgraceful haste that has led the Government into its present predicament. I suggest that it is also an illegal act and that any application to seek an injunction to restrain the Government from proceeding would have a very good prospect of success. It is clear that the action was undertaken without any consultation with the Government of the Northern Territory. That was also a flagrant breach of the Government's own guidelines and, more importantly, of the terms of the undertaking which had been contained in the Minister's letter. It is not dated. I do not suppose that is deliberate but, nonetheless, the wording in the letter is unequivocal. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) writing to the Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr Coulter, stated:

In relation to the possible inclusion of Kakadu Stage 2 on the World Heritage List, procedures for nominating possible future Australian sites for World Heritage listing were agreed at the July 1984 meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM) and included, inter alia, a commitment by the Commonwealth to full consultation with State and Territory Governments. Should the Commonwealth decide to pursue World Heritage listing on the former Stage 2 area, your Government will be consulted in accordance with the CONCOM agreement prior to any approach being made to the World Heritage Secretariat in Paris.

That is an unequivocal commitment and it flies in the face of the disgraceful, deceitful and dis- honourable statements made by the Minister subsequently in the House of Representatives. In my submission it amounts to conduct rendering him unfit to retain his office. It has brought the Parliament into disrepute and there is absolutely no justification at all for doing what has never been done before. In every other instance the State or Territory government has been consulted prior to any attempt at listing and its consent has been obtained. In this instance that procedure was to be followed again. It deliberately was not followed. That in itself is bad enough, but the equivocation of the Minister is beyond belief. The shabby attempts to blame others and to pretend that somehow that commitment does not exist does the Government no credit at all and those who retain the services of the Minister likewise have a lot to answer for.

If that letter had been sent before 8.30 in the morning, why was there not a subsequent public statement or private explanation, at the very least, to the Territory Government detailing why the events of the morning had rendered that letter inoperative? It is an instance of monumental cowardice. If the letter was sent after the shabby deal, it contained a deliberately false and deceitfully misleading assertion. The Minister has pleaded no contest. He does not deny that he wrote the letter on 16 September in the terms I have just recited, or that he put out the Press release in flat contradiction on the same day. At one stage he made a very squalid and sordid attempt to suggest that he had consulted with others. That emerged-it was not plucked out of the air-from the evidence of a Mr Kerr before Estimates Committee D. He stated:

The question of the incorporation of stage 2 in the existing World Heritage list was one of several matters raised. The letter that Mr Cohen sent to Mr Coulter represented the Government's position in terms of consultation.

One might have thought that that offered the Minister, who was desperately seeking some way out, the opportunity to explain that somehow or other he had the consultation which the letter clearly committed him to having. If it were not for the fact that others were present at the meeting I suppose he would have been faced with saying: `Well, it is my word that there were consultations. It is the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory's word that there were not'.

I seek to incorporate two statutory declarations from very courageous Northern Territory citizens. Terence Robert McCarthy, who is a member of the Legislative Assembly, was present at that meeting. On oath, he stated:

World Heritage listing . . . was not discussed whilst I was in attendance at the meeting between the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Hon. Steve Hatton, the Federal Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Hon. Barry Cohen . . . However, listing in respect of Uluru National Park was briefly considered.
Perhaps a more courageous person yet was a public servant by the name of Alan Gregory Morris, who has also deposed to the fact that he was present at that meeting. He stated:

The matter of possible World Heritage listing for Kakadu National Park Stage 2 was not raised between the Ministers while I was present at this meeting. The possible nomination of Uluru National Park for World Heritage listing was briefly raised.

One might have thought that that was sufficient to blow the Minister out of the water. He has not since tried to resort to that shabby explanation. What he has done is almost as bad because if one looks at his answer to a question in the House of Representatives on 9 October, when it was suggested to him that he told a deliberate lie-the questioner was asked to withdraw-his answer was:
. . . it was intended by the previous Government that Kakadu stage 2 would eventually become part of the park and would be an addition to the World Heritage listing . . .
He stated that Uluru National Park had been discussed with Mr Hatton. He continued:
However, in this particular case it was intended to be merely an addition to the existing park.

He is saying that there was no need to have that further consultation. Quite clearly that is wrong. It is quite apparent that a requirement was undertaken voluntarily by the Government, an undertaking that would be consistent with the obligations of the World Heritage Committee. To pretend that somehow there is any such animal in law as an extension to an existing application is quite fictitious. There is simply no provision in any of the international requirements that would countenance such an arrangement. Once Kakadu National Park had been put on the World Heritage List it remained there. There is no provision at all for an extension. A further application would need to be made in respect of stage 2 and that was always the Government's intention. Again, the Minister has resorted to subterfuge and verbal legerdemain that is quite beyond the bounds of propriety in this Parliament and which renders him quite unfit and unreliable in this matter and presumably in others. He has let down those public servants who were prepared to trot out a couple of excuses before the Estimates Committee. He has then given his own feeble excuse. The end result is that he stands condemned for a flagrant breach of an undertaking and for even shabbier attempts to disown his own dishonesty.

There are a number of areas in stage 2 that are of particular conservation value. Many areas are not. More than two-thirds of stage 3 is either bare rock with no vegetation or simply sandy soil supporting heath-like scrub or spinifex-the classic clapped out buffalo country that we have heard so much about. What is required is a sober assessment of the cost benefits of the area and a realistic appraisal of whether it is possible to mine without permanently destroying the natural environment, whilst retaining the integrity and beauty of these unique areas. This does not mean a Swiss cheesing. With the rapid advances in technology, it may well mean that what was not possible at the time of the Fox Ranger Inquiry in 1977 is now eminently possible.

Perhaps the most disgraceful performance of this whole shabby episode has been the conduct of the Minister, who has a great deal of explaining to do. In the absence of a pretty compelling explanation to the Parliament, he ought to resign for conduct unbecoming a Minister of the Crown. Either his code of ethics or his standard of honesty is beyond repair. At the meeting of conservation Ministers in July 1984 the guidelines were agreed. They required full consultation by the Commonwealth with the relevant State and Territory governments, as has always been the case. It is perhaps not coincidental that Mr Cohen's letter of 16 September was responding to a letter of some three months earlier. It is therefore again very difficult to understand why there was a need for such haste. It can only have been a product of the panic that beset both the Cabinet and the Caucus on that fateful day.

The operational guidelines, as I have already indicated, draw no distinction between extension and new listing. The concept of an extension is mentioned nowhere, and it does not exist, as the Minister well knows. His letter shows the need for a fresh application. The tragedy is that, in this whole debate, emotionalism and a desperate effort to pander to anti-uranium forces have seen logic, common sense and the national interest go out the window. There are, I suggest, a number of environmental Pol Pots in this country who are more interested in preserving the pristine beauty and quality of areas, to the exclusion of human beings. To take that position is simply to defeat the very purpose of the declaration of national parks and to ignore the very real reason for trying to preserve the environment. It is for the benefit of those who live in and visit those wonderful areas. Until that historic day of infamy when the pusillanimous Cabinet decision was made there was some prospect of a rational resolution, but there is now no prospect of any reasonable approach being adopted. The concept of multiple land use, one would have thought, was a sensible position to adopt, but it is certainly not capable of being adopted by the Government with its present attitude.

I now turn to some of the statements that take issue with the whole concept that underlies the plan of management. In particular, there is a proposal that the impact of aircraft on the park environment be specified. The plan does not explain why there is a need for that; it simply throws it in. No doubt someone suggested that overflying might loosen a few rocks or might scare away a few water fowl. Good enough! It goes into the plan of management! It is not just me; it is not just a few rednecked miners and it is not just a few anti-environmental troglodytes, but really the plan of management that is ideologically blinkered. Who says that? It is not just Harry Butler and not just Professor Mellanby, who today have said that 75 per cent of stage 2 is not worth listing. They have made a film which flatly contradicts some of the assertions in the plan. They will be presenting that evidence to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation committee. If this Government has any gumption and honour, it will facilitate the presentation of that material before the committee instead of taking every step to frustrate its presentation.

The concept of natural justice involves the right to be heard. The Northern Territory Government has a very good case, and it deserves not only to be heard but also to be encouraged by the Federal Government. Quite clearly the Federal Government will do the opposite. By hook or by crook, it will suggest that somehow it has complied with all the requirements, that somehow this extension constitutes a new application, that somehow it is not required to abide by the time limits and guidelines and that it can simply do what it thinks might be in the short term political interest of saving its own skin to the ultimate detriment of not only the national interest but also the sensible use and preservation of the park in a state of integrity.

I return to one other critic who cannot be dismissed lightly; that is, Professor Slatyer, a former Ambassador to UNESCO and a world-renowned scientist. He is not a pettifogging lawyer; he is not a redneck miner. What does he say in his submission to Professor Ovington? It is a scathing condemnation of fuzzy thinking. He accuses those responsible for the plan of action of having ill-thought-out priorities. That is really a very charitable interpretation. He says:

Because of the vague way in which a number of activities are specified and because of the lack of staffing and other resource details, it is difficult to gauge the degree to which the objectives are likely to be achieved.
Again, it is pretty charitable stuff.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is at the ANU, isn't he?
—He is; he is a well-respected academic.
—Not a troglodyte?
—He is no troglodyte. Indeed, he is a very respected environmental scientist. What does he say about the plan's management objectives? He says:

SPEECH.PARA: This chapter is imprecise, particularly the `key management objectives'. No priorities are set for implementation.
Under the sub-heading `Specific sections', he says:
The categories of management objectives . . . therefore are not adequate, and not particularly useful. Key objectives: many of these are imprecise, using vague or general terms.
And again:
1. What are `Park values'? If the aim, for example, is to protect the natural (and cultural) environment of the Aboriginal inhabitants (and visitors?) . . .
Why not say so? He continues:
What does `whilst developing an Aboriginal perspective for management' mean?
He goes on:

Will these resources be preserved, conserved or merely `protected'? What will they be protected from? What actually is the aim? Again, . . . what are the adverse consequences of fire, or environmental change?
In relation to zoning, he says:
This chapter provides the barest of introductory remarks about zoning, arguably the most important tool of management . . . This is a most inadequate attempt to address the practicalities of zoning.
When he comes to `Wilderness zones', he says:
This contains perhaps the most cowardly definition . . . of wilderness yet published!

Do honourable senators know what the definition was? It was that `wilderness is difficult to define'. It highlights the inadequacy of the plan of management, the plan which has led this Government in panic to rush off to UNESCO to seek World Heritage listing despite the absence of any feasible assessment of its mineral or environmental worth and despite the fact that very many renowned scientists in this country are prepared to take the Government head on and are not got in by a three-day public relations jaunt to the Northern Territory by St Paul, who not so long ago was writing to Mr Cohen that he was very concerned that mining was to be excluded but who now throws around the word `obscenity' whenever it suits him and whenever he thinks there might be an opportunity for political milage. It is a shabby, sordid episode. It ignores the realities and the practicalities; it is not in the national interest. The attempt at listing is illegal; the Minister's conduct is disgraceful. There are those in the environmental movement who are doing their own side a substantial injustice by overplaying their hand and by encouraging governments to think that the majority of the population will be seduced by the green vote. They are doing everyone in this community a grave disservice.

This is a sorry tale. The Government should reconsider its position. It should not squander public money on seeking to pursue the listing further. It should acknowledge the validity of the complaints of the Northern Territory Government. It should withdraw the plan from the listing application. It should go back to square one and assess the very real benefits that might derive to the national interest from the assessment that has been made to date by the Bureau of Mineral Resources and the very real opportunities that exist to get us out of our current account deficit hole by honourable means. Instead it seems that the Government is prepared in a very shabby and sordid manner to seek political mileage from throwing a few bones to members of the conservation movement. I hope that they are not fooled. I hope that they realise that the coalition parties are interested in the preservation of the environment, are prepared to take responsible decisions in the national interests, in fact have a very good track record in their eight years of conservative government and can be relied upon in future to make sensible, objective decisions, not subjective, emotional, political, vote seeking decisions, and ultimately to present a much more sensible and healthy alternative for this nation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two statutory declarations.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
AUSTRALIA
STATUTORY DECLARATION

I, TERENCE ROBERT McCARTHY of 59 Pinarro Crescent Batchelor in the Northern Territory of Australia, Member of the Legislative Assembly do solemnly and sincerely declare that World Heritage listing for Kakadu National Park Stage II was not discussed whilst I was in attendance at the meeting between the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Hon. Steve Hatton, the Federal Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Hon. Barry Cohen, myself and officers held on 4 September 1986 in the Chief Minister's office. However, listing in respect of Uluru National Park was briefly considered.

I make this solemn declaration by virtue of the Statutory Declarations Act 1959 as amended and subject to the penalties provided by that Act for the making of false statements in statutory declarations, conscientiously believing the statements contained in this declaration to be true in every particular.
Declared at DARWIN on 17th October 1986
before me,
S. M. WOODS
Commissioner for Oaths
Northern Territory
AUSTRALIA
STATUTORY DECLARATION

I, ALAN GREGORY MORRIS, PUBLIC SERVANT OF 4 GOTHENBERG COURT, STUART PARK, N.T. do solemnly and sincerely declare that I attended the Office of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, the Honourable S. P. Hatton on Thursday, 4 September 1966 for a meeting between the Chief Minister and the Federal Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, the Hon. Barry Cohen. The matter of possible World Heritage listing for Kakadu National Park Stage 2 was not raised between the Ministers while I was present at this meeting. The possible nomination of Uluru National Park for World Heritage listing was briefly raised.

I make this solemn declaration by virtue of the Statutory Declarations Act 1959 as amended and subject to the penalties provided by that Act for the making of false statements in statutory declarations, conscientiously believing the statements contained in this declaration to be true in every particular.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a motion for disallowance of the Kakadu National Park plan of management, and quite properly so. Looking at this motion one is reminded of the debate that took place a little earlier today in the Senate in respect of Jackeys Marsh. This is the second matter to arise today which is inextricably and intrinsically tied to the political fortunes, at least as the Government perceives them, of this Government. The decision to place stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park on the World Heritage List and the content of the plan of management are nothing more and nothing less than a coldly calculating, cynical, political decision based purely on the premise which is attracting currency in the Australian Labor Party at present that there is a significant leakage and drifting of the conservation vote away from the Labor Party towards the more lunatic Left groupings.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of that assessment which was made recently by the hard heads of the Australian Labor Party, there has been a significant change in direction in respect of matters relating primarily to conservation. As I said, earlier we saw a case of the Federal Government, contrary to the wishes of the Government of Tasmania and the Australian Labor Party Opposition in Tasmania, seeking to impose its views, wishes and judgment on the logging of Jackeys Marsh. For the same reasons the decisions in respect of Kakadu National Park have been made. What better, more gross, crude and unattractive example is there of this than the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), at short notice, making a flying visit to be seen standing on the top of Obiri Rock and visiting the more beautiful parts of the park, which will become common to many people when they see the movie Crocodile Dundee. Of course, the Prime Minister was not viewed or photographed looking at the other parts of Kakadu, which in many respects are a reflection only of the typical landscape of northern Australia which encompasses thousands upon thousands of square miles.

The decision to disallow mining in stage 2, for instance, but to allow mining in stage 3 is nothing more and nothing less than a political decision based, as I said, on the premise that the Government is losing votes from the conservation group. More particularly in respect of that matter, it is to prevent the division that cast itself into the Labor Party in respect of uranium mining. It is interesting to look at the sequence of events. When it was announced in the Budget Speech that uranium would be sold to France there was an enormous uproar, convulsion and imbroglio within the Australian Labor Party. At that time the Government, particularly the Prime Minister, was committed to selective mining or multiple land use in stage 2 of Kakadu National Park and that, I have no doubt, included uranium mining and mining for whatever other minerals and metals were found in due course. However, the moment that Budget decision came to light it became obvious to the conservation lobby within the Government that the decision to mine in Kakadu National Park would go ahead.

So, of course, the Department, or office bearers of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), promptly leaked a letter written by the Prime Minister to Mr Cohen which put the view that there ought to be mining within stage 2 of Kakadu National Park. That, combined with the uproar that had taken place following the decision to sell uranium to France, was more than the Government could cope with politically; so, in consequence of that, the decision was made that there would be no mining in stage 2. The essence and significance of that is that stage 2 is perceived-no more than perceived-to be a major area of significance and potential for uranium mining and is not identified in the same way as stage 3 is, as having the potential for other minerals and metals. The problem was solved simply by saying that there would be no mining in stage 2 at all. That appeared at least to satisfy those who wanted no uranium mining without cutting off the prospect of exploiting other minerals and metals in the park area, because it provided that there could be mining in stage 3. The other significance of that is that there is very little in the way of identifiable uranium resources in stage 3 but there is an already well established and identified resource potential at Coronation Hill for gold, platinum and molybdenum. So the Government, rescuing what it could of the resources of Kakadu National Park, allowed for mining within stage 3.

That all came about, of course, as a result of the leaking of the Prime Minister's letter to his Minister Mr Cohen, whose position was quite clear right from the outset: He had set his face against the Cabinet and the Prime Minister. His position was that there should be no mining of any nature in stages 1 or 2. That left the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, in an intolerable situation. He had to extract the best he could. He and his Department pored, no doubt at great length, over the maps seeking to find out where the potential resources of uranium and other metals and minerals were and finally came down with the poor, weak, pathetic compromise that we finally have. It is in no way bound by logic; it is in no way set upon a premise of common sense; it is simply an arbitrary decision which seeks to placate the conservation vote and those in the Labor Party who will not tolerate uranium mining.

My view is that mining and tourism can take place side by side in parts of the park. I refer to stages 1, 2 and 3, but not necessarily stage 1 or stage 2. I do that for a very good reason-the enormous size of the area. It ought to be remembered that the three stages comprise approximately 19,000 hectares and that the first two stages represent something like 13,000 hectares. The truth of the matter is that the ideal solution for the conservationists is to maintain the whole of the park, stages 1, 2 and 3, in its wilderness state, untouched not only by mining or tourism but also by any human activity. The conservationists certainly have an ongoing prejudice against any form of mining and, to a lesser extent, against tourism. I do not refer to all conservationists; I just do not have time to categorise them. I am referring to the group which, as Senator Zakharov will clearly understand, has been before our Committee. Their preference, if there is to be one, is for tourism, not for mining. One could question why that is so. I can only imagine that the reason is that it is easier to create emotion and set prejudice against mining than it is to do so against tourism, which embraces all sections of the community. Yet it is interesting to note that in the evidence taken by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, if my memory serves me correctly, the preference of the two, tourism or mining, is for mining over tourism. From the point of view of the Aboriginal community, of course, a great deal more damage can be done to the park by tourism than can be done by mining. This is for two reasons. First of all, there is the simple size of the area involved in tourism and the areas that it can lead people to, people who can trample, damage and desecrate parts of the park and areas of significance to the Aboriginal community.

Let me remind the Senate of the extent of mining in the park. The total surface area of Ranger represents some four square kilometres; Jabiluka would be less. In fact, if all the known mining areas were exploited, they would represent slightly less than one per cent of the total area of the park. It is not without significance to note that the conservation groups are particularly antagonistic towards mining, and slightly more tolerant towards tourism. Yet the conservation groups have expressed concern, as has the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, that the concerns of the Aboriginal community be considered. That should be a paramount concern in any deliberation, yet their own private and public views fly in the face of the wishes-perhaps one might put it as highly as the aspirations-of the Aboriginal community. The Aboriginal communities are not opposed to mining per se. In their view, the whole area is of significance, but in fact they support mining provided that it does not interfere with areas of real significance to them. The Northern Land Council, for instance, is not opposed to mining in the park and put that proposition to us. Its view in many respects seems to be parallel to that of the Aboriginal community, and it put that view in evidence to the Standing Committee on National Resources inquiry into the resources of the park.

We took evidence from the Sacred Sites Authority, which had a different view, namely, that there should be no mining at all. What I find unnerving about that is that its charter is to protect and preserve areas of significance and sacred sites in the Aboriginal community and to do it accurately. Yet one finds that its view is contrary to that taken by the people it purports to represent. It never ceases to amaze me that the Aboriginal community is articulate, competent and capable enough to put its own point of view, and does it well; but invariably its point of view is quite different from that put by its white advisers, by the monolithic institutions we seem to be forever setting up to protect and represent Aboriginal interests. Almost without exception, there is a contradiction between the two, and that is true of the present case. The truth is that these people are not representing Aboriginal communities, but put forward their view of the world and how they would like the world to be.

One has to have grave concern about this plan of management because it has been prepared without consultation with people with major experience and interest in the park, not the least of them being the Northern Territory Government. Professor Ovington has indicated that there have been close, co-operative, ongoing negotiations with the Northern Territory Government. The Northern Territory Government says as a statement of fact that there has been no consultation, no co-operation, and almost no communication. Therefore, I find it remarkable that Professor Ovington and his Department are putting it to the community that the plan of management results from close co-operation with concerned people, not the least being the Northern Territory Government.

As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, which has as a term of reference given unto it by the Senate that it shall inquire into the potential of the park, I have always refrained from expressing a personal or private view as to the ultimate outcome of its findings. To the same extent I find myself constrained in putting my view in this debate. What is disheartening is that the sort of evidence we have been receiving appears not to have been accepted, or at least acknowledge, as in part a framework to be used in arriving at judgments on the management of the park. Professor Ovington called for an inventory of the mineral and metal resource potential of the park. I do not know how he could have imagined that could be done when he totally opposed the plan of management and dismissed out of hand any mining at all. How did he imagine that one could take an inventory of the natural resources of the park? In view of the park's geography and the nature of the terrain, such an inventory cannot be undertaken by aerial magnetic survey. Such an exercise must be done on the ground. It cannot be done without some sort of drilling program, and drilling can be done without damaging the park. We have this altruistic call for an inventory, yet at the same time the plan of management says that there shall be no mining-in other words, no exploration. It is an absurd proposition. Perhaps that was just a throw-away line to placate those who might have superficially read the report and taken a view about mining.

The report is equally absurd and vague in regard to tourism. It is imprecise and has no definitions. It is not indicative of how tourism should take place and in no way justifies its position on tourism or sets out the reasons for limiting tourism. As I said at the outset, it is simply a political document. Professor Ovington said that it is a reflection of the view of the government of the day, or more particularly of the Minister's view. It does not involve assembling, assessing and distilling the best evidence, the best knowledge and the best understanding of the position, but is a reflection of the views of the Government and the Minister. That makes it a political document, nothing more and nothing less. It ignores the facts that should have been contemplated.

Kakadu does have some areas of great beauty which deserve to be protected at any cost. They are part of Australia's heritage to be preserved now and for future generations. It must not be forgotten that stages 1 and 2, Gimbat and Goodparla, occupy nearly 20,000 square kilometres, yet the plan of management does not even attempt to address the matter of prospecting or mining within any areas of the park at all. It does not for a moment stop to contemplate the prospect of multiple land use. It seems to me that the underlying golden philosophic thread that runs through the report on the plan of management involves locking up stages 1 and 2 from mining. That would inhibit even managed and controlled tourism, and in stage 3 it would very much limit mining activities in that area. That is a tragedy. The plan of management does not address those matters. I believe it is a great pity that it has not looked at the ramifications or implications of multiple land use. This might well have been a unique opportunity, a blueprint for addressing all the options, but that opportunity has been lost. The truth of the matter is that the very vastness, the very beauty and the very uniqueness of parts of the park-the Jim Jim Falls, Twins Falls, Obiri Rock, all the places that Crocodile Dundee visited; beautiful spots which are, in many respects, unique-should be preserved. Yet there are vast areas and large tracts of the part that are no different from the majority of the northern parts of Western Australia. Now that I have seen that stage 3 is proposed to be made part of the park, I really wonder what will happen to the northern part of Western Australia, from the Pilbara right through the Kimberleys. There is no difference in the country. The areas are identical.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not part of the catchment, are they?

—Of course they are not part of the catchment, but there are vast parts of stage 3 that are not part of the catchment either. There is no reason why, because there is a catchment area in the northern part of stage 3 and running through stages 2 and 1, it necessarily means there is no capacity to have mining and tourism. Senator Zakharov appears to be working on the premise that, because there is a catchment area, that area will catch up any mining that takes place in the park at all. I would not have thought that that was necessarily the case. One only needs to look at mining technology these days. Since Fox put down his report we have realised that there is skill and technology which makes it possible to extract minerals and metals from parts of the park which, by definition, can be considered fragile, without in any way endangering the uniqueness or the beauty of the park. It is a great pity that the park was not looked at other than from a political point of view. This really could have been a unique opportunity to consider and contemplate all aspects of the issue. Criteria could have been set down as a watershed for the future preservation of parts of Australia for their natural beauty.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the beauty and the size of Kakadu National Park we must accept that it will attract more and more tourists every year. If my memory serves me correctly, there were 140,000 tourists in the park last year. Those people visited the park in very poor conditions. The roads are dreadful and inhibiting-I suspect in many cases they are meant to be inhibiting-and the accommodation is almost non-existent except in two areas, Cooinda and the South Alligator River region. Other than that there is virtually no accommodation. If one wants to visit Jim Jim Falls, one must take a four-wheel drive vehicle. The journey takes a day and when one arrives there is nowhere to stay and there are no facilities. It is quite impossible. The park is being locked up from tourists.

Then, of course, we must look at the mining side. How long can mining be ignored? Of course, as long as the Prime Minister is happy with our current account deficit figures-and he appears to be happy with the last lot-the present situation might go on forever. However, when one looks at the potential of the park in respect of mining-although part of the assessment is only indicative, it has been put by responsible people and supported, I suspect, by the Department of Resources and Energy-one realises that it has the potential of approximately $70 billion worth of revenue to the taxpayers of this country. Let us remember that in the Northern Territory in 1983-84 alone mining generated $872m. That is $590m more than the amount generated by tourism. Yet the Government is saying that if it has a preference it will have a bit of tourism but no mining. Of that $872m, $18m went to support Aboriginal communities. Part of that went to the 250 Aboriginals who are spread throughout this massive area of 13,000 square kilometres of stages 1 and 2.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that figure for tourism that you mentioned just for the Northern Territory or for the whole of Australia?

—It was just for the Northern Territory. In my view that is indicative of the resource potential of the park and I suspect that in time it will not be ignored. As I said at the outset, I find it disappointing that this document, this report, this plan of management that we are now seeking to disallow did not address itself sensibly, with some sophistication and responsibility, to all the matters that confront all Australians so that we would be in a position to move forward in a sensible way in the future. I commend the proposal for disallowance of the plan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the need for a plan of management in the Kakadu National Park. As has been stated by previous speakers in this debate, the Australian Democrats will not support the disallowance. The Kakadu National Park is important, both to Australia and to the world. It is important for the diversity of its flora and fauna and for the large number of rare and endangered species of both plants and animals that can be found there. These are not necessarily spectacular plants, but they are plants that probably contain a fair amount of the genetic potential which is necessary for use to recapture a reasonable environment in the tropics.

SPEECH.PARA: Stage 1 of the Kakadu National Park was proclaimed in 1979 and is on the World Heritage List. All the wetlands of stage 1 have been included in the list of recognised areas under the international convention on wetlands of international importance, especially as water fowl habitats. Stage 2 of Kakadu was proclaimed in 1984 and is now likely to be added to the World Heritage List. We are pleased about that process, unlike Senator Alston. Stage 3 has not yet been proclaimed, although public notice was given in March 1984 of a proposal to include the Gimbat and Goodparla pastoral leases in Kakadu National Park. The wetlands, the escarpment and the Aboriginal drawings have been particularly noted for their intrinsic beauty, but a national park is not foremost a place of beauty; it is a place set aside because it is of importance to preserve natural attributes which include not only scenery but also, much more importantly, the plants, animals and features of the region.

I wish to concentrate on one area which has not been mentioned in any detail by my colleagues and that is the preservation of the world genetic pool, which I consider to be one of the most important aspects of national and world heritage parks. For this reason Kakadu is important to the world. Stages 2 and 3 of the park are very important for their natural resources of undulating woodlands and for the large numbers of rare and endangered species of plants and animals. Whilst Kakadu contains natural mineral resources as well as animal and plant resources, it is indeed important to weigh the future advantages of conservation against the opportunity lost by keeping those minerals in the ground at this stage. I wish to point out to those people who assume that most of the minerals are under the Kakadu park that only 3 per cent of the Pine Creek geosyncline, which is the main mining prospect in that area, is in Kakadu territory. According to the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines, 97 per cent of the Pine Creek geosyncline is outside Kakadu, even if one includes in Kakadu the stage 3 area.

While minerals within the national park are effectively locked up for the foreseeable future, they still remain an Australian resource. They are still there and conserved along with the rest of the national park. If, as Senator Crichton-Browne has said, we can ever find methods of mining these effectively without affecting the environment, which I currently doubt, there may be a possibility of doing something. But there is no need to do it. I do not believe that they should be mined now. My experience is that the environment will be damaged and that valuable natural resources may be lost forever, particularly in the form of specific plants which as yet may not even have been classified or recognised by botanists.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know they are there then?

—Senator Crichton-Browne asks how I know that they are there. There have been a number of discoveries of individual plants in the area that are known to survive under very strange and stringent conditions. From discussions with members of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Wildlife and Rangelands and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, I have indications that particular sub-species of plants exist in some areas of the park in environments where they would not be expected to survive. This may give us an opportunity to enable those species to survive in areas that are very inhospitable to them elsewhere and to diversify the genetic pool for some of our main food crops, for example, or maybe for some of our drug-producing or fibre-producing plants.
—Do you mean grow marihuana?

—I am not suggesting that type of drug. I do not believe that mining should be carried out now. Mining is essentially a destructive operation. It destroys, extracts and uses up a mineral resource and often destroys the land associated with the minerals. It also affects all life forms. Some of the run-off from mining areas and the side-products from the extractive processes can be terribly damaging to the environment. I know of no overriding national interest that requires that these minerals within Kakadu National Park be mined, especially as there are many times those deposits of minerals outside the Kakadu area that could be mined. I do not know of any overriding national interest or world interest to justify going in there and ripping out a few minerals, which may have a terrible effect on valuable genetic material, whose future value could be incalculable and may well be millions of times more than the value of the physical mineral wealth of the region.

SPEECH.PARA: Already modern techniques of molecular biology allow us to manipulate genetic material, to take a gene from a plant that grows in only one exotic place and to transfer it to another plant or animal, or even to a bacterium. In this way scientists hope to find cures for a large number of the diseases that affect people, plants and livestock. This will allow us to increase and improve the natural genetic inheritance, to overcome deficiencies and to provide extra genetic capacity to resist various diseases. Other uses that the new genetic manipulations are being put to are to transfer genes for production of rare drugs to organisms that can be easily and plentifully grown and to so reduce considerably the price of medical treatment.

A whole new era of technology is now opening up in front of us that 20 years ago was barely dreamt of and in which new uses of exotic genetic material are economically solving other problems of diverse kinds. It is this type of genetic pool that is held in wilderness areas and in our national parks under the types of conditions that exist in those parks. That is why we need a mosaic of national parks throughout the whole of our nation to protect these natural resources. Once an animal, plant or micro-organism has died out, its complete genetic inheritance, the product of complex evolutionary mechanism, is lost to the world. In fact this may happen in some cases well before we have any idea of the future value of what we are destroying. It is essential that we have a full catalogue of the plant resources in these areas. That has not been developed properly at this stage and we certainly need to protect samples of all areas until this catalogue and a full database has been set up. It is essential to maintain the national parks so that it is possible to grow these various plants in a number of different climatic and ecological landscapes so as to maintain the fullest and most diverse genetic pool for the future generations of man and also for the continuance of life on earth.

National parks are also important for preserving other natural features of our inheritance. We cannot afford to preserve only areas that look good and that people like to visit for picnics and barbecues. It is not only the tourist areas that are important. The educational aspects of national parks are also of major importance. They are the main way in which we preserve areas that reflect our historical heritage, our natural heritage and our geological heritage.

The Kakadu National Park is paramount in preserving some very different parts of the Northern Territory in one integral area. We have a real opportunity there. I hope that the plan of management will be strengthened in the future so that we make certain that we do not lose any of these advantages.

The park has enormous value in teaching us and future generations about our past and the changes that have occurred in other areas through the impact of both natural and human processes. If we can keep wilderness areas, we can learn something about the long term effects, even of our remote cities, on these areas by observing them scientifically. In this way we can learn from our past and have areas that are free from the destructive and wasteful processes that are happening in and near our cities. It is for this reason that the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources has included education as well as recreation as the main uses for national parks that must be managed on a controlled basis. The IUCN calls for `the protection of natural and scenic areas of national or international significance for scientific, educational and recreational use'. The IUCN report states:

The area should perpetuate in a natural state representative samples of physiographic regions, biotic communities and genetic resources and species in danger of extinction to provide ecological stability and diversity.

While stage 1 of Kakadu consists predominantly of flood plains and escarpment country, stage 2 comprises for a large part wetlands, with regions of rainforest and open woodland. The undulating woodlands of stages 2 and 3 are very important environmentally since they contain a greater species diversity than any of the other regions, including a large number of rare and endangered species. This is a very different type of country from what is the popular view of Kakadu. It is ecologically of great significance to Australia and to the world.

Stage 3 of Kakadu contains the headwaters of the Alligator Rivers, especially the South Alligator River. Already there is great concern in the National Parks and Wildlife Service that erosion caused by pastoral activity in this stage 3 region is increasing the turbidity of South Alligator River, so causing a detrimental impact on the existing park. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later today.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TERMS OF REFERENCE
1. The Council of the Australian War Memorial here- by appoints Kenneth Norman Jones, A.C., C.B.E., to investigate and report to it on:
(a) concerns relating to the management of the Australian War Memorial including personnel, financial and general administration;

(b) any deficiencies that you might identify in the management of the affairs of the Memorial including whether the Memorial administration has properly informed the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Council about the affairs of the Memorial;

(c) any other matter relating to the management of the affairs of the Memorial which may be referred to you by the Council or notified by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs by letter to the Chairman of Council; and

(d) any deficiencies in your view in the relevant legislation as it affects the management of the affairs of the Australian War Memorial and the relationship between the Director, the Council, and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

2. In conducting your investigation you are to take account of such earlier reports and material including the O'Connor report, the Auditor-General's report, the Arthur Young report and other relevant documents as are available.
3. For the purposes of your investigation you may with approval of Council obtain such legal advice as you may consider necessary.

4. In conducting your investigation you are to ensure that the Director and any other member of the staff of the Australian War Memorial be given a fair opportunity to be heard on and respond to any matters relating to them. In particular no adverse finding will be made against the Director or any other member of staff unless such person has first had an opportunity to consider any specific allegation, to examine documentation relating to it and to respond in detail either orally or in writing.
5. It is not intended that there be public hearings.

6. The Council of the Memorial has resolved that the Director shall subject to appropriate security and supervisory arrangements have access to the records of the Australian War Memorial during the period of his absence on special leave. Similar access will be granted to any other member of staff on your recommendation.

7. Your report to Council shall include a summary of evidence, the conclusions you drew from it, and any recommendations concerning the management of the Australian War Memorial that you may see fit to make.
8. Your report is to be presented to the Council, through the Chairman, which has resolved to make a copy immediately available to the Minister.

9. The inquiry should be concluded within one calendar month but recognising that there may arise unforeseen circumstances you may apply to the Council for an extension of time to properly allow you to carry out the inquiry.
10. Such administrative support as is necessary for the purposes of carrying out the inquiry will be provided by the Australian War Memorial.
1 October 1986
SUMMARY OF CONCLUSIONS

The Terms of Reference are not directed primarily at criticism of action by the Director. Nevertheless a large number of items put before me, some of which are anonymous in origin are of that character. I have faced a difficulty in reconciling the general nature of paragraph 1 of the Terms of Reference with the process for arriving at adverse findings about an individual. (para 5.2)

I conclude that there are serious weaknesses in the management performance of the present Director. This represents a value judgement by me and is a considered view, arrived at in accordance with the Terms of Reference as discussed at the beginning of this chapter. (para 5.26)

Nevertheless, the Director is entitled to respect from the Memorial staff at all levels for his authority and responsibilities. This has not always been forthcoming to the extent that it should have been, even in the face of differences or difficulties. (para 5.28)

I conclude that in a number of cases, insufficient or misleading information has been given to the present Minister, but not so as to cause him serious embarrassment in the public arena. It has given the Minister serious cause for concern and grounds to lack confidence in the advice he receives from the Director. (para 5.29)

I cannot conclude from this Inquiry that there exists misbehaviour by the Director in the terms of Section 24 (1) of the AWM Act as I understand that provision. I do not find a deliberate intention by the Director to transgress in carrying out his duties. Rather in some situations I have concluded that the Director has displayed a less than satisfactory level of competence and a carelessness in expression where the circumstances demanded truthfulness. (para 5.32)

In the interest of the Memorial and its staff, it is essential for the Council to approve a set of principles governing outside employment in all aspects with particular reference to research and research-related publications. Such principles should recognise the interest of the Memorial in advancing the professional standing of its staff and in promoting research into and understanding about Australian military history. (para 5.43)

. . . similar considerations apply to instances of private practice by say, conservators, and to the use of workshops and other facilities other than for official purposes. In each of these cases, guidelines should be stated clearly, channels of approval should be known, and instances of approval documented. (para 5.44)

The present arrangement (for publications policy and procedure) should be reviewed between the Research and Publications Committee and the Research and Publications Branch so that proposals can be developed for final consideration and decision by Council. (para 5.49)

The Memorial is not a Commonwealth Department and the Council has independent status. Even so the relationship between the principal parties-the Council, the Minister and the Director-is not limited to the formal structures. A fruitful and harmonious relationship can exist only where there are regular exchanges and meetings, at least between the Chairman and the Minister, and, on day to day matters which need reference to the Minister, between the Minister and the Director.
