The Director should advise the Chairman about matters to be taken up with the Minister by the Chairman and should keep the Chairman informed about exchanges between the Director and the Minister. A healthy relationship cannot be preserved if interaction is limited to crisis situations. (para 5.53)

The development of on-going co-operation among all of these parties-the Minister, the Chairman and Council, the Director and the Departmental Head-will be a significant factor in restoring the management of the affairs of the Memorial and the discharge of the Memorial's responsibilities to a satisfactory level. (para 5.61)

In my view, in most cases where an authority has been created to exercise a trustee role on behalf of the nation-which I believe to be the case with the AWM Council-it is undesirable that there be a statutory power for general or specific directions by the Minister. However, that view needs to be seen against the general policy objectives of the present government for ordinary statutory authorities. One has also to weigh up whether the present difficulties in relationships among the Minister, the Council and the Director are such that changes need to be made to the statutory provisions. No doubt it will be generally accepted that if there is to be such a power, its application should involve written directions and specific reference in the Annual Report to that circumstance and to the governing body's response. (para 5.71)

. . . the Minister's proposal for a specific (statutory) power to demand information is unnecessary, given his constitutional rights in that regard. Furthermore, against the background of the conclusions I have arrived at on other matters within the Terms of Reference, I am not persuaded that a statutory power of direction is essential to correct present difficulties and I would see the addition of either of these proposed powers as appropriate only in the context of the Parliament's approval of a comprehensive approach from the Government following confirmation of the thrust of its proposed policy guidelines which are now out for public discussion. (para 5.77)
The proposed (legislative) changes in measures for determining threshold figures for which ministerial approval is required, are sensible and non-controversial and I support them. (para 5.75)
I do not support the redesignation of the chief executive officer's position to `Director General'. (para 5.76)
I do not support the Minister's proposal for the appointment of the Secretary of his Department to the Council in the form in which it has been put forward. (para 5.78)

. . . I would prefer any officer from the Department of Veterans' Affairs appointed to the AWM Council to be a senior officer, not the Secretary, and for any such appointment to be made from among the number of ordinary members. (para 5.80)
I believe it would be appropriate for the Memorial to seek the co-operation of the Public Service Board in mounting a Program Management Performance Review. (para 5.90)

It is critical to the success of such an operation that it have the support and direct involvement of the chief executive officer. Against the background of the current upheaval surrounding the Memorial, it is desirable that this activity be taken up promptly. It follows that there needs first to be a clearing of the air and the creation of a working environment which will foster the pursuit of common purposes between management and staff. (para 5.92)
Chapter 1
PROCEDURE FOR THE INQUIRY
1.1 I commenced on 2 October having had the previous day a discussion with Council, in the presence of the Minister and advisors, about the Terms of Reference which were then being settled finally.

1.2 I gave an early opportunity for each of the Minister, the Chairman and the Director to have a general discussion about the events leading up to my Inquiry and the matters under consideration. In the case of the Director I checked that he had a copy of the basic documents.
1.3 I issued a circular to staff conveying the Terms of Reference and inviting those who wished to do so to discuss any relevant matters with me.

1.4 Subsequently I had a series of meetings with individuals and some groups among the staff at their request. I have also invited some other members of staff to speak with me to ensure that I have received representative views on attitudinal questions which touch on intra-Memorial work relationships and morale. I have had discussions with a number of officers about administrative procedures and have consulted files and Council and Committee records.

1.5 I have had discussions also with some members of Council, with some former members, with the previous Director, and with heads of departments whose ministers are now or were recently responsible for the Memorial. In a few cases these discussions have been conducted by telephone.

1.6 I have had a number of telephone conversations and two meetings with the Director. My purpose was to keep him informed of the course of the Inquiry and of the procedure I was following. I passed to him the list of matters provided by the Minister on 2 October within the provisions of Paragraph 1 (c) of the Terms of Reference. On 20 October I gave him the advice I had received from the Minister dated 16 October about specific circumstances in which he believed the Director had provided him with inadequate and misleading advice.

1.7 In my exchanges with the Director I explained that as a first step I was investigating the long list of matters put before me and would then narrow my examination to consideration of issues and identification of specific allegations about the conduct of individuals. At one stage I pointed out to the Director the desirability of him consulting files before answering written questions, and nominated a point of contact in the Memorial where access would be arranged in terms of Paragraph 6 of the Terms of Reference.

1.8 I have addressed some written questions to the Director and received answers in the course of the initial investigation. I followed this with notifications on 28, 29 and 30 October of the specific allegations that I was pursuing in respect of him and invited responses to those allegations together with some further questions of my own.
1.9 In these exchanges I nominated a time for reply, usually one week.
1.10 I have put written questions to other members of staff.
1.11 I have had discussions with the Chairman from time to time and a further discussion with the Minister. All concerned have co-operated with me.

1.12 I have had access to the O'Connor working papers, some of which were produced after the interim report, to the Young Report, to the Rush papers and to the Auditor-General's Report to the Minister and prior exchanges between Audit and the Memorial staff.

1.13 On 21 October the Director's solicitors wrote to me challenging my refusal to allow him to be present when evidence was being given that might adversely affect his reputation and to allow him or his legal representative the right to cross-examine witnesses. They saw this as a clear denial of natural practice. I was requested to accept information in accordance with the Rules of Evidence and preferably with evidence on oath. The letter foreshadowed an approach to the Council to consider altering the Terms of Reference unless I gave them a favourable response.

1.14 I replied on 22 October pointing out that I was proceeding with my task under the Terms of Reference, that I had kept the Director informed on matters which had been put to me and had provided him with copies of the associated documents and invited his responses and put some written questions to him. It was my intention to continue on that course and before I arrived at conclusions or findings to give him an opportunity to respond to specific allegations. I also stated my understanding that the Terms of Reference made no provision for the cross-examination of witnesses, the taking of evidence on oath or the application of the Rules of Evidence. I indicated that it was open to the Director to make any submission to me as to the weight that I should attach to any of the material made available to him in the course of my Inquiry.
1.15 I provided the Chairman of Council with copies of this exchange. On 24 October the Chairman conveyed to me the views of Council's solicitors on the matters raised by the Director's solicitors.

1.16 As outlined at the beginning of Chapter 5, on 4 November a difference of view crystalised between the Director and me as to the action I should take on particular matters to satisfy paragraph 4 of my Terms of Reference. Having stated my position to the Director I proceeded to complete my investigation and prepare this report.
1.17 Earlier I had sought and obtained the Chairman's approval to obtain legal advice from Commonwealth sources. I have done so.

1.18 On 23 October I made a formal request to the Chairman of Council under Paragraph 9 of the Terms of Reference for an extension to give me sufficient time to provide an opportunity for answers to be given to specific allegations before I reached any conclusions. I nominated 10 November as the expected date for presentation of my report, but drew attention to possible delays arising from the representations from the Director's solicitors. On 27 October the Chairman informed me that Council had agreed to extend the date for completion of the Inquiry accordingly and had suggested to the Director that he seek leave until 14 November. I understand he did so.

1.19 The Terms of Reference address matters of general principle together with a range of specific matters of concern. Consideration of some of these matters rests on a determination of the facts, while others require value judgments to be made. I have had to decide what weight should be given to particular submissions I have received. I have taken my examination of the events and situations put before me as the basis for my conclusions, together with the general understandings I have developed about the Memorial and the conduct of its affairs. I have drawn on my knowledge and experience in Commonwealth administration, with particular reference to relations between a minister, a statutory authority for which he is responsible, and his department.
1.20 Time and circumstance has not permitted me to pursue every item to finality, but I am satisfied as to the conclusions.
Chapter 2
THE AUSTRALIAN WAR MEMORIAL

2.1 The Australian War Memorial (AWM) is a great cultural institution with a well-deserved international reputation. It is a national shrine to the sacrifice of those Australian men and women who died serving their country in time of war and of those who served with them abroad and at home. At the same time the Memorial is a museum and art gallery with an extensive, rich and varied collection. It has developed as a centre of research into Australian Military history.

2.2 The Memorial has been undergoing a major renovation program of its premises in association with the refurbishment of the galleries. Construction has commenced on a separate administration building to provide more appropriate accommodation for staff and to free substantial gallery space in the main building for its intended purpose. In the suburb of Mitchell the Memorial owns a repository and conservation complex together with a nearby warehouse.
2.3 The Australian War Memorial Act 1980 lays down the functions of the Memorial as-
(a) to maintain and develop the national memorial referred to in sub-section 6 (1) of the Australian War Memorial Act 1962 as a national memorial of Australians who have died-
(i) on or as a result of active service; or
(ii) as a result of any war or warlike operations in which Australians have been on active service;
(b) to develop and maintain, as an integral part of the national memorial referred to in paragraph (a), a national collection of historical material;
(c) to exhibit, or to make available for exhibition by others, historical material from the memorial collection or historical material that is otherwise in the possession of the Memorial;
(d) to conduct, arrange for and assist in research into matters pertaining to Australian military history; and
(e) to disseminate information relating to-
(i) Australian military history;
(ii) the national memorial referred to in paragraph (a);
(iii) the memorial collection; and
(iv) the Memorial and its functions.
The Memorial shall use every endeavour to make the most advantageous use of the memorial collection in the national interest.

2.4 A Council of part-time members, made up of the Chiefs of Staff of the three Services and from eight to ten people chosen for the knowledge and experience that each can bring to the task, is responsible for conducting and controlling the affairs of the Memorial and for determining its policies. A Director, who is not a member of Council, is the Memorial's chief executive officer and manages its affairs under the general directions of the Council. Staff of the Memorial are members of the Australian Public Service and the Director has, for the purposes of administering the affairs of the staff under the Public Service Act, equivalent powers to those available under that Act to a departmental secretary.

2.5 The Council may appoint committees to assist it and may include non-members of Council among the members. At present the Council is functioning with three committees drawn from its own members together with the Director who, like the Chairman of Council, is a member of each committee. These are a Gallery Committee, a Research and Publications Committee, and a Buildings and Grounds Committee.

2.6 The staff of the Memorial under the Director is organised into Branches responsible for Programmes and Collections, Research and Publications, and Resources Management, together with an Executive Secretariat and a Public Relations section. The Australian War Memorial Bookshop forms part of this administrative structure.
2.7 The Council has set as its corporate objective

`to maintain and develop the Memorial and its collections and exhibits as a fitting tribute to the sacrifice of Australia's war dead, as a reminder of the cost of war and as a record of Australian military history, and to conduct and further research into that history'.

2.8 The resources available to administer the Memorial have been expanded significantly in recent years. Whereas at the end of 1979/80 there was a staff of 102 and a level of financial activity of $2.5 million, at the end of 1985/86 the number of staff had risen to 207 and the level of financial activity to $10.1 million. This expansion has involved not only the physical changes mentioned above, but also the development of professional curatorial, conservationist and historical activities, together with added emphasis on extended services to groups and individuals including students.

2.9 At present the Council consists of twelve members, there being one vacancy. The present Chairman was elected by her colleagues on 8 August 1985 and the present Director was appointed on 25 November 1982 for a term of five years.
Chapter 3
BACKGROUND TO THE INQUIRY

3.1 The Inquiry had its genesis in the Minister's concern about the quality and reliability of advice he was receiving from the Director, and in some cases from the Council through the Chairman. Some of these matters involve information from the Minister to the Parliament and he was particularly concerned that his should be accurate.

3.2 The series of events commenced with a letter to the Canberra Times on 8 October 1985 by Mr J. R. Heaton, a former curator, who alleged, among other things, that the top management of the Memorial had allowed staff morale to fall to a critically low level, as demonstrated by a rapid staff turnover. Events came to a head with an item in an internal bulletin about a function at the Memorial linked with public criticism by the Opposition spokesman of the Minister over that event, and linked also with the circumstances in which that spokesman came to possess related documents. The matter became public with the statement presented to Senate Estimates Committee F by the Minister on 18 September 1986 about the circumstances in which he had been obliged to have a senior officer of his department undertake an inquiry to settle any allegation of impropriety or less than prudent or efficient administration.

3.3 Over the period from October 1985 to September 1986, the Minister had expressed his concern to the Chairman and also to the Director about particular matters. As early as the Heaton letter event, he had sought advice from the Chairman about a suitable form of management review in the context of possible management and staff morale problems. That issue became interwoven with a Council request for the Minister to endorse a proposed reorganisation of the top structure of the staff; with the Minister's wish to see more cost-effective operations within the Memorial in response to a general government policy objective; with amendments to the AWM Act proposed by Council to change the designation of the position of Director and to upgrade certain fund limits at which the Minister's approval is required; with the Minister's own proposed amendments to the Act to specify a power to the Minister to give directions and to request information, and to have the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs appointed to the Memorial's Council.

3.4 The record of exchanges shows the Council as slow to respond, due in part to the schedule for meetings in February, May, and August of 1986. It appears also that the Council was apprehensive about possible undue involvement of the Minister of the day in the conduct of Memorial affairs. The Minister continued to press his concerns.

3.5 Underlying these exchanges were largely anonymous representations to the Minister about particular events involving actions of the Director and about inadequate communication and poor morale among groups of professional officers in the Memorial.

3.6 On 15 August 1986, the Minister directed a senior officer of his department, Mr G. O'Connor, to investigate certain allegations relating to competence and propriety in the administration of the Memorial; circumstances of the compilation of part of the staff bulletin and a leak of material and information to the Shadow Minister about a ceremony at the Memorial on the occasion of the proclamation of the Veterans Entitlements Act; and the provision of advice to the Minister. The Director had agreed to these arrangements and offered his co-operation and the Chairman was informed.

3.7 Previously, on 13 June 1986, the Director had instructed an officer of his Secretariat, Ms K. Rush, to make a comprehensive review of all Council and Committee resolutions since the passage of the 1980 Act, with particular attention to the years 1983-86; and to review all finance matters, particularly the operations of the bookshop. In issuing the instruction the Director noted the Council's consideration of the Minister's suggestion for a review of the Memorial's organisation and its legislation, and stated that he himself had been the victim of malicious innuendos as to his management of the Memorial and his personal conduct.

3.8 At that time, the Director was hoping to use the results of Ms Rush's investigations to report to the scheduled August meeting of Council. However, subsequently the Rush inquiries were subsumed into an investigation which the Director commissioned from the internal auditors of the Memorial, Arthur Young, on 1 August to confirm that Council decisions and directions had been carried out, with particular reference to expenditure from the Fund. The results of the investigation was also intended to be available to the August Council meeting, but it was not able to be completed until 18 September.
3.9 Mr O'Connor presented an interim report on 21 August and copies were made available to Council members for their meeting on 22 August which the Minister attended. No formal action was taken then.

3.10 A special Council meeting on 8 September considered the interim O'Connor report, together with a written response from the Director, and determined that there was no prima facie case of misbehaviour against the Director with respect to that inquiry. It appointed an executive committee to act forthwith in examining aspects of the Memorial administration which Council believed required urgent examination. At a further Council meeting on 24 September, the executive committee was disbanded against the background of further exchanges with the Minister and of a decision then to have an independent inquiry conducted by a person acceptable to the Minister and to Council and with Terms of Reference endorsed by them.
3.11 At a meeting of Council on 1 October, with the Minister present, my Inquiry was commissioned and its Terms of Reference settled. The Director has been on leave throughout the inquiry.
Chapter 4
EXAMINATION OF MATTERS CONCERNING ADMINISTRATION OF THE MEMORIAL IN ITS AFFAIRS

4.1 In this Chapter I address the various matters referred to me, including the contents of the other reports mentioned in the Terms of Reference. This account constitutes a summary of evidence and information.
Matters Referred By The Minister
Item 1: Acquisition of Warehouse
Matters for Consideration
Circumstances relating to the preparation by the AWM of a proposal to Cabinet for acquisition of warehouse.
The steps taken by the AWM to ensure that the Fyshwick site was suitable in terms of access, security, size, price and lack of encumbrance.
The lack of reference in material provided to the Minister or Cabinet regarding the continued existence of a sublease on the warehouse beyond the date of proposed acquisition.
Action by the AWM to secure tenure of the warehouse after Cabinet's approval of its acquisition became known to the AWM.
The response to the Minister's request for information subsequent to discovery of the difficulties with the Fyshwick proposal.
Background

4.3 On 8 February 1985 the Director forwarded to the Minister a New Policy Proposal (NPP) for the purchase of a warehouse in Fyshwick. The purchase price was $1.32 million. The proposal mentioned that acquisition of the warehouse would accommodate the Memorial's warehousing needs until the turn of the century.

4.4 At the time the proposal was developed, the AWM had a five-year lease over 1300 square metres of the warehouse. That lease was due to expire on 30 June 1986. The remainder of the warehouse (2230 square metres) was being leased by the Indoor Cricket Association (ICA) and that lease from 1 August 1984 for five years with a further five-year option.

4.5 The first reference in AWM records to the proposed purchase is a minute dated 10 January 1985 from the then Buildings Project Officer to the Director. (AWM records show that the Director was on leave at that time and that Dr McKernan was acting as Director. Dr McKernan has stated that this recollection is that although the Director was on leave, he continued to work from home on this particular matter in consultation with the Buildings Project Officer.) In his 10 January minute the Buildings Project Officer mentioned that he had spoken to the owner of the warehouse who had confirmed that it was for sale at $1.1 million. It is not clear how that figure increased to $1.32 million when the New Policy Proposal was put forward just over a month later, although the then Assistant Director, Resources Management, who was ultimately asked to prepare the New Policy Proposal, stated during a discussion with Mr O'Connor in September 1986 that his overriding instruction was a clear direction from the Director that the AWM was proceeding to buy the Fyshwick facility for $1.32 million.
4.6 Cabinet approved the New Policy Proposal on 13 May 1985 and the records show that the Director became aware of the Cabinet decision during the first week of June 1985.

4.7 In a note for file dated 20 August 1985, the Office manager has recorded that the previous day the owner of the Fyshwick building had `confirmed that the Indoor Cricket Area (ICA) lease at Fyshwick was renewed for a period of five years from September 1984'.

4.8 On 30 October 1985, the Director advised the Minister that the Fyshwick building was no longer suitable for purchase `as a further five-year sublease has been let for the the other half of the building'. The Director's minute went on to say that NCDC had identified a suitable block of land close to the Mitchell Annexe on which a warehouse of 3000 square metres could be built within the approved funds of $1.32 million.

4.9 On 7 November 1985, the Minister gave approval to proceed with the Mitchell building on the condition that: the cost (including the Project Manager's fee) did not exceed $1.32 million; there was no forward financial obligation carried into 1986-87; and the Memorial worked in close co-operation with the Departments of Veterans' Affairs and Finance. In that minute the Minister also asked the Director to let him know when the `new' sublease for the Fyshwick warehouse was let; whether negotiations for purchase were begun immediately following Cabinet's approval; and whether the new circumstances had arisen because of a failure to move promptly or because of a change of heart either by the vendors or the Memorial. The Minister also made the point that the advice which had been given to him and Cabinet was that the need for storage was both urgent and unavoidable. He said that the handover date of June 1986 (for the Mitchell building) did not appear to fit squarely with the case for urgency which had previously been put forward, and sought the Director's comments on this point.

4.10 When responding to the Minister on 13 November 1985, the Director said that approval for the purchase was received in a letter dated 21 August 1985 from the Department of Veterans' Affairs and negotiations with the vendors had been initiated the previous week, anticipating formal advice of the allocation of funds. The Director's minute went on to say that during this period the owner also advised that under the terms of an existing sublease, the lessee of the half of the building not occupied by the Memorial was entitled to remain in occupancy even if the building was to be sold; he (the Director) said that this effectively meant that the warehouse could no longer meet the Memorial's requirements.

4.11 On 29 November 1985, Council was given the following advice: `. . . . Just prior to receipt of advice of approval of the proposal (to purchase the warehouse) the owner advised that he had renewed a five-year sublease of the other portion of the building and the sublease would continue in the event of the Memorial making the purchase. As this was unsatisfactory, efforts were made to locate another suitable building and the possibility of the Memorial constructing a new building was also `explored'.

4.12 It is of interest that the owner of the Fyshwick warehouse recently informed this Inquiry that the purchase price for the building was always $1.5 million. He said that he had at no stage put a price of $1.1 million on the building and that while there may have been some discussion about a figure of $1.32 million, he had never at any stage agreed to sell at that price. He also said that it was his clear understanding that all AWM staff with whom he discussed the matter were well aware that the ICA were sub-leasing part of the building.
Comment

4.13 On the basis of the information available (working papers concerning the development of the proposal to purchase the warehouse could not be located in the AWM) this matter appears to have been handled very badly. There is no evidence that a proper assessment of the suitability of the Fyshwick warehouse was ever undertaken by the AWM or by any other agency acting on their behalf (although it is noted that the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services did offer to assist in this regard); there is no indication of how the purchase price of $1.32 million was determined-indeed, the only figure mentioned in AWM records up until the time the New Policy Proposal was put forward was $1.1 million; and despite the fact that it was evident that a substantial part of the warehouse was being used by the Indoor Cricket Association (ICA), there appears to have been no thought given to the possibility that the ICA may have had a continuing sub-lease on the area that they were using.

4.14 The Director's minute of 30 October 1985 to the Minister informing him that the AWM did not want to proceed with the purchase of the Fyshwick warehouse was both untimely and misleading. The Director was aware by at least 19 August 1985 that there was an encumbrance on the building and given that Cabinet had approved the purchase of it in May 1985, it would seem that, even as a matter of courtesy, the Minister, who had been responsible for putting the proposal to Cabinet, should have been informed as soon as the changed circumstances became known. When the Minister was informed on 30 October 1985, the advice conveyed to him was that `. . . the building is no longer suitable for purchase as a further five-year sublease has been let for the other half of the building'. The Minister interpreted this as meaning that a new sub-lease had recently been entered into by the owner. This interpretation would seem reasonable by any standard. It would also seem reasonable to conclude in retrospect that the words used by the Director were misleading.

4.15 When the Minister sought further information from the Director on 7 November 1985, the response that he received just under a week later did not really answer the questions which he had asked. In his response the Director implied that the delay in commencing negotiations for the purchase was attributable to the fact that approval for the purchase was not received until 21 August 1985. While it is correct that formal written advice was not received until that date, the fact remained that the Director had been aware of the approval in early June and AWM staff could reasonably have been expected to commence work on the purchase, particularly given the purported degree of urgency involved. The Director's response to the Minister did not in any way address the Minister's questions concerning the timing of what the Minister referred to as the `new' sublease.

4.16 When responding to questions put to him during the course of this Inquiry, the Director mentioned that he was on leave in January 1985 when the New Policy Proposals were produced by the acting Director. He pointed out that the proposal forwarded to the Minister on 8 February 1985 was prepared by the then Buildings Project Officer and that he (the Director) did not recall any discussion with that person concerning the lease of that proportion of the Fyshwick premises which was not occupied by the Memorial. He also said that he did not know how the Buildings Project Officer had arrived at the price of $1.32 million. Given that the Director signed the New Policy Proposal on 8 February 1985 and that he is the chief executive officer of the AWM, it is considered that he should have made it his business to be better informed about a matter which was being put to Cabinet and which involved substantial expenditure.

4.17 The Director has also confirmed to this Inquiry that neither he nor Memorial staff were aware of the existence of the Indoor Cricket Association lease. Again, common sense suggests that given the ICA's occupancy of almost two-thirds of the warehouse, the possibility of a continuing sublease should have been considered.

4.18 When asked why he did not notify the Minister in August that it had become clear that a sublease existed, the Director said that there would have been little point in taking the matter up with the Minister or Council at that time as no firm alternative had yet emerged and it was not yet possible to recommend a definite course of action. This rationale is difficult to understand.

4.19 The building of the Mitchell warehouse was, in the final analysis, a better outcome from the Memorial's point of view than what might have been achieved at Fyshwick. However, the fact remains that the proposed Fyshwick purchase was very poorly handled by the AWM. As chief executive officer of the Memorial and sponsor of the New Policy Proposal, the Director must accept ultimate responsibility for this. For the reasons mentioned above, it is considered that the Minister was not properly informed about this particular matter and there seems little doubt that the responsibility for this also rests with the Director.
Item 2: Parliamentary Question-The Eastern Staircase
Matters for Consideration
4.20 The advice given to the Minister to enable him to respond to the Parliamentary Question regarding the Memorial's eastern staircase and the circumstances leading to provision of that advice.
Background
4.21 On 11 February 1986 Mr Tim Fischer, Shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, asked the following Questions on Notice in the House of Representatives (PQ 3126):
1. What total exhibition space is it anticipated will be available in the Australian War Memorial at 1 June 1986?
2. What was the cost of providing safe staircases to facilitate access to and operation of the exhibition areas?
3. Has initial design work caused increased costs; if so, will the War Memorial charge the National Capital Development Commission for the additional costs incurred?

4.22 On 25 February 1986, the Director provided a draft response in which he said, inter alia, that the cost of the new staircases was not available to the Memorial as they formed a part of the overall refurbishment program which was the responsibility of the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC).

4.23 On 14 March 1986 the Minister wrote to the Director seeking further information including the cost of the staircases as determined by the NCDC and particulars of the circumstances in which the eastern staircases had been assessed as being unsafe. The Minister also sought an explanation of why it was not intended to charge NCDC if, as he had inferred from the Director's earlier draft responses, the increased costs were as a result of faulty work by the Commission. Given that the Shadow Minister's request related to the operation of the NCDC and the Department of Housing and Construction, the Minister also sought an assurance that any suggested reply had been prepared in consultation with and had the agreement of these organisations.

4.24 When responding to the Minister on 8 April 1986, the Director explained that there had been an almost complete breakdown in communications between the AWM and the NCDC. He said that the relations had become progressively worse throughout the period of the AWM refurbishment program. He pointed out that it was the Memorial's view that the NCDC did not properly assess the requirements for the staircase while the NCDC claimed that the structure satisfied the brief received. In his minute the Director said that it would seem inappropriate for one government body to action to recover funds from another government body and that a demand for reimbursement in respect of the stairs would rekindle the dispute and endanger the rapport which has developed since the appointment of the new NCDC Commissioner. In answer to the Minister's question about assessment of the safety of the staircase, the Director said that this judgment had been made by the Council following an inspection of the area after its meeting of 12 November 1984. When referring to the revised response to the Parliamentary Question (which was attached to his minute and which included the estimated cost of the staircases) the Director said: `The answer has been prepared in consultation with the NCDC and the Regional Office of the Department of Housing and Construction.'

4.25 On 17 April 1986, the Minister again wrote to the Director expressing concern about the information being provided to him in relation to the Parliamentary Question. He enclosed with his minute a revised draft response and asked the Director to let him know as a matter of urgency whether or not the redraft was factual and accurate in every detail. The Minister also asked the Director to confirm that NCDC agreed with the text or a revised version of it. He stressed that it would not be sufficient to say that that organisation had been consulted.

4.26 When responding to the Minister on 2 May 1986, the Director returned a slightly modified redraft which he advised had been provided to NCDC for comment. He said that `the Commission again endorses the reply'.
4.27 The answer to the Parliamentary Question was published on 20 May 1986.
Comment

4.28 The first draft response to this Parliamentary Question was deficient in several ways: having answered the question in relation to total available exhibition space, it provided further figures which did not add up to the total specified; it did not answer the question concerning cost, even though, as subsequent events showed, that information was available from the NCDC; and it did not answer, in a direct way, the question concerning poor initial design work.

4.29 The second draft response was said to have been prepared in consultation with NCDC and the Regional Office of the Department of Housing and Construction. Despite a specific request from the Minister for an assurance that the reply had also been agreed to by those organisations, no such assurance was given. Subsequent advice given to this Inquiry by the AWM Administrator has confirmed that no agreement was in fact reached between the AWM and the NCDC in relation to that draft. In his reply to a specific question on this point, the Director has informed the Inquiry that `the Administrator personally cleared the draft minute with NCDC before dispatch to the Minister. (The Administrator) submitted two drafts to (NCDC) and the final approved draft was submitted to the Minister.' The Administrator has confirmed that he submitted two drafts to the NCDC one of which was finally `endorsed' by the Commission, but has stated that this was not until after the Minister had sent his third query to the Director which was accompanied by the draft prepared in the Minister's Office.

4.30 The third draft response which, as mentioned above, was prepared in the Minister's office, was amended and returned to the Minister with a covering minute which stated, inter alia, that `. . . The Commission again endorses the reply'. Since the NCDC had not agreed to any previous draft response, it is not clear what this advance was intended to convey.

4.31 The records relating to this matter show that the Minister had a good deal of difficulty obtaining clearly-worded and factually complete information with which to respond to this Parliamentary Question. In the circumstances, it would have to be said that the Director's advice in relation to this matter was both inadequate and misleading.
Item 3: The Eastern Staircase and NCDC
Matters for Consideration

4.32 The circumstances relating to the original approval of the eastern staircase, the alteration in plans for the staircase, the need for the alterations, the additional cost involved in these alterations (including the demolition and reconstruction) and the NCDC's views on the AWM's involvement in this and other construction projects.
Background

4.33 An examination of AWM and NCDC records indicates that the origins of the dispute concerning the construction of the eastern staircase can be traced back to a meeting held on 3 August 1983 between NCDC and AWM officials, the Project Manager and the Design Consultant. The minutes of that meeting indicate the following agreement regarding the eastern staircase: `. . . BSM (the designer consultants) are documenting Stair 1-design to be simpler than Stair 2.' These minutes were endorsed by the AWM's then Building Project Co-ordinator in a letter to the NCDC dated 10 August 1983.
4.34 A memorandum from the NCDC dated 17 August 1984 following the emergence of the dispute over the eastern staircase, states that:

`it was agreed at that meeting (i.e. the meeting of 3 August 1983) that the stair need not be as wide as the western stair and that the design should be simpler. At that stage it appeared to be the Memorial's intention that the stair would serve essentially as a fire escape rather than as a general means of circulation.'

4.35 NCDC has indicated that a complete set of working drawings, which included details of the eastern staircase, were delivered to the AWM with a covering letter dated 14 October 1983. It appears from annotations to the AWM copy of the NCDC letter that drawings enclosed with the letter were received and examined by the AWM's Building Project Co-ordinator. An internal NCDC minute dated 23 August 1984 confirms that NCDC were never provided with any comments from the AWM concerning any inadequacies in the set of drawings which they sent to the Memorial on 14 October 1983.

4.36 During an interview with Mr O'Connor on 22 September 1986 the former AWM Building Project Co-ordinator said that the Director had decided that the eastern staircase would be a fire exit only. He (the Building Project Co-ordinator) said that he had received a clear direction from the Director regarding the changes to the eastern staircase.

4.37 It would seem that construction of the eastern staircase took place in the first part of 1984. It was on 9 May 1984 that the AWM indicated to NCDC that requirements for the eastern staircase had changed and that a considerably wider staircase would be required which would involve demolishing the newly built staircase.

4.38 Following the AWM's letter of 9 May to NCDC seeking changes to the staircase, NCDC arranged for preparation of a revised design. While the AWM supported this new design, it would seem that when it reached the Chief Architect at NCDC he voiced strong objections to the proposal. Senior management within the NCDC were also concerned about the prospect of demolishing the existing staircase and constructing another before the completion date for stage 1. They were also concerned that such additional work could not be accommodated within the budget for the building project.

4.39 In correspondence from August 1984 onwards, NCDC indicated that it intended to complete the eastern staircase and that any redesign of the area would need to be considered as a separate project. The NCDC were of the view that the staircase should be evaluated following a period of use by the public before any alterations were made to it.

4.40 In a letter to the NCDC dated 13 November 1984 the AWM Building Project Co-ordinator advised that the Council of the AWM had directed that the stairs be demolished and rebuilt under Memorial control. It was stated in that letter that in view of the anticipated crowds during the Christmas period the Council considered that this action was necessary in the interest of public safety. Minutes of the Gallery Committee meeting of 26 February 1985 indicated that NCDC relinquished the task and that the Department of Housing and Construction had undertaken to rebuild the staircase at a cost of $36,000. Subsequent records show that the total cost paid by the AWM to the Department of Housing and Construction was $46,000.

4.41 It is of note that the NCDC Commissioner wrote to the then Chairman of the AWM Council on 22 November 1984 regarding the dispute over the eastern staircase and the Council's decision to demolish the stairs. The Commissioner also mentioned his concern about other instances of waste which he believed had occurred because of changes requested by the Director. He said that additions and alterations to the works had caused the overall cost to increase from an initial figure of $1.87 million to $2.85 million and that of the roughly $1.0 million increase, about $450,000 had resulted from additions and alterations asked for by the Director. When commenting on the staircase, the Commissioner said that he found it hard to see how the Memorial Council could justify such a waste of public money without any attempt to ascertain in practice whether or not the stairs would cope with pedestrian traffic. He said that as far as the Commission was aware, no evidence had been provided by the Director or his staff, beyond that of mere contention, to show why the stairs were considered to be a threat to public safety. When responding to the Commissioner the then Chairman addressed the question of the overall number of changes which had been requested by the AWM and said that those changes had been made to ensure that the Memorial provides substantially increased facilities for the public, not only in terms of visitor comfort and safety, but also in the Memorial's approach to exhibitions and exhibition technique. On the question of the eastern staircase he referred to a letter which he had sent to the Commissioner earlier that month. In that letter the Chairman said that `. . . In terms of public safety and convenience, the stairs provided on the eastern side are inadequate. Comparisons between original and existing stair widths have previously been made together with our need for adequate communicating links between floor levels. These issues are of such importance that the stairs, in the present configuration, cannot be accepted.'
Comment

4.42 From the information available to this Inquiry, it would seem that the decision that the eastern staircase be built as a fire exit rather than as a main public thoroughfare was agreed to by the then Building Project Co-ordinator during discussions with NCDC staff in August 1983. As noted above, he has subsequently stated that the Director decided that the eastern staircase would be a fire exit only. He has also stated that he was present with the Director at the eastern staircase soon after its completion when a visitor to the Memorial demonstrated that he was able to hold the railings of both sides of the staircase at once. He said that it was at this point that the Director changed his position as to the suitability of the stairs.

4.43 AWM records show that the Memorial subsequently endorsed in writing the changes which were agreed to during the 3 August 1983 meeting with NCDC staff and that plans which were subsequently sent by NCDC to the AWM were not in any way questioned. In view of this, the Director's comment in a letter dated 1 February 1985 to the then Chairman that `the Memorial had neither the staff nor reason to examine just one of the hundreds of drawings received' would seem unsatisfactory. Whether the assertion by the former Building Project Co-ordinator that the decision to change the stairs was made by the Director is correct or not, there is no doubt that the AWM did request and endorse the initial changes to the eastern staircase and, as such, responsibility for the additional costs which were subsequently incurred rests with the management of the AWM.
Item 4: AWM Top Structure
Matters for Consideration
4.44 The advice provided to the Minister regarding the PSB's attitude to the proposal, raised in November 1985, to upgrade the AWM's management structure.
Background

4.45 On 8 November 1985 the Chairman wrote to the Minister seeking his endorsement of a proposed revised top structure for the AWM. The Chairman's minute contained the following statement: `The case for upgrading the Assistant Director Resources Management has been well made in the report and subsequent correspondence to the Public Service Board. A copy of the relevant correspondence is attached.' A copy of the Director's letter to the Board of 29 August 1985 seeking agreement to the revised structure was included in the attachments. That particular letter focused on the question of the proposed reclassification of the Assistant Director Resources Management from Level 1 to Level 2. However, what was not attached, was earlier correspondence from the Board to the Director (dated 5 August 1985) in which the Board said it `. . . would have some difficulty in supporting reclassification of the Resources Management position to Level 2'.

4.46 On 13 March 1986 the Chairman again wrote to the Minister seeking his urgent consideration of the proposed revised top structure. That correspondence made no mention of the fact that on 19 November 1985, in response to the Director's letter of 29 August 1985, the Board had said `. . . we remain unconvinced that the position would stand up to L2' and `. . . these concerns lead us to conclude we cannot endorse your proposal from that viewpoint'.

4.47 When asked to comment on these matters during this Inquiry, the Director said that he completely denied that the Chairman's minute of 8 November 1985 to the Minister had any intention of conveying a false impression. He said that with hindsight the Chairman could have mentioned the Board's opposition to one element of the Memorial's proposal, but pointed out that the very purpose in writing to the Minister was to gain his support based on the Memorial's case so that the Board and the Department of Finance could be favourably influenced. The Director said that the Chairman's subsequent minute of 13 March 1986 was an attempt to get the Minister's support so that the Memorial's management might be improved.
Comment

4.48 As mentioned above, the Chairman's minute to the Minister of 8 November 1985 did not refer to the fact that the revised top structure proposal had not been agreed to by the Public Service Board. Given that the minute included a copy of the AWM submission to the Board, it might reasonably have been expected that it would also have included a copy of the Board's letter of 5 August 1985 to the AWM, or at least some reference to the fact that the Board had at that time expressed concern about aspects of the proposed new top structure.

4.49 AWM records show that the Chairman's minute of 8 November was prepared in draft form by the Director. The records also show that his covering note to the Chairman did not make it clear that the Board had already stated that it had some difficulty supporting the reclassification proposal. In subsequent correspondence with this Inquiry, however, the Director has stated that at the time of drafting the minute he did inform the Chairman of the terms of the Public Service Board's advice of 5 August 1985. He has also stated that he discussed `in depth' with the Chairman the actual choice of words used in the minute. He said that the views expressed were intended to convey to the Minister that the AWM had so far been unsuccessful in negotiations with the Board or Finance although it was believed that the Memorial's case was valid and logical. He mentioned that copies of the correspondence with the Board were attached to the Chairman's minute of 8 November 1985. He also said that he had recommended the precise terms of the Chairman's further minute to the Minister of 13 March 1986 and confirmed that at that time he had informed the Chairman of the Board's views as expressed in their letters of 5 August and 19 November 1985. The Chairman has subsequently confirmed that the Director did discuss with her the circumstances of the Public Service Board's attitude on each occasion.

4.50 It is considered that the advice which was conveyed to the Minister in the Chairman's minute of 8 November was selective and, as a consequence, misleading. It did not mention that the Public Service Board had already expressed concerns about reclassification of the Resources Management position; it did not (according to the Minister's Office and contrary to the Director's assertion) have attached to it a copy of the Board's letter of 5 August 1985; and it conveyed the impression, by not including this information, that the Board endorsed the proposal.
4.51 The Chairman's letter of 15 March 1986 to the Minister is also selective in that it makes no reference to the Board's further correspondence of 19 November 1985.
4.52 On the basis of the information made available to this Inquiry the Minister would have good reason to believe that he was given inadequate and misleading information in relation to this matter.
Item 5: The 1984/85 Annual Report
Matters for Consideration
4.53 The advice provided to the Minister regarding the delay in submitting the AWM's 1984/85 Annual Report.
Background

4.54 Under the Acts Interpretation Act the AWM is required to submit its Annual Report to the Minister within six months of the end of the period to which the Report refers. The Report must include the audited statements of accounts for the AWM. The Memorial's 1984/85 Annual Report was due for presentation to the Minister on 31 December 1985.

4.55 On 22 November 1985 the Director wrote to the Minister seeking his approval for an extension of the period allowed for submission of the Report. In that minute, the Director conveyed the following advice to the Minister: `It is a requirement of the Australian War Memorial Act 1980 that the financial statements be submitted to the Auditor-General before they are submitted to the Minister. Most statutory authorities have the same provisions and as such the Auditor-General must certify financial statements for over 100 statutory authorities. It therefore takes some time to obtain the necessary certification and this inevitably causes delays in tabling the annual report.' The Director also mentioned that the financial statements had been completed by 30 August 1985 and forwarded to the Auditor-General.

4.56 When responding to the Director's minute on 12 December 1985, the Minister said that while on the face of it he was prepared to approve an extension of time, before doing so he wanted to raise with the Director some matters which were of concern to him, particularly as the request for an extension of time would need to be tabled in Parliament. The Minister said that the clear inference which he had drawn from the Director's minute of 22 November was that the delay in certifying the Memorial's financial statements was attributable to the Auditor-General. He made it clear that the Director's reference to the Auditor-General's workload in having to give certification to over 100 statutory authorities, and to the fact that delays inevitably occurred, had led him to this conclusion. He pointed out, however, that he had since learnt that the financial statements were not completed by 30 August 1985 (although he acknowledged that statements may have been sent to the Auditor-General at the end of August) and that revisions had to be sought by the Auditor-General. He said that he understood that those revisions had resulted in a final draft being submitted by the AWM in the middle of November.

The Minister asked for urgent advice from the Director about these matters and said that he would be prepared to consider a request for an extension if he could be assured that the Director's advice accurately reflected the true position.

4.57 In a minute which reached the Minister's office on 23 December 1985, the Director said that in drawing the Minister's attention to the need for the Auditor-General to certify the Memorial's financial statements, it was not intended that the Auditor-General be accorded any blame. He said it was intended to highlight the fact that the requirement for the financial statements to be audited prior to their submission to the Minister inevitably caused delays in producing the Annual Report. He said that in the course of the audit following submission of the financial statements, some queries were raised by the Auditor-General's office and subsequent amendments were made to the statements. He assured the Minister that every effort had been made by the AWM to ensure that the Annual Report was produced within the statutory period.

4.58 AWM records show that while the financial statements were submitted to the Auditor-General on 30 August 1985, further draft statements were also submitted on 11 and 28 October and 11 November before a final draft was submitted on 18 November and certified by the Auditor-General on 29 November 1985.
4.59 The AWM's 1984/85 Annual Report was ultimately delivered to the Minister's office on 5 February 1986.
Comment
4.60 The point at issue in relation to the 1984/85 Annual Report is whether or not the Director provided the Minister with inadequate or misleading information in relation to this matter.

4.61 In response to questions put to him during the course of this Inquiry, the Director said that he had no reason to believe that the contents of the minute of 22 November 1985 were anything other than factual or correct. He said that the request for an extension of time should have been a straightforward administrative matter which could have reasonably been left to the acting Executive Officer. He mentioned that similar requests for such an extension of time had been made in previous years. (It is noted that the 1983/84 Annual Report was also delayed.) He also pointed out that the Commonwealth Auditors had not raised all their queries in the first instance and referred to an attachment (recently signed by the person who was acting Finance Manager at the time) in which it is mentioned that the matters referred to by the Auditor-General were raised separately and on different occasions over a period of several weeks by different members of the Auditor-General's office.

4.62 Despite the Director's observations about the difficulties encountered with the Auditor-General's office between 30 August and 29 November 1985, the fact remains that the wording of his minute to the Minister of 22 November 1985 clearly implied that the delays were attributable to the Auditor-General. Subsequent inquiries have revealed that the draft was prepared in good faith by staff of the AWM Secretariat and that it was signed without amendment by the Director. While the wording may have been inadvertent it nevertheless resulted in the Minister concluding that the cause of the delay was the Auditor-General's office rather than the AWM. The Minister's assertion therefore that he was given inadequate and misleading advice is not unreasonable.
Item 6: The Change in the AWM's Bankers
Matters for Consideration

4.63 The circumstances surrounding the change in the AWM's bank from Commonwealth to Westpac, including Council involvement in that decision and the considerations taken into account in making it; whether advice to the then Minister in respect to an answer to the Parliamentary Question on Notice from Mrs R. Kelly was accurate.
Background

4.64 The relevant events occurred towards the middle of 1983 when the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment was responsible for the War Memorial. On 13 April 1983 by minute the Director requested the Minister to seek approval of the Treasurer for Westpac Banking Corporation to be deemed to be an `approved Bank within Section 63 (j) of the Audit Act in respect of the Australian War Memorial'. The Director stated as reasons that confusion by the Bank between the two accounts had caused administrative problems, and investment advice from the CTB resulted in less than optimum returns from investment funds. The Bank referred to was the AWM's existing bank, the Commonwealth Trading Bank.
4.65 That particular matter was finally settled on 12 December 1983 when the Minister assisting the Treasurer approved the Westpac Banking Corporation as requested.

4.66 Formal action to transfer AWM bank accounts to Westpac commenced on 1 June 1983 when the Director told his senior administrators that following discussion with the local Manager of Westpac he intended to transfer the bank accounts to them. He said in his minute, `I do not intend to go to Council with this until after the transfer is made when I will seek ratification.' The following day the Assistant Director, Resources Management responded with a detailed minute which, among other things, challenged the statement that the Commonwealth Trading Bank had not provided adequate service, reminded the Director of earlier advice that there were four reasonable alternative Banks including the Commonwealth and Westpac, and suggested that each should have been given the opportunity to bid for the business. There was a recommendation for the matter to be raised at an approaching meeting of the Executive Committee. There is no indication on the file of consideration of that minute.

4.67 Subsequently on 14 June 1983, the Manager of the local Westpac Branch wrote to the Director indicating the services they could make available. The minutes of an Executive Committee of Council meeting on 16 June 1983 state, `The Director informed the Committee that the Memorial was changing its bank accounts from the Commonwealth Trading Bank to the Westpac Corporation. The Committee noticed this action.'

4.68 There is a letter of 1 July 1983 from the Manager of the Commonwealth Bank which had carried the business, expressing his disappointment at the decision and indicating a willingness to continue to quote from AWM investment needs.

4.69 On 19 October 1983 Mrs R. Kelly. M.P. asked the Minister a Question on Notice about the transfer of the Memorial's bank accounts to Westpac and in particular for reasons as to the change, information about the investigation made of the services of the various banks, as to how many banks were invited to tender, and the reasons for the selection of Westpac.

4.70 On 28 October 1983, advice went from the Memorial to the Minister on a suggested reply. The draft reply included statements that `discussions were held with trading banks concerning their services' and `the facilities offered by Westpac were considered to be most advantageous to the War Memorial'. On 8 December 1983 the Minister replied to the Question (No. 636 House of Representatives Hansard page 3647). The reply included the words that the transfer to Westpac had been made `. . . . following discussions with several banks concerning their services, because its facilities were considered to be most advantageous to the War Memorial. Tenders were not invited.'
4.71 There is no record of any approach to any banks other than Westpac or of any comparative assessment of the services available from them.
Comment

4.72 The Inquiry has asked questions of the Director to ascertain why the change was made, why he had not acted on the advice of the Assistant Director or recorded his reasons for not doing so, and about the circumstances in which he or some member of his staff had approached the banks, which presumably was the basis for the advice given to the Minister about the reply to the answer to the Parliamentary Question.

4.73 In reply the Director has linked the decision to transfer the bank accounts to dissatisfaction with the circumstances in which urgent action had to be taken about reinvestment of a sum of money from the AWM investment portfolio which was lodged with the Commonwealth Bank. He said he was not familiar with the Parliamentary Question referred to, but identified Branch names and Managers' names for local branches of each of the four banks with which he had had discussions. The Inquiry felt obliged to check this statement in respect of the three banks other than Westpac, and made oral enquiries of two of the three people nominated, each of whom is now retired, and also of the managers in succession of each of the three people. Each reported no record or recollection. This outcome was reported to the Director together with the fact that there appeared to be no reply to the Assistant Director's advice of 2 June 1983. The Director was then asked to respond to the propositions that in respect of this matter:
(a) You were deficient in carrying out your duties by not responding to specific advice from a senior officer or not recording the action you took following that advice;
(b) you gave false information about approaches to the four banks to the Executive Committee; and

(c) you gave the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment false information on the particular question of consultation with the banks which he subsequently related to Mrs Kelly and the Parliament in his written reply to the question on notice.

4.74 His answer was that his listing of the names of the Bank Managers in an earlier written answer was not intended to imply that he had had discussions with those individuals, rather he had personally visited the four major banks deliberately not identifying himself, and discussed with counter staff investments and bank charges and counter services. He regretted his misleading answer to the Inquiry, referred to the pressures of current circumstances, and was glad of the opportunity of correcting this answer. His answers to the propositions were:

(a) That he had little confidence in the Assistant Director and had taken the matter out of his inefficient hands and any reply to his minute would have been verbal. Action taken was documented in the papers of the Executive Committee and this was after approval by the Committee.
(b) He did not give false information about the approaches to the four banks, which were as set out in his reply.
(c) He did not give false information to the then Minister as there had been discussions with the banks in accordance with the sequence of events he had set out.
4.75 The Inquiry's examination of this matter shows that the propositions it put to the Director have been substantiated.
(Note the reference in 4.74 (c) should have been to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment.)
Item 7: Ordering and Delivery of Commemorative Port
Matters for Consideration

4.76 The circumstances surrounding the ordering and delivery to the Memorial of bottles of commemorative port, including action decided on by the Council when the matter was brought to attention and how that action has been represented by the Director: why a letter to Lieutenant-Colonel McCann from the Director is apparently not on AWM files and the circumstances in which that letter was written.
Background

4.77 Over the period end 1984 to the beginning of 1985 discussions took place between members of the AWM staff, including the Director, and a Canberra firm of wholesale wine merchants about the sale of specially labelled commemorative port bottles in the AWM shop. During January 1985 six cases were delivered to the shop out of a total consignment of one pallet (64 cases) ordered by the merchants.

4.78 There were protracted exchanges between the wine merchants and the Memorial over such matters as the approval of the reproduction of the specially designed label, the nature of packaging, the size of the order and whether there had in fact been an order. There was also uncertainty about the legal capacity of the Memorial to sell liquor on its premises. In the course of these events the Director declined to accept delivery of any port and returned the six cases.

4.79 Finally Council took action at a meeting on 26 April 1985. It admonished the Director over the difficulties which had arisen while acknowledging the intention of the Director and certain staff to increase Memorial funds. Council decided to handle the matter itself from then on with a view to a settlement with the wine merchants.

4.80 On 29 August 1985 a cheque for $2250.67 was sent to the wine merchants with a letter from the new Chairman in settlement of the dispute without prejudice. That letter went under cover of a letter of 3 September 1985 from the Director, in a personal vein, to Lt. Col. McCann, a director of the company. In response to the Inquiry, the Director has described that letter as a demi-official one to thank Lt. Col. McCann for providing information which helped to prevent a possible legal problem for the Memorial. In fact the letter was also critical of the action taken by the Council under the previous Chairman.
Comment

4.81 This matter had a number of unsatisfactory features and was dealt with by Council. This Inquiry has not sought to pursue it further. It has noted elsewhere the Auditor-General's comment, in respect of this episode, that the AWM's practice of ordering goods without proper documentation contributed to the confusion. That general question is a matter for the administration to pursue.
Item 8: The Director's September 1985 Overseas Visit
Matters for Consideration

4.82 The Director's September 1985 overseas trip, including the advice provided to the Minister regarding the cost and/or itinerary of the trip, the Director's entitlements and his wife's entitlements.
Background

4.83 With the Minister's approval, the Director attended the 16th Annual Conference of the International Association of Transport Museums in Nuremburg, Western Germany, from 7 to 13 September 1985. His wife accompanied him at official expense. A draft itinerary and a cost estimate of $10,000 formed part of the material from the Director when the Minister's approval was sought in July.

4.84 Travel was arranged through National Australia Bank Travel, not through Qantas. The itinerary for the outward journey as put to the Minister was Sydney-Munich-Nuremburg, but the actual route taken was Melbourne-Hong Kong-Frankfurt-Nuremburg with a 50 hour stopover in Hong Kong. The actual cost for both the Director and his wife was in the vicinity of $20,000.
4.85 In response to the interim O'Connor report the Director stated, in answer to criticisms, that:
He and his wife were entitled to first class travel.
The travel clerk had chosen National Australia Bank Travel as offering the best package and had made the usual request for Qantas to be used as a carrier where feasible.
The variations to the itinerary reflect information on flight availability closer to the travel date and involved no extra cost.
The rest period in Hong Kong (50 hours compared to 24 hours) had not been excessive.

The cost covered both the Director and his wife whereas the sum of $10,000 mentioned to the Minister was intended to cover the Director only, his wife's travel was a separate proposal taken up later in the minutes to the Minister.
Some unauthorised payment for allowances had inadvertently been made to Mrs Flemming and a sum of $294.08 had been repaid.
Comment
4.86 The bookings should have been made through Qantas in order to comply with the Finance Directives which have been adopted for the AWM Council.

4.87 The changes to the itinerary and stopover time should have been reported to the Minister together with an explanation. This could have been done on a for information basis, particularly if the Director had no doubt about the interpretation of the cost figures.
4.88 No reasonable person could have been expected to interpret the minute to the Minister as indicating a total cost of $20,000.

4.89 The principal question is whether the Director and his wife were entitled to first class travel for an official visit. The experience and understanding of the Inquiry is that the Director would be entitled to the same class of travel and rate of travel allowance while overseas as a Senior Executive Service (SES) Level 4 officer which is his salary classification. The entitlement is to business class air travel.

4.90 The fact that approval of an overseas visit by the chief executive officer of a statutory authority has to be approved by the Minister and reported in advance to the Prime Minister, as is also the case for Departmental Secretaries, is not a ground for assuming that the chief executive officer's entitlement to class of travel overseas is the same as a Departmental Secretary, which is first class.

4.91 However investigation by the Inquiries has shown the position to be unclear and suggests that the lack of clarity is shared by a number of other chief executive officers of statutory authorities.

4.92 The Remuneration Tribunal has determined the salary and domestic and overseas travel allowance for the office of Director of the AWM at levels equivalent to SES. This determination does not extend to the question of the class of travel, which is a matter beyond the Tribunal's jurisdiction. Therefore the class of travel is a condition of employment which could be set within the provisions of the AWM Act, that is by the Executive Council. To the knowledge of the Inquiry no such determination has been made.

4.93 Advice from the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet is that there is likely to be a number of Authorities for which no such determination has been made. While there is a presumption that, in the absence of a formal determination, the SES level of business class for overseas air travel should apply, the situation is uncertain. The Department has told the Inquiry that attention is being given to appropriate steps to clarify the position.
4.94 In this situation the Inquiry accepts that it was not unreasonable for the Director and the AWM staff to assume that he and his wife were entitled to first class travel.
Item 9: V.E.A. Proclamation Ceremony/Staff Bulletin
Matters for Consideration
Circumstances under which `ministerial direction' reference was included in bulletin
the advice the Director initially gave to the Minister concerning his not being involved in the preparation of the bulletin
the delay in advising the Minister that the advice to the Minister was incorrect
circumstances under which Mr T. Fischer, MP, obtained a copy of the bulletin.
Background

4.96 The AWM staff bulletin of 21 May 1986 mentioned that `as a result of a Ministerial direction' the Department of Veterans' Affairs would be holding a small function in the Memorial's sculpture gallery on 22 May 1986 at which the Minister would introduce the new Veterans' Entitlement Bill which was due for proclamation that day. The function was to be attended by representatives of a number of veterans' welfare organisations.

4.97 During Question Time on 22 May 1986, Mr Tim Fischer, MP, asked a question without notice concerning the use of the AWM for what he referred to as `a political function'. He also asked whether the function was taking place as a result of an `absolute ministerial direction' (See H of R Hansard P. 3754). The same day, Mr Fischer issued a press release to which he attached a copy of the staff bulletin which had the words `Reverse Leak' and `With compliments, Tim Fischer M.P.' written across it. In an AAP interview that day, Mr Fischer is reported as having said that senior officials at the War Memorial had told him that they had been used and pressured by the Veterans' Affairs Minister into holding the function. (It is noted that in a radio interview on 24 September 1986 Mr Fischer is recorded as having said that he did not know where the leak had originated from and was not aware that it was from either senior or junior staff management).

4.98 On 29 May 1986 the Minister, when responding to a question without notice said, inter alia, that the Department (of Veterans' Affairs) had made the decision that the suitable place for the proclamation ceremony would be the AWM (see Senate Hansard, p. 2981).

4.99 On 30 July 1986, at the Minister's request, the Memorial's Public Relations Officer, Ms James, met with the Minister and his Senior Private Secretary. At that meeting Ms James informed the Minister that the words `Ministerial direction' had been included in the bulletin as a result of an instruction from the Director in the form of an annotation by him on a minute which she had written him on 13 May 1986. (It is noted that on 19 May 1986 Ms James also cleared the relevant wording for this part of the bulletin in writing with the Director). Ms James has confirmed that at no stage did she inform the Director of her meeting with the Minister and his Senior Private Secretary.

4.100 At a meeting in the Minister's office on 31 July 1986, the Minister asked the Director whether he could shed any light on the matters raised by Mr Fischer in his parliamentary question and press release of 22 May 1986. The Director said that he had no idea; he said that he felt it was entirely proper and appropriate for the ceremony to be held at the AWM. He mentioned that the Public Relations Officer at the Memorial writes the bulletin and that he does not vet it.

4.101 In a minute dated 1 August 1986 the Director advised the Minister that, after checking AWM records following his discussion with the Minister the previous evening, he found that he had in fact cleared he draft of the bulletin which included the words `as a result of a Ministerial direction'. The Director said that he had not recalled this at the time of his meeting with the Minister. The Minister's office records show that this particular minute was not received in the Minister's office until 3.33 p.m. on 4 August 1986.

4.102 At a further meeting in the Minister's Office on 12 August 1986, the Director was advised by the Minister that a handwriting expert had stated that the words `Tim Fischer M.P.' appearing on the copy of the bulletin obtained from Mr Fischer's office, were consistent with having been written by the Director. (It is noted that the advice from the handwriting expert also mentioned that the lack of a significant number of individual characteristics in the printed entry `REVERSE LEAK' precluded him from taking the matter any further than saying that it is similar to the limited amount of printing attributed to the Director.) The Director denied categorically that it was his handwriting. On at least two subsequent occasions (in the Parliament and on radio) Mr Fischer has stated that the handwriting was his own. He has also confirmed this in writing to this Inquiry.

4.103 In response to questions put to him in the course of this Inquiry, the Director has stated that, after reading the contents of his minute (to the Minister) of 1 August 1986 to the Chairman of Council, he personally delivered it to Parliament House at 9.00 a.m. that day and left it with the Security Officer in the right side office at the top of the main stairs. He has stated that the Security Officer agreed to contact the Minister's office for delivery of the letter. The Chairman of Council has confirmed that he read the minute to her on the morning of 1 August and his acting secretary has stated that she recalls him leaving the office to deliver the minute.
Comment

4.104 It seems clear that, despite contrary advice given orally by the Director to the Minister, the Director was not in favour of holding the VEA Proclamation Ceremony at the AWM. It is also clear that the inclusion in the staff bulletin of the words `as a result of a Ministerial direction' was at the Director's request. There is no evidence, however, that the words `Reverse Leak' or `With compliments, Tim Fischer M.P.' were written by the Director. Indeed, given that the advice of the handwriting expert is not unequivocal and that Mr Fischer has stated and is prepared to attest to the fact that it is his handwriting, it would be difficult to conclude that the writing is that of the Director. In response to a specific question concerning this matter, the Director has stated that he did not nor did anyone acting under his direction provide Mr Fischer with a copy of the staff bulletin.

4.105 It has been noted that a minute dated 22 April 1986 from Ms Cynthia Martin of the Minister's office to the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs states that `He (the Minister) would like a ceremony arranged at the War Memorial'. This would suggest that even if the Minister did not personally direct that the function be held at the AWM, the advice emanating from his office certainly indicated that this was his wish.
