Mr Stewart, Director (Public Relations) D.V.A., also confirmed during a discussion with Mr O'Connor on 19 August 1986 that the decision to hold the function at the AWM was not taken by the Department, but by the Minister's office. In the circumstances, the conclusion by the Director and his staff that the function was being held at the Memorial as a result of a Ministerial direction does not seem unreasonable.

4.106 On the question of the Director not recalling his request that the words `as a result of a Ministerial direction' be included in the staff bulletin, it is noted that over two months had elapsed by the time he was asked to comment on it by the Minister. At the same time, however, it is noted that in addition to annotating Ms James' minute of 15 May 1986, he also cleared a specific draft paragraph put to him by Ms James on 19 May 1986. Notwithstanding the elapse of time, it seems improbable that he would have forgotten that the words were included at his request, particularly as he did not make a practice of editing the staff bulletin.
Item 10: Private Use of AWM Facilities
Matters for Consideration

4.107 Circumstances relating to any private use of War Memorial facilities, including the workshop and photographic facilities, the authority given for that use and, if so, any outside employment which required approval.
Background

4.108 The interim O'Connor Report considered a specific instance in which a member of the workshop staff used the Memorial facilities in his own time to fabricate material for the Director's home. There was a further case of the present Building Services Co-ordinator having used the facilities of the workshop in his own time to construct a piece of furniture for use in his home. This latter activity was noted by Commonwealth auditors during their visit to the Memorial.

4.109 In response to the O'Connor report the Director stated that in both cases the use of Memorial facilities had been in accordance with policy and with guidelines set out in the Personnel Management manual. There have been conflicting statements about the nature of the specific approval given by the Director for the Building Co-ordinator's activity.

4.110 The Rush papers draw attention to possible cases of the use of photographic reproduction facilities for private purposes, and the follow-on work of Arthur Young drew attention to possible cases of private authorship by Memorial staff without prior approval.
4.111 The Auditor-General's report to the Minister commented on private use of the AWM workshops and expressed the view that there needed to be formally documented and promulgated policy.
Comment

4.112 The Inquiry sees the need for clarification of policy and practice in respect of private use of Memorial facilities and outside employment by Memorial staff across the range of Memorial staff. Once they are agreed there needs to be promulgation of these arrangements and appropriate measures for monitoring them. This matter is taken up further in Chapter 5.
Item 11: Publication and Reproduction of TEE EMM
Matters for Consideration
4.113 The circumstances surrounding the commissioning of the publication TEE EMM.
Background

4.114 During World War 2 the Royal Airforce published in magazine form a monthly memorandum on training known as TEE EMM. On 14 March 1984, a former RAF officer now living in Australia wrote to the Assistant Director, Research and Publications proposing the publication of a reproduction of the collected editions of TEE EMM. On 2 April 1984, the Director annotated that letter with the following note to the Assistant Director, Research and Publications: `. . . We will proceed with this. Please take appropriate action.' In a minute to the Assistant Director, Research and Publications dated 9 October 1984, an officer of the Editorial and Publications Section indicated that certain routine actions needed to be taken before TEE EMM was published. These included: assessment of the historical importance of the work; copyright permission; and referral to the Research and Publications Committee in view of the limit of $5,000 per volume set by that Committee for facsimile publications. When responding to the issues raised in that minute, the Director made the following points in a minute to the Assistant Director, Research and Publications dated 23 October 1984: the publication should be regarded as a textbook for specialist consumption; it was probable that all World War 2 pilots would like to obtain a copy; the publication should be treated as a special case and sold at a price which just covered expenses; there was no need to further assess suitability for publication-this had already been decided; copyright permission from the Minister for Defence had been obtained; and he (the Director) would consider how the Research and Publications Committee was to be approached should he consider it necessary.

4.115 In a letter to the Director dated 16 August 1985 the former RAF officer who had made the original suggestion to publish TEE EMM, stated that a survey had been conducted among original subscribers and ex-service associations and that the response to an offer to purchase TEE EMM at $50 to $60 had been more than disappointing. In the circumstances, he said that it had been concluded that it would not be viable to proceed further.

4.116 In October 1985 the Director asked the Assistant Director, Research and Publications to prepare a submission to the Research and Publications Committee to produce 4,000 copies at a total cost of $56,000. The Director indicated that the books could then be sold at a very reasonable price, particularly to the 1200-strong Aircrew reunion which was to be held in Queensland in June 1986. Although the submission to the Research and Publications Committee recommended publication of 4,000 sets of two volumes, during the course of the meeting the Director recommended that 2,000 sets of two volumes be produced. The minutes of that meeting show that the Director advised the Committee that revised costings for the proposed publication indicated that should 2,000 sets be produced, the likely cost would be no more than $50,000 and the retail price per set would be approximately $28.00. The Committee subsequently approved the facsimile republication of 2,000 two volume sets at a total cost of `not more than $50,000 . . . to be met from the Fund'.

4.117 In late October, the Director approved an exemption from tender for the publication and subsequently a Purchase Order and production advance of $20,000 to John Ferguson Pty Limited was arranged. The retail price for the aircrew reunion in June 1986 was later set at $27.00 per set. 300 sets of TEE EMM were taken to the reunion and 116 copies were sold. Subsequent to the reunion a number of sets were sold by mail order and as at 24 September 1986 a total of 317 sets had been sold.
Comment

4.118 With the benefit of hindsight, it seems clear that this publishing venture was not viable. Although it is reported as being the second most expensive publication ever produced by the AWM, very little attention seems to have been paid to the potential market for it. Indeed, the records show that advice which was passed on to the Director from the Editorial and Publications Section in October 1984 was that while the concept was still being evaluated it would be unwise to make an early commitment to proceed further with the publication. Notwithstanding this advice, the Director informed the Assistant Director, Research and Publications in a minute dated 23 October 1984 that he (the Director) `. . . would like this treated as a special case' and that he did `. . . not wish to make a Memorial profit of any consequence'. In that same minute the Director stated that there was no need to assess suitability as this had already been decided.

4.119 When commenting on the O'Connor Report, the Director said that in June and July 1986 the books easily outsold any other AWM publication (other than posters) and that sales had been maintained steadily. He also mentioned that enquiries from Canada and England had been received and bulk sales could be expected. The fact remains, however, that as at 24 September 1986 only 317 sets had been sold and of these 116 had been sold at the Aircrew Reunion.

4.120 On the basis of the information available to this Inquiry, it would seem that the Director's decision to proceed with the production of TEE EMM against clear advice from his staff that he should not do so without first fully evaluating the concept, resulted in a publication which on current indications is unlikely to sell in sufficient numbers to recoup costs.
Item 12: The Aircrew Reunion
Matters for Consideration
4.121 The circumstances surrounding AWM sponsorship of, and staffing involvement in, the Aircrew Reunion on the Gold Coast in June 1986.
Background

4.122 In December 1984 the convenor of a proposed Commonwealth Airforces Reunion wrote to the Director with details of the reunion to be held on the Gold Coast from 2-6 June 1986. The letter requested the AWM to take up sponsorship of the reunion and indicated that a minimum of $1,000 was being requested from each sponsor. In a handwritten note of the same date from the convenor, the Director was invited to be a guest speaker at the reunion. That same letter indicated that after discussing the matter with the Director, the convenor had taken the liberty of including the War Memorial as a sponsor. In a letter dated 15 July 1985 the Director accepted the invitation to speak at the reunion and for the AWM to become a sponsor. A cheque for $1,000 was enclosed with the letter.

4.123 In a letter dated 27 August 1985, the Director sought the views of the convenor of the reunion on the possibility of establishing an AWM bookshop at the reunion. The Director indicated that he would bring his bookshop staff and that copies of the TEE EMM reprint would be available for sale at that time.

4.124 In an information item submitted to Council on 28 August 1985, Council was advised of the sponsorship by the Memorial and further advised that a temporary outlet for the Memorial shop would be opened at the reunion. On the same day Council endorsed the Director's action in accepting the invitation to help sponsor the reunion and also commended the Director for his initiative in arranging for a temporary outlet to be established for the Memorial bookshop.

4.125 The Aircrew Reunion was subsequently attended by the Director and four staff members from 1-6 June 1986. The officers attending included the Commercial Operations Manager-to operate the bookshop; the official AWM photographer-to take photographs which could be of use to the AWM and to assist in the bookshop; and the Curators of Audio-Visual and Written Records who were to perform curatorial duties in securing donations of photographs, diaries and personal papers from participants. In addition, the Director's wife attended and her registration fee of $90 was met by the AWM. The total cost for AWM staff attendance at the reunion was $6,141 (which includes the registration fee for the Director's wife) in addition to which the Memorial was required to pay the $1,000 sponsorship fee. Total bookshop sales at the Reunion were $6,366.91.
Comment

4.126 While the decision that the Memorial should be an official sponsor for this reunion appears to have been made by the Director, it is clear that Council subsequently endorsed that decision well in advance of the event and commended the Director's initiative in setting up an outlet for book sales. Reasons for the attendance of each of the AWM staff who participated are well documented and those reasons appear to be quite sensible. In these circumstances, and while noting that registration fees were paid for the Director's wife and for the four staff who were engaged in AWM work at the reunion, it is not considered that the decision to sponsor the function, or to send the staff who attended, was either irregular or inappropriate.
Item 13: The Karen Rush Investigation
Matters for Consideration

4.127 Circumstances behind Ms Karen Rush's appointment to conduct an investigation into AWM matters. The nature of the tasks she was given, the way in which the investigation was conducted, the protection given to staff during the investigation and reports or findings made as a result of that investigation.
Background

4.128 At the relevant time Ms Rush was an officer of the AWM Secretariat pending promotion to another Department. On 13 June 1986 the Director instructed her, by minute, to undertake a comprehensive review of all Council and Committee resolutions since the introduction of the 1980 Act, with particular attention and priority to be given to the years 1983-86. Specific mention was made of all matters financial, under contract, consultancy or other arrangements involving government funding, and also to commercial operations covering the bookshop and associated activities.

4.129 The instruction was prefaced by a statement that the Council at its next meeting on 28 August 1986 (it actually occurred on 22 August) would consider a suggestion of the Minister that the Memorial organisation and its Act be subjected to a comprehensive departmental review. As part of the preface, the Director noted Ms Rush's knowledge that he himself had been the victim of vicious innuendos regarding the management of the Memorial and his personal conduct regarding the use of resources, to which he was unable to respond.

4.130 It appears that there was no promulgation of this inquiry and that Ms Rush proceeded by examining files and speaking with some members of staff. She provided a series of minutes to the Director which included reports of apparent discrepancies (eg. changes in scale of fees for photographic reproduction and waiver of any fees), indicated points requiring clarification, or made suggestions for action Council would have to take to regularise a particular transaction.

4.131 There is little indication of an attempt to seek clarification or explanation from the officers directly concerned or from the head of Research and Publications Branch, the work of which became the focus of attention.

4.132 There were written exchanges between the Assistant Director, Research and Publications Branch and the Director about the process and about rumours circulating amongst staff. On 30 June the Director confirmed that the work would proceed as Ms Rush's primary responsibility until 30 August when she was expected to leave on promotion.

4.133 On 1 August the Administrator (formerly Assistant Director Resources Management) commissioned the internal auditors, Arthur Young, to examine Council decisions since 1980; to confirm that decisions and directions had been carried out; to confirm that all AWM Fund expenditure had been approved by Council; and to recommend corrective action when necessary. It was hoped that the project could be completed in advance of the Council meeting which had then been set down for 22 August. Although not stated in the Terms of Reference given to the internal auditors, the Rush inquiries were subsumed into their task. The material from the Rush investigation was made available to Arthur Young. Arthur Young reported on 18 September.
Comment

4.134 The Inquiry regards the process followed in the Rush investigations as unsatisfactory, particularly in relation to the position of individuals subject to criticism. It did not interview Ms Rush and has not taken up the issues or recommendations from her submissions to the Director. It has directed its attention to the follow-up work contained in the Arthur Young Report.
Item 14: Declaration of the Director's Pecuniary Interests
Matters for Consideration

4.135 Whether the Director has provided to the Minister a declaration of his pecuniary interests. In this regard whether the Director is a director or has any interest in any private company, the business of any such company and any remuneration received by the Director from business interests.
Background

4.136 Since 1984 it has been Government policy to invite full-time statutory office holders of SES equivalent level to furnish annually a declaration of pecuniary interests to the Minister. This applies to the Director of the AWM and a similar requirement exists for the Assistant Directors to furnish declarations to the Director. These arrangements are intended to be administered with sensitivity and in confidence.
Comment

4.137 The Inquiry has found a state of uncertainty within the Memorial on this matter. The Director says he had not been aware of the requirement previously, although he had provided a list of personal interests to the previous Minister towards the end of 1984. He had not done so with the present Minister, but, now that he is aware of the requirement, he has provided him with an appropriate statement. He has also drawn the requirement to the attention of his Assistant Directors.

4.138 From conversations with two long-serving Assistant Directors it is unclear as to whether the requirement had been drawn to their attention. Neither of them has ever made a declaration in the Memorial.

4.139 In answer to the Inquiry the Director provided specific information about family business interests including recent action to resign from non-remunerative directorships in two family trusts. The Inquiry is not aware of any conflict of interest arising from the Director's pecuniary interests.
4.140 Both the Minister and the Director need to ensure that the Government's requirements in this matter are observed on an ongoing basis.
Item 15: Chilean Embassy Ceremony 1986
Matters for Consideration
4.141 Whether the Memorial's facilities were used for a ceremony conducted by or for the Chilean Embassy in September 1986 and, if so, whether this function was in contravention of Council's policy.
Background

4.142 On 19 September 1986 a wreath laying ceremony by the Ambassador of the Republic of Chile took place at the Memorial. A similar event has been held each year since at least 1981. In 1985 and 1986 the explanation given with the request to hold the ceremony was as a `gesture of friendship between my country and yours . . .' whereas from 1981-84 the explanation was described as `in memory of Australia's contribution to peace, during difficult periods of this century'.

4.143 There is a Council policy for ceremonies and wreath laying at the Memorial and guidelines were last approved on 29 May 1986. The relevant provision appears to be `. . . as an extension of this policy, the Memorial does permit people to lay wreaths at the Memorial in honour of all people who died in war'.
Comment

4.144 This function has been held periodically and presumably has been deemed to be within Council policy. However, the guidelines are not without ambiguity and ought to be made clearer for the benefit of all concerned and to avoid possible embarrassment. It is understood that the AWM administration has this in hand.
Item 16: Garden of Remembrance Replanting Project
Matters for Consideration
4.145 The circumstances in which plants were replaced in early 1985 in the Garden of Remembrance area.
Background

4.146 In January 1985 it became apparent that a number of shrubs in the Garden of Remembrance had died due to lack of water. There had been problems with leakage in the Galleries below following work done by the NCDC and the reticulation system for the garden had been damaged and subsequently turned off. On his return from leave in late January 1985 the Director decided to have the plants replaced. He selected the firm Everglades from Sydney to do the work and on 25 March 1985 that firm submitted to the Director a quote for $5,500 for the supply and installation of plants for the garden. A note for file by the Director on an apparently undelivered minute to members of the Executive Committee shows that agreement to use Everglades at a cost of $5,000 was given by all members of that Committee who were contacted by telephone during the week commencing 1 April 1985. The work was ultimately completed by Everglades in the time specified.
Comment

4.147 The replanting of the Garden of Remembrance appears to have been handled personally by the Director. In answer to questions during the course of this Inquiry he indicated that he had sought the services of Everglades because no Canberra nursery was able to do the work. He said that he had contacted several local nurseries (including Rodney's Nursery at Pialligo) but none had been able to do the work in the time specified, i.e. before ANZAC Day 1985. The Director confirmed that he had never had any previous contact with Everglades or its management and mentioned that their existence had become known to him following a visit by the principal of the firm to the AWM in early 1985. He said that it was as a consequence of that meeting that he invited Everglades to submit a quote for replacement of the shrubs.

4.148 It is noted that when this matter was discussed during the course of the Inquiry with the former Assistant Director, Resources Management, he stated that the Director had told him beforehand that the work was going to be done free of charge.

4.149 The procedures followed by the Director in relation to the replanting of the Garden of Remembrance were not consistent with normal purchasing and supply practices. In particular, there is no record of quotations having been sought from other companies, no indication of how Everglades was selected for the task, and no record of a Purchase Order having been completed in advance of the work being done.

4.150 Notwithstanding these administrative deficiencies, it should be noted that there is no reason to believe that the Director chose to pursue the matter personally for any reason other than his concern to ensure that the Garden of Remembrance was in a presentable form by ANZAC Day 1985.
Item 17: Information for the Minister
Matter for Consideration
4.151 The information provided to the Minister in order that he be kept informed on a continuing basis on the AWM's activities.
Background

4.152 This matter comes up for consideration under a number of items being discussed. The Inquiry understands that this specific reference reflects difficulty faced by the Minister in obtaining copies of agenda papers and minutes of the Memorial Council and its Committees. These are now being provided.
Comment

4.153 Just as the Council requires adequately and timely information from the Director about the administration of the Memorial, so ought the Minister to receive adequate and timely information from the Council about the conduct of its affairs. However, in neither case should it be necessary or is it desirable to go into matters of detail. As between the Minister and the Council, it might well be more appropriate, in an ongoing co-operative relationship, for summary material to be provided, supplemented by personal discussion.
Item 18: Inadequate Information to Council or a Committee
Matters for Consideration
4.154 Any Circumstances where Council, or a Committee of Council, has been placed in a position of making a decision based on inadequate, incorrect, one sided or biased advice.
Item 19: Irregularities in Making Staff Appointments
Matters for Consideration
4.155 Any failure to follow proper procedures, or favouritism, or prejudice, in filling positions, or not filling positions, on the AWM staff.
Item 20: Irregularities in Distribution of Sections Among Branches
Matters for Consideration
4.156 Any failure to follow proper procedures, favouritism or prejudice, in the relative disposition of staff members between different areas of the AWM.
Item 21: State of Morale Among Staff
Matters for Consideration

4.157 The allegations regarding poor morale in parts of the AWM, including whether this is a result of any lack of consultation (particularly with professional staff), capricious decision-making and inadequate delegation.
Background

4.158 Item 18-21 are taken together. The topics were supplied by the Minister and on checking the Inquiry was informed that they reflected points made to the Minister by a deputation of four staff members on 9 September immediately after Council on 8 September had found no prima facie case of misbehaviour against the Director. The four officers agreed to meet with the Inquiry and identified a number of events in support of their criticism of the Director's actions under those four headings.

4.159 The Inquiry linked a number of points advanced by this group with representations it had received from other groups and individuals, including from two union job delegates. It put to the Director a series of criticisms of him based on this wide range of representations.

4.160 The Director declined to respond on the grounds of unreliability of the information and of what he regarded to be its source, that is, a small section of a disgruntled element. He asked the Inquiry to take no further evidence from that particular source unless he could be present and question witnesses. The Inquiry declined to do this, but said that it would take his views into account as the completion of the Report proceeded.
4.161 Some of the points put to the Director from various sources (not just the `disgruntled element') are discussed below against the background of this exchange with the Director:

(a) The Director was criticised for having modified agenda papers going to the Research and Publications Committee on 11 September 1986 to make Committee approval of the manuscript a condition of proceeding with the Bicentennial Volume. It was contended that the Committee should have been told that all preparatory work had been done and that contractually the Committee had no power to intervene in the publication. The inquiry acknowledges the right of the Director to modify material going forward to the Committee, however in doing so he needs to ensure that the Committee is informed of the consequence of action proposed. In this case, an undesirable consequence could be staff dissatisfaction as well as administrative difficulties.

(b) There is further criticism that certain elements of the previously approved research program for 1986/87 were deducted in the course of final preparation of material for Council on 22 August 1986. It was asserted that there had been no consultation with staff nor would Council have been in a position to weigh the relative merits of expenditure cuts in various areas within the Memorial. The Inquiry sees it as the prerogative of Council and the Director to make the hard decisions about priorities when available resources are limited. It is difficult for the Inquiry to assess whether adequate information was available or not, but it appreciates there can be a need for confidentiality about the reasons for such decisions.

(c) The Director was criticised for making an arrangement to engage a person as an historian of the AWM contrary to advice from staff that this would contravene recently promulgated Public Service Board guidelines concerning fixed term temporary employment, and that a Public Service Board requirement for prior advertisement and union consultation should have been observed. The criticism appears to be substantiated.

(d) Another staffing decision criticised was the process followed and the action finally taken recently to fill a position of Curator Grade 2 (Audio-Visual Records). The Inquiry believes that the Director was acting reasonably within his rights as a manager. It is noted that one unsuccessful candidate believed that the Director had dealt with a difficult situation equitably.

(e) Over the last year or so, there have been changes in allocations of Sections across Branches following an internal organisation review. A recent decision by the Director to transfer Research Centre Sections to the Programs and Collections Branch was criticised because of lack of consultation under the Industrial Democracy Plan and of apprehension about further changes. The Inquiry acknowledges that the Director should have engaged in appropriate consultation, particularly as there was a legitimate expectation of no further changes. However it cannot share the view that the Director had an ulterior motive in wanting to disadvantage the head of the Research and Publications Branch. In the view of the Inquiry, there is a legitimate case for further review of the distribution of functions across the branches.

(f) There has been a number of complaints about the impact of decisions the Director has taken during the planning for galleries. This has been asserted to involve unrealistic deadlines, costly and disturbing changes of mind, and the ignoring of considered advice from curators and conservators. It was further claimed that after the Exhibition Planning Co-ordination Committee had arranged the preparation of a statement of principles and a program for the planning of new galleries over a five-year period and this work had been endorsed at Assistant Director level, the Director had introduced substantial changes without consultation. In the view of the Inquiry, there is a need for substantially more cross-fertilisation of ideas and information within the Memorial staff and for enhanced opportunities for middle managers to bring forward proposals to the state of final consideration. There remains the important basic principle, that changes can be made by top management. When this happens there ought to be adequate consultation and feedback.

(g) There is great concern amongst conservation staff about the action taken to instruct maintenance staff to increase lighting levels in several galleries without consultation with them. The Inquiry acknowledges the Director's responsibility to weigh up the competing needs of conservation and display, but he needs also to be sensitive to the impact his decisions are likely to have on the commitment of professionally trained staff.
(h) The Inquiry sees a similar concern, and falling-off of commitment, amongst exhibition staff about costly and damaging changes being made contrary to agreed planning and execution arrangements.

4.162 The Inquiry itself had noticed criticism from certain areas because the Director has not accepted or has countermanded action professional staff have taken to reflect what might be called the protest movement in respect of some of the conflicts in which Australians have been engaged, eg. the Vietnam War. In the view of the Inquiry, these are policy issues which rest upon appropriate decisions by Council and their articulation in practice by the Director. It is not for individuals or groups within the staff to make such decisions. It may be, however, that Council needs to clarify the position.

4.163 These various criticisms need to be evaluated in the knowledge that there has been no specific response from the Director, and in the light of other related elements of the work of the Inquiry. The Inquiry has sought out views from other staff members so that it might make a balanced assessment of the Director's management style, an assessment which it acknowledges to be value-based.

4.164 The Inquiry has found serious morale problems among Memorial staff. This is by no means universal but it is substantial. The morale of workshops and security staff is high and they appear to have an extremely high regard for the Director. At the other extreme is a group of staff, primarily in the Research and Publications Branch, who are completely disenchanted with the Director. There are others among Conservators and Curators whose commitment has been damaged by what they see as capricious and costly decisions taken by the Director. The majority of administrative staff appear not to be ill disposed to the Director.

4.165 The Inquiry has noted also that some of those who are critical of the Director's management style are equally critical of the way some staff members have gone about developing their criticism of the Director. That behaviour brings into light the right of a chief executive officer to expect loyalty from his people. It needs to be recognised also that some morale problems derive from conflicting views among working groups, quite apart from their views about the Director's management.

4.166 A further general observation is that while the staff of the Memorial has grown rapidly over recent years and there has been a dramatic expansion of professionally trained staff, top management has continued to rely unduly on the advice of the pre-existing staff. The Inquiry sees it as the job of management to facilitate co-operation and support between various occupational groups within the staff and to use the range of talents to best advantage.

4.167 Formal delegations to staff positions were reviewed by Council in August 1985 and appeared to be appropriate, subject to what is said elsewhere about the authority of the Commercial Operations Manager and the need for review of publications policy and procedure.
Item 22: Acquisition and Disposal of Aircraft and Historical Material by the Australian War Memorial
Matters for Consideration
4.168 Any irregularities in the purchasing or disposal of aircraft or historical or other material by the Australian War Memorial.
Background

4.169 Section 8 (4) of the Australian War Memorial Act provides that disposal (by the AWM) of historical material exceeding $5,000 in value must be approved by the Minister. Section 35 of the Act provides that, subject to Section 8 (4) the Memorial shall not, without the Minister's approval, enter into a contract under which the Memorial is to pay or receive, in the case of the acquisition of any historical material, an amount in excess of $100,000, or in any other case, an amount in excess of $50,000.

4.170 The AWM policy on aircraft collection is set out in the Report of the Committee of Review of the Aircraft Collection of the Australian War Memorial (The Barnes Report), which was endorsed by the AWM's Gallery Committee on 29 February 1984. Among other things, the Report outlines the AWM's collecting objectives; specifies the priorities for acquisition of aircraft and recommends that the AWM actively follow a policy of exchange of material.
Comment

4.171 An examination of AWM records during the course of the Inquiry has revealed that Ministerial and/or Council approval has not always been sought for the disposal of aircraft parts where such approval appears to have been required. Examples include the disposal of two sets of wings of Mustang aircraft referred to in the Council resolutions of 12 November 1984; the disposal of two Mustang wings, two Winjeel wings, two Winjeel centre sections or a Merlin engine referred to in a submission to Council of 4 October 1985; and the disposal of a Gypsy Major engine referred to in the Agenda for the Gallery Committee meeting of 13 March 1986. In relation to this last item, the Director made the following file annotation on 25 February 1986. `. . . please proceed with exchange. Ministerial approval is not required for barter items'.

4.172 There is also inadequate documentation in AWM records relating to the acquisition of complete aircraft and in particular to the terms of specific acquisitions. An example is the P-51 Mustang Fighter which was purchased from the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT) in 1983. In a letter to the RMIT dated 1 February 1983 the Director said: `. . . I refer to our telephone conversation of 26 January with regard to the Mustang P-51D, A68-648. I have pleasure in confirming our offer of $55,000 (Fifty five thousand dollars) and aircraft components as discussed'. The RMIT responded by saying that they accepted the offer and would `. . . liaise with (the senior curator) at a later date regarding the other aircraft components'. It is not clear from the AWM records what (if any) aircraft components were provided to the RMIT as part payment for the P-51. When the matter was reported to the Executive Committee on 3 March 1983, the disposal of aircraft components as part of the price was not mentioned and there is no indication that the Minister was advised as would have been required if the aircraft parts were classified as historical material and their value was in excess of $5,000.

4.173 A further example of incorrect procedures being followed in relation to aircraft acquisition concerns the purchase of the B25 Mitchell Bomber. Circumstances surrounding this purchase have been addressed in detail in Item 23 of this Chapter.

4.174 It has also been noted that the AWM has an arrangement whereby it acquires aircraft and aircraft parts, seemingly free of charge, from the RAAF and the Aeronautical Research Laboratories. These acquisitions are being used by the AWM for the purpose of barter with other collectors. The precise arrangements are not entirely clear from AWM records and it may well be that they are contrary to the normal procedures for acquisition and disposal of Commonwealth property.

4.175 The issue of acquisition (and restoration) by the AWM of historical military aircraft was raised in a letter to the Minister from a former Curator of Military Technology on 29 September 1986 and that letter has been drawn to the attention of the Inquiry. In the letter it was asserted that the Director had: `. . . ignored the advice of his curatorial staff . . . jeopardised the security of the national collection . . . undermined the professional credibility of the Memorial in his dealings with the collection community . . . compromised professional standards . . . and . . . reduced staff morale to its lowest ebb'. Each of the specific examples given by the former Curator has been closely examined during the course of the Inquiry.

4.176 It is considered that the letter contains many factual errors, exaggerations and unsupported assertions and, in view of this, it was seen as being of dubious value in terms of making a balanced judgement about the acquisition and disposal policies of the AWM. In addition, while the Director had offered some comments on these criticisms, he had asked the Inquiry to seek further information from the author. Although requested, this was not available at the time of writing.

4.177 There seems little doubt that institutions such as the AWM need to `trade in the market place' if they are to operate effectively as a major museum. It is apparent, however, that some of the practices adopted by the Director and his staff have had a strong element of ad hockery about them and that there is a need to introduce better and more clearly identifiable procedures and to maintain better records in relation to the acquisition and disposal of aircraft and historical material by the AWM.
Item 23: Letter to the Canberra Times from Mr. J. R. Heaton
Matters for Consideration
4.178 Issues raised by the correspondence to the Canberra Times in October 1985 by Mr J. R. Heaton.
Background

4.179 On 8 October 1985 a letter from Mr J. R. Heaton, former Senior Curator of Military Technology, appeared in the Canberra Times. In the letter Mr Heaton stated that staff morale in the Australian War Memorial had fallen to a critically low level following rapid staff turnover, particularly in the professional areas, during the previous 18 months. He said that a number of other experienced curatorial staff members were either actively seeking employment elsewhere or, though unwilling to move, were unhappy with the existing management. Mr Heaton also said that it was his experience while with the AWM that directives for major programs would change without warning from week to week, particularly in the area of gallery design and construction; that staircases would be built, knocked down and rebuilt without ever being used; that on the management side jobs were regularly offered to staff without proper consideration of the procedures to be followed; that employment offers, once made, were very often withdrawn or considerably modified; that sections within the institution were continually being changed and reorganised; and that staff morale was undermined when management freely and openly discussed the ability of staff with people from all levels.

4.180 Following a request from the Minister's office, the Director wrote to the Minister on 8 October 1985 (ie. the day the letter was published) addressing the three main issues raised by Mr Heaton, viz: staff turnover at senior levels, problems associated with the AWM's building and gallery programs and staff selection procedures. Although conceding that the Memorial had endured a number of difficulties during the previous 18 months (particularly in relation to staffing and financial constraints and building and gallery refurbishments) the Director essentially refuted Mr Heaton's allegations.

4.181 During Question Time that day (8 October 1985) the Minister assured Senator Aulich, in response to a question without notice, that he (the Minister) had satisfied himself that, to a great extent, Mr Heaton's allegations had very little substance and that senior staff who had resigned had done so for personal or career advancement reasons. He also said that the Memorial's previous problems were substantially due to inadequate financial and human resources and that these shortcomings had been effectively addressed in the 1985/86 Budget. The Minister has stated that in replying to the question he was acting on the Director's advice.

4.182 The following day (9 October 1985) in the adjournment debate in the House of Representatives, the Shadow Minister, Mr Fischer, referred to the Minister's answer of the previous day and asserted that the Minister had been wrong in his contention and advice to the Senate. Mr Fischer said that the AWM had had a loss of specialist middle management level personnel far in excess of what might be regarded as normal turnover. He stated that the Minister had been responsible for a `cover-up' or, alternatively, a failure to investigate the situation fully. He concluded by saying that the Minister had absolute responsibility to investigate comprehensively and then take corrective action.

4.183 Following Mr Fischer's comments, on 18 October 1985 the Minister asked the Chairman for Council's advice on whether there were management and staff morale problems at the Memorial which needed to be addressed and, if so, did Council see value in initiating a suitable form of management review. His request initiated a process which ultimately culminated in this Inquiry.
Comment

4.184 While Mr Heaton's letter includes reference to such issues as staff morale, planning and construction of galleries, refurbishment of the Memorial and organisation and staffing practices, the essence of the Minister's concern is that the Director's minute to him of 8 October 1985 was not accurate and that it placed him in a position where he was in effect misleading the Parliament. The individual issues mentioned by Mr Heaton are each specifically addressed elsewhere in this Report. The point at issue here is whether or not the advice conveyed to the Minister in the Director's minute of 8 October 1985 was accurate.

4.185 A review of the reasons for resignation given by AWM staff who resigned between February 1982 and March 1986 has not been particularly revealing as the reasons tend to be worded in a non-specific way. Similarly, the list attached to the Director's minute of 8 October 1985 to the Minister is not particularly informative. The reasons for leaving specified in the attachment to the minute (ie. in relation to the positions referred to by Mr Heaton in his letter to the Canberra Times) vary substantially and include: temporary and permanent transfers, promotion, participation in a staff development program, pre-retirement-sick leave and resignation. While there is no evidence in AWM personnel records that people left during this period because of their disenchantment with the organisation, it cannot be assumed that this was not the case, particularly where no reason was given at all or the people concerned have stated that they were leaving for personal reasons.

4.186 When responding to points raised by the Minister on 16 October 1986 in relation to this matter, the Director, on 27 October 1986, reaffirmed his view that his minute of 8 October 1985 to the Minister was accurate in all respects. He has also mentioned that the minute was cleared through the Chairman and has noted that all documents pertaining to the matter were (subsequently) discussed at length by Council and the matter declared satisfactorily actioned.

4.187 In discussions with staff and former staff during the course of the Inquiry, it became apparent that some senior personnel left the AWM because of their dissatisfaction with the management style of the Director. From what has been said, there seems little doubt that Mr Heaton and at least two others resigned for this reason. It also seems likely that a further two senior officers sought (and obtained) moves elsewhere in the Service because of a deterioration in personal relationships with the Director. The Director would have been well aware of these particular staff morale problems when writing to the Minister on 8 October 1985 and the fact that he chose not to mention them at all indicates that his advise was at best inadequate and at worst misleading.
Other matter raised in the Interim O'Connor Report
Item 24: The painting of No. 77 Squadron
Matters for Consideration
4.188 Circumstances in which a painting of No. 77 Squadron was commissioned from Mr Robert Taylor of Bath, England.
Background

4.189 In March 1984 the then Curator of Post-1939 Art wrote to Mr Robert Taylor, an artist resident in Bath, England, to ask whether he might be interested in undertaking a commission for the AWM. Mr Taylor subsequently confirmed that he would be prepared to undertake the work for the AWM and, in a series of correspondence in succeeding months, it was agreed that he would paint an oil on canvas depicting the first raid into North Korea by a combined RAAF/USAF force on 2 July 1950-the first day of operations for Australian forces in the Korean war. It would seem that, as the Director flew as a pilot with 77 Squadron on that occasion, the Curator of Art sought his advice on the technical aspects of the event and the aircraft concerned. The Director subsequently also corresponded with Mr Taylor about this work.

4.190 The work was finalised in June 1986 and received by the AWM in August 1986. The final price paid by the Memorial was 5000 pounds sterling. (Payment approval had been given by the Gallery Committee on 8 November 1985.)
Comment

4.191 Although the Director had a personal interest in this painting because of his Air Force background, and although he had an input to the final format of the work, there is no indication on file that he was responsible for the commissioning of it or that there was anything irregular about the purchase.
Item 25: Eternal Flame Project
Matters for Consideration

4.192 The circumstances surrounding the decision to install an `eternal flame' in the commemorative area as a bicentennial gift from the Australian Gas Association, and the related proposal and its cost, for relocating the present water feature elsewhere.
Background

4.193 On 4 October 1985 the Australian Gas Association (AGA) approached the Memorial, through the Director, with a provisional proposal to donate an eternal flame to the AWM as a bicentennial project with the AGA meeting design and construction costs in addition to free gas. The Director referred the matter to the Building Committee which, on 24 October 1985, endorsed the concept and the acceptance of the gift, subject to, and with the intention of referring any formal offer to, Council for approval. The Director was asked to clarify matters of concern to the Committee-the responsibility for maintenance and approximate cost; safety aspects; security; environmental implications of long term burning of the gas flame.

4.194 On 27 February 1986 the Director reported, as a late agenda item, receipt of a detailed proposal from AGA to remove the present water feature and bear any costs involved in restoring the courtyard; provide an eternal flame to the War Memorial's specifications and design and provide free gas for the first ten years of operation. The Director pointed out that removal of the water feature and installation of the eternal flame would maintain the tranquil and reflective ambience of the courtyard. Council approved the concept and the bicentennial gift from AGA and sought assistance from NCDC in the formulation of a design for the eternal flame and the development of a suitable external setting for the water feature.

4.195 On 22 August 1986 Council considered a further letter of 13 August from AGA with sketch drawings of alternative designs, including plaques incorporating both the bicentennial and AGA logos. It appears that the NCDC had prepared the designs, but had not favoured inclusion of the logos on the plaques. Council decided on the title `The Eternal Flame' with a water level concept and approved one plaque at floor level, with reference to AGA and the logo to be deleted.
4.196 There is no record of any further consideration of a design for an alternative setting for the water feature. It appears that this is still with NCDC.
Comment

4.197 The Inquiry understands that an earlier approach by AGA about the installation of an eternal flame in the commemorative area had not been taken up by a previous Council. However it is clear that the present Council has endorsed the bicentennial gift proposal. Until the NCDC comes forward with a design concept it is difficult to estimate the cost of relocation of the present water feature. That relocation cost would be a matter for the Commonwealth, and no doubt the Council will take that into account in reaching a decision on that matter.
Item 26: Parliamentary Question-Remuneration of Members of Council
Matters for Consideration
4.198 The provision of information to the Minister about remuneration in respect of Mrs E. Darling, MP, as a member of Council, for use in answer to a Parliamentary question.
Background

4.199 On 22 March 1985 Mr Leo McLeay, MP, asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, on notice, for details of the remuneration and travelling allowance payable to each member of a statutory authority, advisory panel and council within his jurisdiction.

4.200 On 13 May 1985 the Minister answered the question (House of Representatives Hansard 2230) by providing a schedule with information about each member of the relevant bodies by name. This included information for members of the AWM Council based on advice from the Memorial. That information was incorrect in that it led to the inclusion of an amount of $4,487 for `salary or remuneration' for each of the members of Council other than the Chairman. In fact four of those members-Mrs Darling and the Chiefs of Staff-do not receive any remuneration.

4.201 On 27 May 1985 the Secretary, Department of Veterans' Affairs, drew the error to the Minister's attention, informed him that Mrs Darling had never received payment for her services as a member of Council and recommended that the recorded answer be amended to correct the information in respect of Mrs Darling and the other service chiefs. This was done.

4.202 When the Minister expressed concern that Mrs Darling's position could be endangered by the wrong information, the Director's response was that no remuneration had, in fact, been paid to Mrs Darling and it was ridiculous to assert that the information supplied could lead to forfeiture of her Parliamentary office.
Comment

4.203 The significant consideration here, in addition to ensuring correct answers to Parliamentary questions, was that there could be serious consequences for a Member of Parliament who received remuneration through a second office of profit under the Crown.

4.204 The misleading information was probably due to lack of understanding or lack of due care by an officer of the Memorial. It was not picked up when the Department co-ordinated the response for the Minister. Following a period of uncertainty proper corrective action was taken and it is somewhat puzzling that the Director did not acknowledge that the information provided by his staff was misleading.
Matters raised by internal auditors-Arthur Young report

4.205 Arthur Young are the Memorial's internal auditors. On 1 August 1986 the Director commissioned them to make a concentrated special study of Council resolutions to confirm that Council decisions and directions have been carried out; that all AWM Fund expenditure has been approved; to recommend corrective action when necessary. They reported on 18 September. The exercise was originally intended to provide a basis for the Director to report to a scheduled meeting of Council on 22 August about the matters under review and Arthur Young followed on from an internal review by an officer of the Secretariat which the Director had commissioned on 13 June 1986. Because of other developments with the matters that led to the appointment of this Inquiry, the Arthur Young report had not been considered by the Council when I undertook my own task. However, subsequently the Chairman of Council checked with me to ensure that I was following up the matters raised by Arthur Young which she said would otherwise have been acted upon by Council.
Business Requiring Council Ratification

4.206 In response to their Terms of Reference, the internal auditors concentrated on matters involving expenditure from the AWM Fund. They drew attention to a number of transactions authorised by the Research and Publications Committee which they saw as requiring Council ratification. In doing so they raised questions about the powers of the Committee and about inadequacies in the contents of resolutions of Council without reference to supporting agenda material and minutes. They drew attention also to instances of private authorship by Memorial staff which had not been identified to the Research and Publications Committee and which might have been engaged in without prior approval. Their examination was not intended to be exhaustive.
Powers of Committees

4.207 As to the powers of committees, it is clear that the AWM Act does not confer any decision-making powers on Committees or permit the Council to delegate such powers to them. It has been the practice within the Memorial to rely upon the ongoing delegations from the Council to the Director to underpin action proposed by Committees, subject of course to those cases in which the Council itself takes an appropriate decision. As noted by Arthur Young, in August 1985 the form of words used in the Terms of Reference for each Committee, and in the delegations given to the Director, and where appropriate to other officers, were modified by Council in an attempt to ensure that there was proper authority for action taken following Committee consideration.

4.208 I appreciate that members of a Committee concerned with significant ongoing activities of the Memorial would not be satisfied to be required to have all of their actions underwritten by the Council. There would be practical difficulties also with such a requirement. I support the efforts that were made in August 1985 by Council in this regard. Council should seek advice on the validity of the decision process, both before and after August 1985.

4.209 Arthur Young has recommended that the Council ratify a list of actions taken by Committees. I endorse that approach. However, in some instances it appears that Arthur Young were not sufficiently informed about the nature of Memorial activities in the publications area. It has been the practice for the Council or Research and Publications Committee to take a decision about a particular publication and then to rely on the delegation responsibility of the Director to carry that into effect. Proper approval having been given for an item in publications program, matters such as the eventual cost, print runs, tenders and contracts, retail price, marketing and distribution were the Director's responsibility within the limits of his delegations. I understand that some of the items which Arthur Young recommend for ratification may in fact be covered by these arrangements.
4.210 It is desirable however that the matter be clarified by a reaffirmation by Council of the policy and practice it wishes to pursue in these situations.
Form and Content of Agenda, Minutes and Resolutions

4.211 As to the wording of resolutions, I see a need in a wider context for improved documentation of the material presented to Council and Committees, and of their deliberations and conclusions on particular matters. However, the action taken ought to strike a balance between providing adequate and timely information and adding unnecessarily to the workload and degree of detailed consideration required of Committee members.

4.212 Arthur Young have drawn attention to discrepancies in determining charges for reproduction fees from AWM holdings for use in commercial publications. This was seen to involve discounts or waiver beyond delegated authority. They referred to one case in which a fee of $3,000 had been paid for the reproduction of photographs for the first two volumes of the series when the normal fee would have exceeded $11,000. On this basis the internal auditors saw a need for Council ratification of the transaction.

4.213 My investigation shows that the Arthur Young assessment was based on a miscalculation by an officer of the Research Centre within the Memorial. In fact the cost for the reproduction of the number of prints actually ordered for the first volume of the series was very close to the $1,500 agreed with the publisher for each of the first two volumes. Action had already been taken to change the basis of costing for subsequent volumes, though that too was based on the same miscalculation as to the likely cost. There may be some tidying up needed for arrangements in this area. I see this as a task for the Memorial administration.
Private Authorship

4.214 The internal auditors have noted instances in the publications examined by them where there has been no disclosure to the Research and Publications Committee of authorship of particular material by staff members writing in a private capacity. They have drawn attention to the provisions of the Public Service Act about outside employment in the context of staff appearing to have been engaged as authors or support staff in the production of private publications without prior approval. For convenience, I take up consideration of this matter in Chapter 5 under the heading `Private Authorship and Outside Employment'.

4.215 Arthur Young has asked questions about the publication `Guide to the Australian War Memorial' which was included in a report on the publications program at a value of $63,000 without any record of Council or Research and Publications Committee approval. In addition a member of staff had written the work for the commercial publisher in his private capacity.

4.216 My enquiries show there is a category of publications which are purchased for sale by the Memorial but are not part of the publications program. I have had conflicting advice from the Director and the head of the Research and Publications Branch about this particular publication. The Branch head says it comes within the category of items which have never had Research and Publications Committee approval; the Director says that is does not and requires specific Committee approval and ratification of expenditure by Council.

4.217 I can find no policy statement to determine this difference of view, but I must say that it is reasonable to expect that the expenditure of $63,000 on a publication intended for sale in the Memorial bookshop at a substantial price and with a topic of this sort, should be a matter for consideration by the Research and Publications Committee. There appears to have been no approval for private authorship even though the Branch head was aware of the staff member's engagement through his own dealings with the publisher.

4.218 The status of the publication has recently been brought under review by the Research and Publications Committee. These events underscore the need I address in Chapter 5 for the development and application of policies on publications and on private authorship.

4.219 One difficulty with the Arthur Young report is that it does not reflect discussions with senior officers of the Research and Publications Branch either during the enquiries or at exit. I sought a commentary from the head of the Branch on the detailed recommendations in the report. This has been passed to the Memorial administration for their consideration as part of the follow-up action on the report.
Matters raised by the Auditor-General

4.220 During July 1986 the Minister drew to the Auditor-General's attention a list of 10 items relating to alleged irregularities in the operations of the Memorial. Subsequently in August that list was the starting point for the O'Connor Inquiry. The Audit Office took the items in the list into account in the course of its ordinary annual audit of the accounts and records of financial transactions and records relating to assets for the year ended 30 June 1986. An exit report by the Auditors was submitted to the Director on 26 September for comment. Comments were provided by the Administrator on 9 October (the Director was on leave pending my inquiry) and on 30 October the Auditor-General reported formally to the Minister after taking account of the comments received.

4.221 My purpose is not to canvass the details of the audit findings, but to take up some matters from the Audit report which are pertinent to the inquiry. In doing so I record my understanding that while there are still shortcomings, the Audit Office recognises that the standard of financial management and reporting at the Memorial has improved significantly during the term of the present Director.
Item 27: Purchase of B25 Mitchell Bomber

4.222 The Memorial entered into an agreement with a partnership operating as `Aero Heritage' on 25 August 1983 for the purchase of a B25 Mitchell Bomber from the U.S.A. The agreement provided for a series of payments, the last of which would be due on or before 31 July 1987, with the intention that when that payment had been made title of the aircraft would pass to the Memorial.

4.223 Against this background Audit has questioned a number of apparently inaccurate statements made by the Memorial when applying for exemption from customs duty and sales tax in December 1983. Customs was told that the aircraft was being imported as the property of the Australian Government, was not intended for the purpose of trade and was therefore exempt from duty and sales tax. Enquiries by Audit indicate that as Aero Heritage was the owner at the time of importation, duties and charges amounting to approximately $30,800 may have been payable.

4.224 The Memorial has advised Audit that the certificate was signed in good faith with no intention to avoid customs duty and sales tax. The Memorial is seeking clarification from Customs of any liability in that regard.

4.225 Also on 16 March 1984 the Memorial wrote to the Department of Aviation stating that the aircraft had been purchased by the Memorial which would operate it as a flying museum piece. The aircraft would be flown for non-commercial purposes at infrequent air shows and would be stored and maintained by the RAAF at Fairbairn. This action was taken following representations from Aero Heritage which included a statement that it was beyond their means to meet the demands that had been made on them for air navigation charges.

4.226 There were further exchanges in this matter with the Department of Aviation, including a letter of 13 June 1984 in which the statement about Memorial ownership was reaffirmed. Enquiries by Audit indicate that based on a proper assessment the air navigation charges would have been around $18,000 per annum prior to 1986 and later $20,000 per annum as compared with a rate of $500 per annum for an historic aircraft. Taken over four years the difference is between charges paid of about $2,000 as compared with possibly more than $70,000.
4.227 At Audit request the Memorial is seeking clarification from the Department of Aviation of the liability of Aero Heritage for air navigation charges.

4.228 The matter for consideration is whether false statements were made by the Memorial to Customs and Aviation with potential to result in a loss of revenue to the Commonwealth. My enquiries show that the statements to Customs came from the Finance Officer following advice from a curator and that the letter to Aviation was signed by the Director to whom the Aero Heritage representations which stimulated it had been addressed.

4.229 I asked the Director questions to elicit whether he had grounds at the time for believing the aircraft to be Memorial property and whether he was aware that the provision of statements claiming ownership would have an impact on Customs and Aviation decisions about the level of charges. In reply, the Director argued the significance of the aircraft to Australia; stated that at the time he believed the AWM to be the equitable owner; and sought to draw a legal analogy to substantiate this view. At the time he did not consider that either duty or sales tax was applicable.

4.230 In my view, the Director and his staff should have been aware of the significance of the contractual arrangements and if in doubt should have sought clarification before making statements as to ownership. As indicated above, the Memorial is seeking clarification from Customs and Aviation as to their view of the matter.
Item 28: AWM Kiosk Licence

4.231 In April 1985 the licensee of the kiosk claimed that there had been an unsatisfactory restriction to its trading during renovation and extensions of the kiosk premises and it sought a five year extension of the licence with a further five year option as compensation. Council responded by extending the licence for a further three years. Audit has commented that there was no consideration of a possible review of rental arrangements or of a stipulation as a condition to the extension of the licence that the licensee forego any claim. Audit commented further that Council was not advised to discuss the option of inviting tenders as part of normal business practices.

4.232 In its comments to Audit the Memorial has stated that the extension was not on the basis of compensation but as an act of good will as recorded in the Council minute and that in the circumstances the Memorial did not consider the need to seek legal advice. Audit says it does not consider the Memorial's response as adequate justification for not having sought an increase in the business rental for an expanded and refurbished kiosk.

4.233 My concern is to point out that in any transaction of this nature the administration of the Memorial should have given more comprehensive advice, including consideration of the options, to the Council. I note, however, that at the time the administration did obtain legal advice about the terms of extension.
Item 29: Australian War Memorial Foundation

4.234 On 29 May 1986, following a submission from Council member Mr Wright, Council approved the establishment of the Australian War Memorial Foundation Incorporated in order to enhance the development of the Memorial. At the start of their investigation Audit questioned the administration about the legal authority for the Memorial to establish a limited liability company; as to how it would ensure that the body would operate within the scope of the AWM Act; and whether the proposed loan of $40,000 to the Foundation, which Council had also approved, was in accordance with the requirements of the Act. In reply the Memorial advised Audit that since the Council approval legal advice had been obtained which indicated that the loan contemplated is not within the authority of the Act and therefore the memorial was seeking further legal opinion. The Auditor-General did not pursue this matter in his report to the Minister.

4.235 However I asked questions of the Director in an effort to determine whether this was a case in which the Council had been placed in the position of making a decision based on inadequate advice from the Director. Acknowledging that the submission came from a member of Council, I asked whether the Director had made any recommendation about the matter to Council, had sought any legal advice in advance, and if so had made that known at the Council meeting or had taken any action subsequently to determine whether there was any legal impediment. I also asked whether this was a matter about which the Council should have informed the Minister and whether the Director had offered any advice to Council on that particular issue. Finally I asked him whether he agreed that the Council had been asked to make a decision based on inadequate advice from the Director.

4.236 My questions were put and answered before the Auditor-General's report of 30 October was available. In reply the Director has pointed out that it appeared that the details of Mr Wright's proposal were not circulated with the joint copies of agenda material and there was not sufficient time to seek legal advice before the meeting. However he had discussed the matter with an officer of the Secretariat some time later and had directed him to seek legal advice. The Director pointed out further that Mr Wright's paper indicated that the Minister was aware of and supported the proposal. The Director did not regard the Council as having been put in the position of making a decision based on inadequate advice from him.

4.237 In my view this proposed venture was a significant development with potential for a substantial impact over time on the affairs of the Memorial. In a case such as this the administration of the Memorial, and not simply the Director, should have ensured that the Council was aware of the need to consider its legal capacity before approving such an arrangement. Having established its capacity to act, a decision to proceed should have been conveyed to the Minister by the Chairman.
Other Matters in the Auditor-General's Report

4.238 The Auditor-General has told the Minister that he is considering scheduling in the near future a `project' audit which is a more detailed review of the accounts and records and which, in the case of the Memorial, would focus primarily on management practices in regard to the acquisition and conservation of the collection. I see such a review as helpful to the Memorial.

4.239 Elsewhere the Auditor-General draws attention to deficiencies in workshop job control and recommends corrective action. In this context Audit identified a private job which had been completed in the Memorial workshop. It noted Memorial advice that there had been an unwritten policy for some years to permit workshop staff to use Memorial facilities in their own time for private non-commercial jobs which must be under the strict supervision of the foreman. Audit advised that a policy of this sort should be formally documented and promulgated to ensure that there is no private use of Memorial facilities during work time or private use of Memorial consumable materials or avoidance of taxes.
4.240 I have taken the Audit comment about private job control into account in my conclusions in Chapter 5 about private authorship and outside employment.

4.241 The Auditor-General has also noted that the Director, who has a delegation from Council to fix discounts for sale of commercial stock, has himself issued a delegation to the Commercial Operations Manager of the authority to set some discounts. Audit sees this as a contravention of the provisions governing the power of delegation in the Act and the Memorial has replied that this authority will not be exercised by the Commercial Operations Manager until it is given by Council.

4.242 Elsewhere at Item 7 I discuss the purchase of the Commemorative Port for the Memorial. Audit has noted the settlement in September 1985 of this longstanding dispute by the payment of $2,250 and has concluded that the practice of ordering goods without appropriate documentation had contributed to the confusion surrounding the delivery of the port and the subsequent claim by the wine merchant.
4.243 I have no comment on the other particular matters dealt with in the Auditor-General's report.
Chapter 5
CONSIDERATION OF ISSUES AND CONCLUSIONS
5.1 In this chapter I identify issues for consideration arising out of my examination of the various matters in Chapter 4 and my other enquiries. I then arrive at conclusions.
Interpretation of the terms of reference in my dealings with the Director

5.2 The Terms of Reference are not directed primarily at criticism of action by the Director. Nevertheless a large number of items put before me, some of which are anonymous in origin, are of that character. I have faced a difficulty in reconciling the general nature of paragraph 1 of the Terms of Reference with the process for arriving at adverse findings about an individual.

5.3 I have had to consider which particular matters can be determined by establishment of the facts and which require also the interpretation of events or of the actions of those involved. Some of the matters raised do not carry sufficient degree of specification to enable concrete propositions to be put to an individual in order that that person might be able to respond. In this situation I have had to weigh up carefully the information put before me. I have had to have regard also to the facilities and time reasonably available to me.

5.4 Before reaching conclusions I had to deal with differences of opinion with the Director about what constitutes specific allegations with particular reference to paragraph 4 of the terms of reference. Over the period 28 to 30 October I had nominated to him the following as covering a range of specific allegations that I was investigating in respect of him:
The provision of inadequate or misleading advice to the Minister:

the events nominated by the Minister-the Heaton letter; purchase of the warehouse; review of the top structure; the timing and presentation of the Annual Report for 1984-85; the eastern staircase; and the ceremony in connection with the proclamation of the Veterans' Entitlement Act.
The provision of inadequate advice to the Council:
the proposed establishment of the Australian War Memorial Foundation.
The making of a false statement to a Commonwealth Authority:
acquisition of a the B25 Mitchell Bomber.
The making of a false statement to the Executive Committee and also to the then Minister:
transfer of bank accounts.
The provision of inadequate advice to the Minister; failure to follow proper procedures in filling positions and in the relative distribution of staff; his responsibility for poor morale among staff:
instances put forward by staff pertaining to Items 18-21.

5.5 The Director has answered my questions throughout the Inquiry and sometimes has made submissions to me. In the case of the last item listed above, on 4 November he rejected the criticism from staff sources and sought the facility to be present and to question witnesses before I took any evidence from those whom he understood to be the source. I was not obliged to do this and I informed the Director on 6 November that I required no further information from him about this matter and would take his response into account in arriving at conclusions.
5.6 That particular group of questions covers matters about which I have had to weigh up conflicting advice and opinion. It is very much in the area of value judgments.

5.7 On 4 November the Director also questioned my assessment that the first item listed above (the group of six items nominated by the Minister) constituted specific allegations. The Minister had stated that this sequence of events `has led me to the view that the Memorial Director has on a number of occasions provided me with inadequate and misleading advice, and has therefore jeopardised the proper conduct of my ministerial responsibilities'.

5.8 While the Director has answered my questions on the first group of items from the Minister, on 4 November he told me he could not regard the Minister's letter of 16 October and its attachments as providing him with specific allegations. He requested that if, after having considered his answers, I believed there were any specific allegations I should provide him with further and better particulars about each of those six events in accordance with a schedule of questions he presented to me.

5.9 I was not prepared to do as the Director suggested. I was satisfied on the basis of the information available out of my investigation, including the answers given by the Director, that I have pursued those various matters sufficiently and had provided sufficient opportunity for the Director and others to respond. My reply to the Director on 6 November covered this matter also.

5.10 I believe I was justified in moving on to complete my inquiries and to reach conclusions both in respect of the conduct of the Director and of the broader management of the Memorial, and to complete this report.
Issues concerning the Director

5.11 The principal issues which arise from the investigation in respect of the Director are whether he has provided inadequate or misleading information to the Minister; whether he has made false statements; whether he has provided inadequate advice to Council and whether there has been a deterioration in internal working relationships and of morale amongst staff of the Memorial, for which he carries substantial responsibility. All of these matters have an impact on a judgment about his management performance.

5.12 To begin it must be noted that during the term of the present Director the major building program has been completed, a number of galleries have been opened, the Mitchell warehouse acquired, further major acquisitions realised, work has commenced on a separate administration building, together with a very large increase in the number of visitors.

5.13 Through his dedication and energy the Director has contributed significantly to the development of the Memorial and its administration and has represented the Memorial most effectively in public. It has to be acknowledged that while the Director carries the responsibility for decisions taken and for advice offered to the Council and the Minister, he must rely on the advice and support he receives in a number of situations.

5.14 I take each of the issues in turn, but recognise that they are inter-related and that in a number of respects conclusions need to be based on consideration of the total picture. My references to individual items need to be related back to what is said in Chapter 4.
Inadequate or Misleading Advice to the Minister

5.15 Each of the six items nominated by the Minister does involve inadequate or misleading advice to him. The Heaton letter, the eastern stairway and the VEA ceremony/bulletin issues were the subject of Parliamentary questions in which the Minister faced some difficulty and was not helped by the nature of advice given him by the Director. The misleading explanation about the delay in the tabling of the 1984-85 Annual Report appears to have been the fault of staff rather than of the Director himself. The answer given to the question about Mrs Darling's status on the Council was part of a composite answer prepared finally in the Department.
