The fault there seems to lie with Memorial staff members rather than with the Director.

5.16 The information given to the Minister about the building rather than the purchase of a warehouse, and in seeking his support for a top structure review was misleading also. While there was no direct communication with the Parliament at the time, the issues in both cases were important to the Minister's relationships with his colleagues in the Government, and the warehouse issue, at least, could have drawn comment in the Parliament.

5.17 As events developed from the end of 1985 into 1986 the Director should have been on his guard in the knowledge that the Minister was looking carefully at, and taking advice from his Department on, material coming to him from the Memorial.
Making a False Statement

5.18 I am satisfied that the Director made false statements both to the executive Committee and to the then Minister in the middle of 1983 when he said that he had contacted other banks to ascertain what options were available to him before recommending transfer of the Memorial's accounts from the Commonwealth to Westpac. His failure in this respect was compounded by the answers he gave to me in the processes of my Inquiry. This matter was clearly his personal responsibility. There appears to be a similar situation with the statement he made in a letter to the Department of Aviation about ownership of the B25 Mitchell Bomber. He has argued that the intention was for the AWM to have at least, what he called, equitable ownership of the aircraft and if there had been any doubt he would have sought another form of agreement. I regard the provisions of the agreement as quite clear and cannot understand how he could have assumed otherwise, or not have been aware of the likely impact of his statement on the level of charges to be made by Aviation.
Inadequate Advice to Council

5.19 This matter comprehends advice to the Chairman in her dealings with the Minister as well. With the top structure proposals, while the Director explained the nature of the Public Service Board's responses when she was asked to sign the two letters to the Minister, I believe he exercised bad judgment in not recommending that she declare this situation to the Minister. Information was given to the Council about the warehouse and the transfer of bank accounts in terms similar to that given to the Minister. The Arthur Young report has thrown up a number of matters of which the Council and the Research and Publications Committee were not properly informed, but the weight of responsibility for that situation must be shared with staff members, not simply the Director. I believe the Director was personally deficient in not ensuring that the Council had advice about its legal capacity to establish the proposed foundation and to make an interest free loan to it. There remains a general need for better information to Council and its Committees.
Deterioration in Internal Work Relations and Morale for which the Director Carries Substantial Responsibility

5.20 As indicated in Chapter 4 these matters require a general assessment of information and comments and the application of personal judgment to the state of morale. The morale of the staff cannot be judged simply in global terms. It is necessary to consider morale among broad groups or even individuals within the Memorial staff. At one extreme I find a group of people in Research and Publications Branch, including its head, who have completely lost sympathy with the Director and, I believe, he with them also. At the other extreme the staff in the workshops and in the security force speak highly of the Director, of the effectiveness of his management and of their excellent personal relations with him. In between there are people, primarily in the Conservation and Curatorial areas, who feel aggrieved and professionally concerned about the Memorial and its assets because of the way the Director has dealt with their advice and treated work they have done.

5.21 There are some staff members who are anxious about their individual situation and not always because of the Director. Throughout the organisation there is a strong measure of commitment to the Memorial and its ideals.

5.22 The War Memorial is not a large organisation and it has been treated relatively well with staff and other resources in recent times. Its Director is entitled to loyalty from staff even where he exercises his right to disagree with advice or to change his mind. For effective administration such action needs to be handled with sensitivity, and if there is not mutual respect and understanding, there needs to be reporting back as to reasons and acknowledgment of the value of the advice received.
Management Performance

5.23 The grounds for criticism of the Director reflect very much on his management style. He has to his credit complete commitment to the Memorial, energy and enthusiasm and a wish that things should be done promptly. However he has failed to maintain the support of significant elements of the staff because of capricious decision making and the lack of attention to two-way communication within the administration. He has exercised poor judgment on a number of occasions including an over-reliance, from time to time, on one or another individual who has been given wide responsibilities. He has failed to give sufficient attention to following the rules on things that matter. He has attempted to make himself the sole channel of communication with the Council and has abandoned section head meetings as being of no value where he ought to have tried to develop them as positive channels for the two-way communication of information and ideas. He has not paid sufficient attention to record keeping on significant matters, but he shares that deficiency with the administration of the Memorial in general.
5.24 He has not managed to weld the new corps of professionally trained people with the old.
The Behaviour of the Director

5.25 The primary responsibility of the Director of the Australian War Memorial is to manage it from day to day and to assist the Council to manage its affairs through policy development and advice. Adequate and timely information flow is essential so that Council may be fully aware of events and circumstances. The Director must acknowledge and give attention to his responsibility to the Minister, through the Council. The Minister has a right to know. The Director's role is essentially that of a manager who need not necessarily have a background as a museologist or an exserviceperson.

5.26 I conclude that there are serious weaknesses in the management performance of the present Director. This represents a value judgment by me and is a considered view, arrived at in accordance with the Terms of Reference as discussed at the beginning of this chapter.

5.27 If some of the unfortunate attributes he has displayed in carrying out his duties had been tempered to a degree, the adverse impact on the morale of a significant number of professional staff members and on their commitment to work in co-operation for the enrichment of the Memorial, could have been avoided.

5.28 Nevertheless, the Director is entitled to respect from the Memorial staff at all levels for his authority and responsibilities. This has not always been forthcoming to the extent that it should have been, even in the face of differences or difficulties.

5.29 I conclude that in a number of cases, insufficient or misleading information has been given to the present Minister, but not so as to cause him serious embarrassment in the public arena. It has given the Minister serious cause for concern and grounds to lack confidence in the advice he receives from the Director.

5.30 I acknowledge that some of the less than full and frank provision of information to the Minister, and to a degree to the Council also, may well be due to carelessness by officers or loose administrative practice in the Memorial. In particular the practice of having material for the Minister, including answers to Parliamentary Questions, prepared in the Secretariat without full documentation and without reference back to the operating areas concerned, is bound to lead to problems.

5.31 From my investigations there was a serious deficiency by the Director in the way he carried out his duties in respect of the false information provided to the then Minister in answer to a Parliamentary Question in 1983 about the transfer of the Memorial's bank accounts, a circumstance which was compounded in the Director's response to my inquiries. There is also the possibility of a false declaration having been made by the Director to the Department of Aviation about the ownership of the B25 Mitchell Bomber with loss to the Commonwealth revenue. That particular matter may well need consideration in another forum.

5.32 I cannot conclude from this Inquiry that there exists misbehaviour by the Director in the terms of Section 24 (1) of the AWM Act as I understand that provision. I do not find a deliberate intention by the Director to transgress in carrying out his duties. Rather in some situations I have concluded that the Director has displayed a less than satisfactory level of competence and a carelessness in expression where the circumstances demanded truthfulness.
Private Authorship and Outside Employment

5.33 As noted in Chapter 4, Arthur Young have drawn attention to cases of private authorship by Memorial staff which under the outside employment provisions of the Public Service Act require approval. Such approval, if given, appears not to have been documented. They have noted also cases in which the fact of private authorship was not disclosed in material put before the Council or the Research and Publications Committee.

5.34 Such research activity by Memorial staff needs to be assessed against the background of the developments in practice over time of the application of the outside employment provisions of the Public Service Act. With an institution like the Memorial particular consideration needs to be given to the status of officers whose duties involve a substantial research element. Furthermore, under its statute the Memorial is directed to assist in research and disseminating information about its field of interest. The Council has given weight to those activities in its corporate objective.

5.35 Council and Research and Publications Committee records demonstrate support and encouragement to staff to maintain and develop research activity together with a small element of direct financial support in particular circumstances. However, in material coming forward from the administration there often is no clear indication of whether a particular research or publication activity is official or private or indeed whether a publication is research-oriented or for popular consumption.

5.36 My examination of the instances referred to in the Arthur Young Report shows that there was a substantial level of approval, but not completely so, and that there was a lack of documentation about approval and any associated conditions. In some cases a small degree of staff and resource assistance with private publications has been acknowledged. What I failed to find was a clear understanding amongst those concerned of a need to seek and obtain specific approval for individual cases of private authorship and publication before undertaking them.
5.37 While the internal auditors were concerned with activities by some members of the Research and Publications Branch, the situation exists also for officers employed as curators and conservators.

5.38 There have been instances where administrative directions about these activities have been promulgated throughout the Memorial. In 1983 a Code of Ethics was endorsed by the Research and Publications Committee and by Council. This drew attention to the code of conduct applicable to both statutory office-holders and to Public Service staff. Among other things, it laid down that officers should avoid conflict between private interests and public duty, should disclose those interests where conflict might occur with a view to obtaining approval, or should divest themselves of those interests; and that scholarly publication and other scholarly endeavour undertaken as part of their duties was the property of the Memorial.

5.39 Also in 1983 Administrative Circular 10/83 addressed research assistance to be available to Memorial staff. Against the background of encouraging staff to undertake research, it set down guidelines approved by the Director. However those guidelines cover research undertaken as part of official duties and towards the acquisition of higher formal academic qualifications as well as for private research. The emphasis is on limited support from the institution with not a great deal of development of the circumstances in which private research might be undertaken.

5.40 More recently, by Administrative Circular 6/86 of 6 May 1986 the Director instructed staff that they would require his personal prior approval before undertaking writings, either on behalf of the Memorial or as a private venture. He emphasised that for private publications no Memorial resources should be used without the specific approval of the Director and this extended to a range of support staff, equipment and services. He related this instruction to the code of conduct applicable to Public Servants. This circular did not address other areas of outside employment.

5.41 The May 1986 instruction brought a reaction from members of the Memorial's Consultative Committee-its industrial democracy forum-and resulted in their consideration of a draft alternative Administrative Circular which was presented to that Committee towards the end of August 1986, by which time some of the difficulties which led to this Inquiry were well known within the institution.

5.42 I find the Consultative Committee's draft statement on outside employment and conflict of interest deficient in its treatment of research-related activity and publications. It first addresses non-job-related outside employment such as driving a taxi at night or writing articles for a particular magazine under contract, for which it requires formal application and permission. However, in the area of research and related publications the draft takes a quite limited form by simply questioning whether occasional production of books or articles for publication in the officer's own time actually constitutes employment. It states that where such external publications is relevant to the activities of the Memorial, it would be courteous to advise the Director. It further states that scholarly activities are generally to be encouraged and that ownership of material prepared solely in personal time remains with the staff member. It is silent about any requirement for advice and prior approval.

5.43 In the interests of the Memorial and its staff, it is essential for the Council to approve a set of principles governing outside employment in all aspects with particular reference to research and research-related publications. Such principles should recognise the interest of the Memorial in advancing the professional standing of its staff and in promoting research into and understanding about Australian military history. There needs to be recognition also that persons, including public servants, operating in areas of research and related academic endeavour do not base their official duties on hours of work or indeed on the place of work. Even so, there need to be clearly understood arrangements under which all private activity of this nature is to be approved in advance in order to ensure that appropriate attention is directed towards official duties and so that some measure of control can be exercised over the nature and level of outside activity related to those duties. Furthermore, approval should be within the discretion of the director or his delegate and not be regarded as an entitlement.

5.44 While the discussion here has concentrated on research and publications as an element of outside employment, similar considerations apply to instances of private practice by say, conservators, and to the use of workshops and other facilities other than for official purposes. In each of these cases, guidelines should be stated clearly, channels of approval should be known, and instances of approval documented. If this is done, there is less likely to be misunderstanding about the distinction which needs to be made between staff using facilities of the Memorial for private purposes with approval, and making their personal, professional or skilled services available to others outside hours and off Memorial premises.
5.45 It would be helpful to full understanding and acceptance of these proposed arrangements for the Consultative Committee to be associated with the developments of the details.

5.46 I note here and endorse the Auditor-General's advice that there should be a formally approved, documented and promulgated policy on the use by workshop staff of Memorial facilities in their own time for private non-commercial jobs. Assuming the Council adopts such a policy, the arrangements should ensure that there is strict supervision by the foreman; private use is not made of Memorial facilities during worktime; Memorial consumable materials are not used for private purposes; and taxes, e.g. sales tax on materials used are not avoided.
Publications policy and procedure

5.47 In Chapter 4, under matters raised by the internal auditors and elsewhere in Chapter 5 under Private Authorship and Outside Employment, I have considered matters arising from the Arthur Young Report about practices for the approval and subsequent development of proposed publications. I now address the need which I see for some clarification and codification of both policy and practice in publications activity.
5.48 Relevant matters include:
The use of the Director's delegation to carry through to finality a publication once it has been approved and subject to the availability of funds.
The nature of the financial report to the Research and Publications Committee.
The distinction between an official Memorial publication and a publication that is purchased for resale by Commercial Operations.
Relationships with publishers.
Information to Council and Research and Publications Committee about any private authorship by Memorial staff.
Procedures for assessment of manuscripts as part of the process for initial and final approval of a publication.
The suitability of the content of material going forward to Council and Research and Publications Committee in these matters.

5.49 The present arrangements should be reviewed between the Research and Publications Committee and the Research and Publications Branch so that proposals can be developed for final consideration and decision by Council.
Relationship between the Council, the Director and the Minister

5.50 Against the background of the investigations I now give particular attention to terms of reference 1 (b)-management of the affairs of the Memorial; and whether the Chairman and the Minister are being properly informed by the administration about the management of those affairs. I outline the situation as I see it.
5.51 The Council has control of, and is responsible for, policy formulation and for general directions to the Director. It has oversight of the Director in his handling of day to day matters.

5.52 Council members are the trustees for the Nation's interest in the Memorial. In our system they discharge this general responsibility and associated specific statutory obligations by reporting through the Minister to the Parliament. The Minister is entitled to information about the affairs of the Memorial and to receive this from the Council. The Minister should not seek to intrude or feel obliged to do so. If the Council keeps the Minister in touch with developments and shows sensitivity to Government policy developments which apply to the Memorial there ought not to be conflict between the Council and the Minister.

5.53 The Memorial is not a Commonwealth Department and the Council has independent status. Even so the relationship between the principal parties-the Council, the Minister and the Director-is not limited to the formal structures. A fruitful and harmonious relationship can exist only where there are regular exchanges and meetings, at least between the Chairman and the Minister, and, on day to day matters which need reference to the Minister, between the Minister and the Director. The Director should advise the Chairman about matters to be taken up with the Minister by the Chairman and should keep the Chairman informed about exchanges between the Director and the Minister. A healthy relationship cannot be preserved if interaction is limited to crisis situations.
5.54 Council needs to demonstrate cohesion in carrying out its tasks and should lay down guidelines on major issues affecting the day to day operations of the Memorial.

5.55 The Director is responsible for running the Memorial under the general policy direction and oversight of the Council. He and the Chairman provide the link, particularly between meetings of Council. The Director needs to ensure that there is an adequate and timely flow of information to the Council and through the Council to the Minister. He will not succeed in this task unless he acknowledges the responsibilities of the Council to the Minister, and in public service matters, his own responsibility to the Minister.

5.56 The Director and senior staff carry the responsibility to ensure that Council is aware of the things that matter and at the time that matters. It would be beneficial if branch heads were regular attenders at Council meetings. I am not suggesting that they should all be there all the time or that the Council should be denied a measure of privacy in their deliberations. I do see increased understanding by the Council and a greater awareness among staff of Council's wishes being generated through such an association. The opportunity should also be given to Council members, in association with their attendance at Council and Committee meetings, to interact with staff and functional areas in the work environment. Members of Council are chosen for the knowledge and experience they can bring to Memorial affairs and they should be encouraged to share it with the Memorial family.

5.57 Events of the past year have produced tension and reserve between the Council and the Minister. Some rather extreme positions have been taken on each side, in particular over the issues concerning amendments to the Act. The Council has been slow and cautious in its responses to the Minister. I see regular consultation and exchange of views as a way to restore that relationship to a level of effective co-operation; legislative changes are not the answer.

5.58 In the course of the Inquiry I have noticed instances in which the Minister had discussions with staff members without prior or subsequent knowledge of the Chairman or the Director. One was an interview in July with a staff member shortly before the Director was confronted by the Minister about the circumstances of the staff bulletin issue. In my view the Director should have been informed. The other was a meeting with a small group of concerned staff following the Council's decision in early September that there was no prima facie case for the Director to answer about his behaviour. In the latter case the Minister could not be expected not to receive a deputation, but he might have been expected to follow up the assertions they made with, in the circumstances of the time, the Chairman rather than the Director. Situations such as these should not occur when a positive climate of co-operation between the Minister, the Council, and the Director is restored.

5.59 It is appropriate to comment here too on an effective and supportive role for the Minister's Department-the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The Department has been helpful to the Memorial in a number of important matters since the transfer of the function to their Minister's portfolio at the end of 1984. The joint efforts of the Minister and the Department produced additional financial and staffing resources for the Memorial and the Department has assisted with staff exchanges and specialist support.

5.60 In the current strained situation the Department is assisting the Minister in monitoring the activities of the Council and the Director. It is somewhat unfortunate that in the early days following the transfer of ministerial responsibilities there was no joint consultation among the Minister, the Chairman, the Director and the Secretary of the Department to work out an effective liaison. In my view it is appropriate and desirable for the Department to advise the Minister in the ordinary course of business on the more important matters coming forward from a statutory authority, particularly those to do with the Minister's relationship with the Parliament. It is critical that all parties have an understanding about the arrangements.

5.61 The development of on-going co-operation among all of these parties-the Minister, the Chairman and Council, the Director and the Departmental Head-will be a significant factor in restoring the management of the affairs of the Memorial and the discharge of the Memorial's responsibilities to a satisfactory level.
Should the AWM Act be amended?

5.62 The terms of reference (paragraph 1 (d)) require me to consider whether there are any deficiencies in the AWM Act of 1980 as it affects management of the affairs of the Memorial and the relationships between the Director, the Council, and the Minister. I have done so against the background of my investigations and have taken into account specific proposals for amendment now current from the Council, with the support of the Director, and from the Minister.

5.63 It is relevant to recall some of the major characteristics of the present Act which came into force in 1980. The Council was created as a successor to a former Board of Trustees and, through incorporation and other provisions, was given ownership and control of land and buildings and other assets and control of funds, including the AWM Fund. Following representation from those trustees, the then government deleted from the draft bill, a provision for a general power for the Minister to give written directions to Council. The Parliament did not insert such a provision. It is worth noting that, at about that time, an act was passed to establish what was then called the Museum of Australia and contained such a power of ministerial direction.

5.64 By way of further contrast, the AWM Act provides for the members to elect the Chairman and does not make the Director a member of the Council. What is now the National Museum Act, provides for the Chairman to be appointed by the Governor-General in Council, and makes the Director an appointed member of Council. There are parallel provisions to this latter arrangement in the legislation governing other similar institutions.

5.65 To me, this distinction in treatment for the AWM expresses an intention for the Council to have a substantial degree of independence. However, even without specific provision, the Council is subject to certain restraints and obligations in its relationship with the Minister. Given the Minister's constitutional responsibilities, the Council is required to provide information to him beyond the limited areas set down in the Act. Even so, relationships between the governing body of a Commonwealth authority and the responsible Minister, do not depend entirely on the enabling legislation. There are wider questions of relationships and responsibilities which depend upon the establishment and maintenance of effective communication and understanding between the parties. These relationships and responsibilities extend to the chief executive officer also. That person must play a key role in exchanging information and fostering understanding among the three parties.

5.66 In looking at questions of possible amendment to the Act, I have considered also the contents of a Policy Discussion Paper tabled in the Parliament on behalf of the government in June 1986. That sets down proposed guidelines for ordinary statutory authorities-other than marketing authorities (para 1.17, page 4). These include-
The authority's relationship with the responsible Minister, its governing board and other government agencies will be specified clearly in legislation.
The authority's charter, its reporting obligations and its procedures for funding and financial management also will be specified clearly in legislation.
Ministerial powers of direction, when used, will be in writing, and will be reported in the authority's annual report to Parliament.
Financial and reporting arrangements will be standardised.
Revised arrangements governing the creation and control of subsidiaries of statutory authorities will be adopted, including requirements for ministerial approval and notification to Parliament.
As appropriate to the circumstances of individual bodies, `sunset' provisions will be included in the authorities' enabling legislation.
5.67 I have noted other statements in that discussion paper which I believe are relevant:-
An acknowledgment that the degree of exemption from ministerial control depends upon the nature of the functions which justified its establishment outside the departmental framework.
Areas of independence and those subject to ministerial control should be clearly and precisely specified.
Even when independence is specified, the Minister will normally monitor activities and in doing so needs to be kept informed regularly about those activities.

Historically, a power of ministerial direction has been used as a power of last resort to clarify differences of opinion between a Minister and an authority. The paper postulates, however, that there is scope for the constructive use of a power of direction as a means of improving communication between a Minister and a particular authority.
In a general sense, and irrespective of whether there are expressed powers of direction, statutory authorities should take account of relevant government policies.

Specific provisions requiring the authority to present an annual report to the Minister to be tabled in both Houses of Parliament represent the centrepiece of accountability and are an essential component of enabling legislation.

5.68 I have noted also that the guidelines envisage provisions for the suspension or termination of an appointment before a term of office has expired, which appear to be substantially more comprehensive in scope than those contained in the AWM Act (para 2.25, page 11).

5.69 Relevant to my purpose too, is the view in the proposed policy guidelines that from time to time departmental officers will be appointed as members of governing bodies. Attention is drawn to the need to exercise special care to avoid conflict of responsibility and loyalty between the officer's position as a member of the authority and as an officer of the department.

5.70 I have outlined these various provisions of the proposed policy guidelines to demonstrate that there are a number of considerations involved in a decision as to how the relationships between the principal parties should be reflected in legislation.

5.71 In my view, in most cases where an authority has been created to exercise a trustee role on behalf of the nation-which I believe to be the case with the AWM Council-it is undesirable that there be a statutory power for general or specific directions by the Minister. However, that view needs to be seen against the general policy objectives of the present government for ordinary statutory authorities. One has also to weigh up whether the present difficulties in relationships among the Minister, the Council and the Director are such that changes need to be made to the statutory provisions. No doubt it will be generally accepted that if there is to be such a power, its application should involve written directions and specific reference in the Annual Report to that circumstance and to the governing body's response.
5.72 I turn now to the list of amendments to the AWM Act which currently have the endorsement of the Council or the Minister.

5.73 The Council, with advice from the Director, has proposed that the position of Director be redesignated `Director General' and that the threshold figures for ministerial approval of certain Council action be brought up to date by way of an ongoing regulation making provision. The Minister has indicated his endorsement of these amendments for introduction in association with proposed amendments of his own. Further amendments proposed by the Minister are for the Minister to have power to issue directions to the Council relating to its management of the Memorial; to have power to seek information from the Council relating to its activities, and for the appointment of the Secretary of the Department of Veteran Affairs as ex-officio member of Council. I understand that the Minister has deferred, for the present, an approach to the Parliament seeking approval to changes to the Australian War Memorial Act.
5.74 I offer my own view of these proposals.
5.75 The proposed changes in measures for determining threshold figures for which ministerial approval is required, are sensible and non-controversial and I support them.

5.76 I do not support the redesignation of the chief executive officer's position to `Director General'. I see that designation as, in itself, rather outmoded, and if comparisons are to be made with the chief executives of other institutions in the family of cultural institutions, I regard the National Museum of Australia and the Australian National Gallery as more relevant than either the National Library or the Australian Archives. Nor can I accept the argument that such redesignation would facilitate recognition of the multi-purpose character of the Memorial and would facilitate an upgrading of senior executive positions immediately below the Director. That particular issue should be determined on its own merits. Furthermore, given my proposal elsewhere for an organisation and management review of the Memorial's administration, any such change now would be premature.

5.77 As indicated above, the Minister's proposal for a specific power to demand information is unnecessary, given his constitutional rights in that regard. Furthermore, against the background of the conclusions I have arrived at on other matters within the Terms of Reference, I am not persuaded that a statutory power of direction is essential to correct present difficulties and I would see the addition of either of these proposed powers as appropriate only in the context of the Parliament's approval of a comprehensive approach from the Government following confirmation of the thrust of its proposed policy guidelines which are now out for public discussion.

5.78 I do not support the Minister's proposal for the appointment of the Secretary of his Department to the Council in the form in which it has been put forward. I appreciate that there is now and has been a significant number of cases in which departmental secretaries serve as members of important statutory authorities within their Minister's portfolio, some of them ex-officio. My own preference in circumstances where a statutory body is responsible for a cultural or academic institution, is that any office of the Minister's Department appointed to such a body should be someone other than the secretary and should be seen to be one of those persons appointed for the knowledge and experience he or she can bring as an individual, not as a representative of the department. In this way, the key responsibility of the departmental secretary for giving advice to his Minister on any matter within ministerial responsibility will not be compromised. My reading of the relevant provisions of the proposed policy guidelines (paras 2.27-2.30, pages 11-12) lends support to this view.

5.79 For the Memorial, I do not see a parallel between the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Chiefs of Staff who are ex-officio members of Council. Their relationship with the affairs of the Memorial has a particular character reflected in the Memorial's Charter which is not shared by the head of the department.

5.80 Therefore, in this particular matter, I would prefer any officer from the Department of Veterans' Affairs appointed to the AWM Council to be a senior officer, not the Secretary, and for any such appointment to be made from among the number of ordinary members.

5.81 I note the fact that under the Australian War Memorial Act the Council has the power to delegate the exercise of functions to a member, and I mention that there may well be circumstances which warrant some delegation to the Chairman to be exercised between meetings of Council.

5.82 Finally I note that in that Arthur Young report, attention has been drawn to the understanding that the Council has power to delegate authority only to a member, the Director or a member of staff; not to a committee collectively. That appears to be a standard provision in Commonwealth statutory authority legislation and should be considered for change only if legal advice indicates change to be necessary. The Council is free to take administrative action in support of a concept of granting effective authority to a Committee or its Chairman if it so wishes.
A review of management of the memorial
5.83 Here I address action directed particularly to terms of reference (paragraph 1 (a)), internal management of the Memorial, including personnel, financial and general administration.

5.84 A number of the situations reviewed in this report demonstrate the desirability of promoting an improvement in the internal administration and management of the Memorial. However the need for improvement does not rest on the shoulders of a single individual nor is it due to any limited range of circumstances. An improvement in the performance of the administration and an enhancement of staff morale will flow on from greater attention by top management to consultation and feedback processes from improved record keeping and from enhanced communication. The latter should include regular meetings of section heads, serious attention to the industrial democracy plan and process and a higher profile for bodies such as the Exhibitions Planning Coordination Committee which cut across branch boundaries.
5.85 The Director must set the scene. However the task of putting those arrangements into place will rest heavily on middle management, with guidance and support from top management.

5.86 There are proposals outstanding for a reorganisation of the top structure of the Memorial staff together with reallocation of functions among branches. This has been caught up with consideration of proposed amendments to the Act, the proposed redesignation of the Director as `Director-General' and the need for all statutory authorities to pursue more cost effective operations.

5.87 Action taken or contemplated by the Director for changes in the internal organisation of the Memorial may have been misconstrued by some who consider them to be directed towards other objectives. The fact is that there is a good case for reviewing the allocation of some functions and for grouping functions in a way which reflects the essential purpose of the organisation. For example there is an argument for bringing all of the collection resources together and for divesting the Research and Publications Branch of operational activities which could better be placed elsewhere.
5.88 The requirements of Program Budgeting need to be observed, but at this stage of development they should not determine the organisation.

5.89 The organisation of the Memorial should reflect its corporate objectives and ought to be developed as part of an appropriately designed corporate plan. It is not essential for the Committee structure of the Council to parallel the internal organisation structure. Furthermore while any major internal reorganisation should have the support of Council, the task is primarily one for the Chief Executive Officer.

5.90 I believe it would be appropriate for the Memorial to seek the co-operation of the Public Service Board in mounting a Program Management Performance Review. The use of that label does not require a stereo-typed approach or standardised process. What it does entail is a co-operative effort between top management of the Memorial and the Board's Office, perhaps with the involvement of outsiders.

5.91 The starting point should be the Council's corporate objective (see paragraph 2.7 above). The review would be directed towards establishing a strategic direction within a corporate plan. This would entail the development of an associated program structure and organisation and staffing arrangements. The task could also involve measures for assessing program effectiveness and possible improvements in operations. The parties to the arrangement should settle the terms of reference.

5.92 It is critical to the success of such an operation that it have the support and direct involvement of the chief executive officer. Against the background of the current upheaval surrounding the Memorial, it is desirable that this activity be taken up promptly. In follows that there needs first to be a clearing of the air and the creation of a working environment which will foster the pursuit of common purposes between management and staff.
LETTER FROM MINISTER FOR VETERANS' AFFAIRS TO CHAIRMAN OF THE COUNCIL OF THE AUSTRALIAN WAR MEMORIAL
Minister for Veterans' Affairs
Parliament House
Canberra A.C.T. 2600
11 November 1986
Dear Dame Beryl

I agreed in my telephone conversation with you at about 1 pm today that I would not table the report of the Inquiry into the Australian War Memorial in the Parliament today, in order to allow the Council to deliberate in an environment of confidentiality.
However, I am now writing to advise you that I have decided to table the report at the earliest opportunity.

I have been reluctantly forced to this decision because I have learnt that a member of the press has been provided with a copy of the report by a person associated with the Memorial. It has been confirmed to me that the journalist has written a detailed article on the report's content which will appear in a major national daily newspaper tomorrow. I have also been advised that that article is highly selective in its references to the report, and is said to draw conclusions very much at odds with the report's principal findings.

It was certainly my intention to maintain the report's confidentiality, at least until the Council had concluded its deliberations on this matter tomorrow. However, I am sure you will understand that my hand has now been forced in this respect by the actions of another person.
I will be tabling a copy of this letter with the report, and ask that you provide copies to each Council member.
Yours sincerely
(A. T. GIETZELT)
Dame Beryl Beaurepaire, DBE
Chairman of Council
Australian War Memorial
Canberra ACT 2600

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I gave the Chairman of the Council of the War Memorial, Dame Beryl Beaurepaire, an undertaking by phone at approximately 1 p.m. today that I would not table the report today, in order to enable the Council to deliberate on its contents in an environment of confidentiality. However, I have now learned that a member of the Press has been provided with a copy of that report by a person associated with the Memorial and that that journalist has written an article, to appear in a major national daily newspaper tomorrow, on the report's contents. I have also been advised that that article is highly selective in its references to the report and draws conclusions very much at odds with the report's conclusions.

SPEECH.PARA: I also inform the Senate that the report fully vindicates my concerns regarding the administration of the Memorial and my decision to seek the inquiry. It substantiates my concerns on the great majority of the matters that were referred to the inquiry. The report finds that the Director made false statements; that I was provided with inadequate or misleading advice on each of the six matters I referred to him as having the potential to cause me to mislead the Parliament or the Government; that the Director was personally deficient in relation to a number of items; that he was involved in capricious decision-making; that he exercised poor judgment on a number of occasions; that there were serious weaknesses in his management performance; and that false information was provided both to me and to my predecessor as Minister responsible for the Memorial, the Honourable Barry Cohen, MP. I wrote today to the Chairman of the War Memorial Council to advise her of my decision to table the report. I also table a copy of that letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) has apologised because he has been unable to comply with the usual two-hour notice. The Opposition accepts the apology and understands the circumstances in which the Minister felt he had no alternative but to table the report this evening. As a result, the Opposition has had access to this report for only the last seven or eight minutes. The Minister stated that some journalist has written a report in which he has been highly selective in what he has said. It seems to me, with respect, that the Minister has been highly selective in what he has said about the conclusions in the report, because the Minister did not say that Mr Jones, who conducted the inquiry and who is held in high regard on all sides of this chamber, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot conclude from this Inquiry that there exists misbehaviour by the Director in the terms of Section 24 (1) of the Australian War Memorial Act as I understand that provision. I do not find a deliberate intention by the Director to transgress in carrying out his duties. Rather in some situations I have concluded that the Director has displayed a less than satisfactory level of competence and a carelessness in expression where the circumstances demanded truthfulness.

I acknowledge openly that I have been selective in that I have picked out only one paragraph in the summary of conclusions, but it indicates that Mr Jones certainly did not find any evidence of misbehaviour within the terms of the section of the Act. I have not had a chance to look at the section of the Act but I presume that it would be the section contravention of which would warrant dismissal. Senator Gietzelt indicates that that is not so; I am not sure what that means.

Mr Jones, in his report, makes it clear that he believes that this matter could be sorted out administratively by the Minister. I suggest to the Minister that there has been a breakdown in communications and a breakdown in confidence between himself and the Director which have led to a number of problems. Mr Jones says that there are some proposed legislative changes. He supports some of them, but he then states:
I do not support the redesignation of the chief executive officer's position to `Director-General' . . .
He also says:
I do not support the Minister's proposal for the appointment of the Secretary of his Department to the Council in the form in which it has been put forward . . .

I would prefer any officer from the Department of Veterans' Affairs appointed to the AWM Council to be a senior officer, not the Secretary, and for any such appointment to be made from among the number of ordinary members.
Mr Jones then goes on to make this most significant recommendation:
I believe it would be appropriate for the Memorial to seek the co-operation of the Public Service Board in mounting a Program Management Performance Review . . .
Those are some of the significant recommendations to which I refer honourable senators at this stage. In other respects, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.27 to 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: KAKADU NATIONAL PARK PLAN OF MANAGEMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break I was explaining how important the type of country to be declared stage 3 of Kakadu National Park is to Australia. It contains a number of species which are very rare and may be endangered if they are not protected in the correct way. They contain a considerable pool of genetic material which could be extremely important to Australia's economic future. There is already great concern within the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service that erosion caused by pastoral activity in stage 3 of the park is increasing turbidity in the South Alligator River region. This is having a detrimental impact on the existing park. The Coronation Hill mineral deposit, right next to the South Alligator River, is on a steep slope so that, according to reports, run-off can not be adequately contained.

SPEECH.PARA: The plan of management for Kakadu National Park is a responsible plan which does not allow any further mining other than at those mines already in operation. This is in accord with the accepted practice of management of national parks. The definition of national parks by the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers includes this statement:
. . . an area that is a national park should be protected from all interference other than essential management practices.

Mining, I believe, is not an acceptable practice in national parks. The Northern Territory Chamber of Mines in its recent submission to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources inquiry into the potential of the Kakadu National Park region displayed a map showing key mineral resources. The minerals included gold, tin, tantalum and tungsten. Only three such deposits are shown within Kakadu, with a large number of promising sites being shown outside the park. A similar pattern exists for silver, lead, zinc and copper deposits. In fact, most prospects for those minerals are outside the park. It is probably only uranium, gold, and the platinum associated with the gold deposits at Coronation Hill, that are of concern to the mining industry.

I believe that we should initially concentrate on mining resources outside the national park. The mineral sites within Kakadu are not unique, nor is their mining vital to Australia's national interest at present. There is no valid reason for overriding our need to preserve our natural heritage, our plants and wildlife and our genetic pool. Even tourism and education will not be allowed to have deleterious effects on such areas of the park. For this reason it is important to declare stage 3 of the Kakadu National Park as soon as possible.

The area has been described by some people as `clapped out buffalo country'. No one has taken any responsibility for the area for years. It has been overgrazed because neither the departments responsible for pastures and resources nor any other Northern Territory Government department have seen the area as their responsibility. This is because it is due to become a national park. Such open savanna and forest land is becoming increasingly rare throughout the world. This is happening as man encroaches on it more and more in his search for grazing for livestock. We have already turned large tracts of land on the edge of the Sahara in Africa into desert. In South Africa overgrazing is causing great concern for the natural ecology of the open savanna and forest regions in that area. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the Australian Conservation Foundation, which I have shown to both sides of the chamber, that covers some of the dangers associated with gold mining in the South Alligator headwaters.
Leave granted.

Australia 3122
7th November, 1986.
Call for Immediate Declaration of Kakadu Stage III.

The Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation, Mr. Phillip Toyne, said today that the Foundation was reassured that the Federal Government was prepared to take a stand to protect National Estate values in Tasmania's forests.
However he said he was disconcerted that the Prime Minister's commitment to no mining in Kakadu was only for States I and II.

``The Prime Minister himself in announcing the declaration of Stage II recognised the value of having a total catchment included in the Park. On that occasion he said, `Of particular importance is the inclusion in the Park of virtually the whole South Alligator River catchment, with its internationally significant wetlands.' ''

``Gold mining in the South Alligator headwaters of Stage III would threaten these internationally significant wetlands, firstly with cyanide used in processing, and secondly with changes to the ecology because gold processing takes large quantities of water. In the dry season this could be crucial to the Stage II wetlands.''

``For three years the Government has been reassuring the environment movement the area would be immediately added to the Park to complete the Ranger Inquiry recommendations of nine years ago. Why is the Government drawing back from this commitment?''
``The Prime Minister has also acknowledged while visiting Kakadu that there are plenty of minerals outside the Park.''

``The Government should immediately add all of Stage III to the existing Park under the same management plan as Stages I and II. This would allow no mining or prospecting. The area should then be declared World Heritage as has already been recommended by the World Heritage Committee,'' he said.
Joan Staples 47-3013, 472-472.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. We indeed need a quick decision to declare stage 3. The Gimbat and Goodparla pastoral leases should be part of the Kakadu National Park so that the National Parks and Wildlife Service can take responsibility for the management of this area and cut down the damage that has been done by overgrazing. The plateau complex, the southern hills and basins, are an as yet biologically unexplored region containing many species of insects and even many new animal species, such as a marsupial mouse which was reported recently as living in this area. We do not have full details of the flora and fauna which would be recorded in a national data base and protected if the National Parks and Wildlife Service were in charge of the area.

SPEECH.PARA: The stage 3 region, and in fact a large part of the Kakadu National Park, are owned freehold by the traditional Aboriginal owners who have leased their land to the Director of National Parks and Wildlife for the purpose of a national park. The Aboriginal owners will continue to enjoy their traditional use of the land but will be trained in park management and public education and in providing information services for tourists. Recently I visited Kakadu and several Aboriginal communities throughout South Australia and the Northern Territory, including the `refugee camp' at Yalata to which Aborigines from the Maralinga bomb sites were moved. I was able to compare that camp with the communities at Uluru, where Aborigines have been used as park rangers. I was struck by the enormous difference in the outlook between the two camps. At Yalata there were problems of drunkenness, petrol sniffing, uncontrollable youth, and terribly low morale. Some difficulties were due to the large numbers of different communities thrown together, which had led to a breakdown of traditional values. On the other hand, at Uluru, optimism and self-esteem had come through the Aborigines being used in the management of a national park. I believe that this type of thing can be carried on in Kakadu and that we can have happy and constructive Aboriginal communities which will show world tourists that Australia is a very effective country in relation to its indigenous people.

At Uluru there were none of the major social problems of petrol sniffing and alcohol. I believe that the outcome at Kakadu will be just as beneficial to all concerned. In fact, I recommend that the same type of program be introduced at Kakadu. On that note, I wish to commend the management plan to the Senate. It is far from perfect but it is certainly better than having nothing, which is what the Liberal and National parties are proposing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Kakadu National Park plan of management and the decision by the Liberal-National Party to oppose its incorporation and adoption. I find it quite amazing for Senator Vigor to say that stage 3 should be incorporated as a national park. As a matter of fact, I find it quite amazing that all of stage 1 is a national park. I, as a Tasmanian who has been to Kakadu many times, find very little of the park, apart from the obvious areas that I suppose occupy some 20 to 30 per cent of stage 1, to be what I would regard as significant areas. In fact, I think a lot of the Tasmanians who visit the park feel that they have been robbed when they get there after having been shown photographs of very nice areas there. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has put photographs of only seven of these areas into its brochure, although there may be more that it has not found or that it may not want people to go and see anyway. Of course, to have only that number of places in an area that is about one-third the size of Tasmania just proves to the world how insignificant some of them are. It is quite remarkable for people to rush up there to see this area and rave on about it, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has in the last few days. I said to somebody, almost jokingly: `If ever you hear that I am going to Kakadu National Park again, shoot me because you will know that I have gone mad'. I am just trying to emphasise how boring that area is. I do not use the word `boring' very much, even in this place, where a lot of the speeches could be properly described in that way. It is a word that I specially keep to use in the context that it is meant to be used, and I believe that a lot of the Kakadu National Park is like that.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what has happened recently. In the Senate today we heard discussions about the Government's new-found interest in conservation. It was trying to interfere in the logging operations that were taking place, as I see it quite within the agreements that the Federal and State governments had. During the last few days the Prime Minister visited Kakadu, even though he had said prior to going that he would not allow mining in the area. I do not think many people in this country really expected him to go there and to change his mind about it. He went there with a closed mind. I consider that he has found the Northern Territory and Tasmania to be expendable politically. They are virtually of no use to the Prime Minister politically. He may lose one seat in the Northern Territory and he would be lucky to win one in Tasmania at all-I do not think he will in the next election. He went to Kakadu with a closed mind. I think he wrongly anticipates that this country will fall for the kind of left wing rubbish that he has had thrust upon him in that area and in Tasmania. Even the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania, Mr Batt, disagrees with the Prime Minister's interference in Tasmania.

Tonight I want to concentrate on the plan of management, a plan that I have already said was produced by people who I believe have closed minds, a plan that many people have said is flawed in many areas and a plan that has been altered little from the draft, even though the people who sent in submissions pointed out that it was flawed in many areas. I have in my hand a copy of comments and representations concerning Kakadu National Park. Many of these people agree that the area is not worthy of total inclusion. Of course, we would expect the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines to say something like that but, on page 2 of its submission, it states:
. . . there should be a balance between resource development and resource conservation.
We are not seeing a balance in this country at the moment. The Northern Territory Chamber of Mines goes on to state:
As currently worded, the proposals relating to mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu National Park demonstrate clearly that no commitment to balance exists in the Plan of Management.
I will say a little more about that in a moment. The Northern Territory Chamber of Mines, in its submission, also talks about tourism and mining. It states:

It is often conveniently forgotten by those who would place resource conservation before resource development that the original catalyst for the recent tourist interest in the Kakadu area was the privately funded construction of the all-weather road to Jabiru . . .
Of course, we all know that that is the site of the Ranger uranium mine. Further on in this document another letter states, in part:

Lastly we believe it is an insult to the average tourists' intelligence to label much of stage 2 of Kakadu as National Park. This is a dry, dusty, featureless tropical savanna common across Australia.

It is common across northern Australia. It is not unique except in the words that a lot of the conservationists use. They seem to use the words `pristine' and `unique' whenever they are trying to drive a point home. They use those words thinking they will be impressive to some of us whom they think have no intelligence. To me Kakadu is not pristine and it is not unique. Senator Vigor mentioned that there are endangered species. He, scientist that he is, would recognise that, just as an individual within a species has a lifespan, so it is believed by a lot of scientists that species themselves have an allotted lifespan. So we will always have endangered species in this world. The sooner a few people recognise that fact the better off this country will be. Senator Puplick, who is not in the chamber at the moment, made what I believe to be a very balanced statement about his attitude to Kakadu. It was balanced, it was detailed and it dealt in part with the requirement in the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act to include a detailed discussion of mining in that plan of management.

Senator Richardson, who spoke shortly after Senator Puplick, seemed a little lost on just where the boundaries of the stages of the present park are, even though I have been with him to the UDP Falls. He seemed to think that that was in stage 2 of the national park when it is not. Somebody from Tasmania who had just been to the Kakadu National Park thought that UDP stood for undeveloped park and that person was quite surprised when I said that it had something more to do with uranium development than an undeveloped park. Obviously this is the kind of thing that people are trying to get across. They are trying surreptitiously to change the names of all these places. Many people seem to have forgotten that those who wanted to see what minerals were available first went to this area. They built the roads, they were there first and then came the conservationists. Now they are trying to make it look as if the miners are coming in to take over from the conservationists when in fact the opposite happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the miners who suggested the national park.

—That is right. I thank the honourable senator. It was the miners who suggested the national park. People often forget that geologists, who go in first, by no means want to create havoc in the area. I will get on in a moment to what can be done these days in the rehabilitation of areas, many of which I have seen around this country. Senator Richardson seems confused. His confusion has come about because he has found out from some polls that may have been taken by the Australian Labor Party that the greenie vote is going to go to the Democrats. The Labor Party is doing its best to get rid of the Democrats from this place. They are now trying to make sure that they win those votes. They have written off the Northern Territory and Tasmania because they think that they can win a couple of seats in the Volvo socialist areas of Melbourne and Sydney by appealing to the greenies.
—That is pure supposition, Senator.
—It may be supposition, but I am going to stick to it. I will keep saying it.
—They have all got Alsatian dogs.

—My father was a politician before me and he said that if a person throws a few rocks, the dogs start yelping. There was a very good editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning. It was headed `Richardson the populist'. I think it should have said `Senator Richardson the populist' but we will not argue about that. In the last paragraph it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson apparently shares Mr Hawke's intense concern for Kakadu and the environment. But sadly, he seems to lack the Prime Minister's understanding of the economic difficulties facing the Government, and the Treasurer's appreciation of the politics of tax reform. By calling for further changes to the fringe benefits tax, Senator Richardson has given the opponents of the new tax new hope and probably prolonged the noisy, destabilising struggle to have the tax watered down.

I think that that is one of the areas that indicate that he is taking the easy way out in life at the moment. I do not think that many people on the Labor Party Government benches will disagree with me on that. There was an editorial in the Australian today which was headed `Duty of government is governing'. The last paragraph-Senator Richardson always seems to be saved for the last paragraph-stated:
Senator Richardson's comments and some recent Government decisions must raise the suspicion that there is a growing desire within the ALP for electoral victory at any price.

Mr Hawke and his Cabinet colleagues owe it to themselves and to Australia to repudiate Senator Richardson's clumsy suggestions and to reconfirm their commitment to the nation as a whole. Are they really committed to this nation as a whole, or are they out to get Tasmania? Are they out to knock the stuffing out of the Northern Territory? I say that the Government is about to do the latter.
Let us think about the history of this area. What did Mr Fraser say when he set it up as a national park? He said:
We look forward to the time when the management of the region, with its various planned uses, produces an harmonious relationship between the various activities . . .

First of all he mentioned mining, then tourism, park management and environmental protection. Usually politicians put things in the order in which they want to deal with them. I would say that the former Prime Minister understood full well that there was going to be mining in that area. He finished off that statement by saying:
. . . good management and goodwill can lead to natural resources being obtained with a minimum of interference to a region's inhabitants and its environment.

Surely that is the kind of thing this country needs at the moment. We cannot afford any longer to go on with left wing rubbish about locking all sorts of areas up. A letter was incorporated from the Australian Conservation Foundation a moment ago. Without even reading it I know what it says-leave it as a national park. It says it has endangered species-endangered plants, animals, moths and things like that. I point out to Senator Vigor, who may not have had as many dealings with the ACF as I have, that every submission to each of the Senate committees of which I am a member that has ever come from the ACF has said the same things-make it a national park.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they going to do about the natural leeching of heavy metals into the lakes--

—There should be some examination done on that matter. I am not sure that some of the areas where the tourists go are safe. They can sit on the sandstone monument in the grounds of Parliament House. Both Senator Jessop and I know from measuring its radioactivity that it is very radioactive. I think in many ways it would be a safer national park if we removed all the uranium. That is something I will not go into tonight because it is not something we ought to talk about at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us return to the plan of management. It was always intended that exploration and other activities should coexist in the park. The new plan of management is quite different from what would have been expected. It states specifically:
No operations for recovery of minerals will be carried out in the Park except on existing mineral leases.

The Prime Minister has put paid to them as well. The present plan of management does not comply with the requirements of section 8 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. On that ground alone I put it to the Senate that it should not be approved.

Senator Crichton-Browne, who is in the chamber, mentioned the attitude of the Aborigines. He did it very well. I refer people who read my speech to his, because we have both been on a committee that has been looking at the area. I get the impression that the Aborigines really want to have a say in-and rightly so-and benefit from the mining activities there. They want to have a say in the future of their land. I believe that a genuine error of massive proportions has been made by the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority of the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Followed by a cover-up.

—I am not sure from looking at the sacred sites legislation that, having put a sacred site unwittingly in the wrong area, there is any provision for deregistering it. Once a sacred site has been registered, can it be deregistered? I doubt whether that is possible. The Aboriginals have a huge sacred site in an area that I will not mention because I want them to come back and tell me whether I am right or wrong and whether there is any way of getting rid of a sacred site, having once said that it is sacred.

SPEECH.PARA: Keeping in mind what Senator Crichton-Browne has said, the Aboriginals have an expectation that they will benefit from some of the mining activity. They will have a say in their future. Not many of the people who have spoken have mentioned the Aboriginals. I am sorry, Senator Vigor did mention them. I apologise. I was not trying to say that he did not speak about them, but many of the other speakers did not. I believe that the Aboriginals would like to see the commencement of detailed exploration work. I believe that they recognise that the money that they get does not grow on trees and they cannot continue to be given huge amounts of money unless there is some development-of course, I mean sensible development. The Minister mentioned Swiss cheesing the area. Nobody these days wants to do that. I have been to a sand mining area in New South Wales. As one looked along a sand hill which must have been seven or eight kilometres long, one could tell which areas had been sand mined. They looked better than the others; they had been rehabilitated. Somebody will say: `But they trod on a frog and that frog is not there any more'. People will come up with some stupid, left wing reason for saying that, because of that, we should not do anything.

I really think we have to remember that some people are not as stupid as some of the left wingers in the Government of this country. It is time that this country recognised that Mr Hawke is now being run by the left wing group in his Government. He is giving in to everything they want. I am sure that is not what the people of this country want. Today the Australian-I am not using that as the only paper I have read today because it is not the only paper that I have read today-had a quote from Mr Butler on page 3. He said in Darwin yesterday that 75 per cent of stage 2 was not worth heritage listing. He said that large portions of stage 1 also were disaster areas. That comes from a guy who is well respected around the world. He was supported in that statement by another gentleman, a Professor Kenneth Mellanby from Britain, so he did not say it off his own bat. I think we have to recognise that the people of Australia are virtually being robbed by this Government if they allow this whole area to be locked up for the time which the Government would like to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What percentage of the area is under mineral lease?

—I cannot tell the honourable senator the percentage, but I will give him that information tomorrow. We would expect the lease to be somewhere between 1 per cent and 5 per cent. Getting back briefly to the Aboriginals, they are in an area where they could have been of some benefit. The lease could have been granted to the wildlife service, I suppose, but they would not have any say in what would happen to it after that. Under those circumstances it must surely be open to the Aboriginals to refuse to participate in any lease-back arrangement with the Government. With regard to World Heritage listing, I again suggest that Senator Puplick was correct: The way in which the listing was carried out was both underhand and by the back door. It is questionable as to whether stage 2 would qualify for nomination for World Heritage listing if it were proposed in isolation. In fact I would say that it is extremely unlikely.

SPEECH.PARA: The way in which the nomination was carried out was quite dishonest. The Minister responsible for conservation said that the Northern Territory Government would be consulted, right until the Federal Government announced that the World Heritage listing would be requested. Yet no consultation or agreement with the Northern Territory Government was sought or obtained. As such action is directly contrary to the formal agreement made between the Commonwealth and the States in a document that I will mention in a moment, I believe this whole plan of management should be rejected. The document that was signed in February this year is entitled `Australia and the World Heritage Convention'. It was issued by the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment in February this year. Under the heading `Process for nominating Australian properties', that document says:
The Commonwealth Government writes to the State and Territory Governments inviting them to submit suggestions . . .
It goes on a little further to say:

Any suggestions for World Heritage listing brought forward by other than a State or Territory Government to be referred, with supporting information, to the relevant State or Territory Government for comment prior to examination by the Commonwealth.
I do not believe that happened. Finally, it says:
The Commonwealth Government has indicated, however, that it will not take unilateral action to nominate areas for World Heritage listing without the agreement of the State or Territory concerned.

I ask the Senate: Did that happen in this case? Of course it did not. Honourable senators will note that the agreement states that there must be not only consultation but also agreement. That did not happen. I suppose the real question that has to be decided is whether the preservation of an area that not all people feel is as good as some others claim it to be should be carried out to the exclusion of all else. Obviously the majority of Australians do not think so. In a survey they were asked:

Provided areas of scenic and other significance were not disturbed, would you be in favour or against the mining under stringent environmental conditions of any large deposits of gold, platinum or other minerals found in Kakadu National Park?

Just under 60 per cent were in favour of the mining and just over 33 per cent were against. Whereas the Government may think it is on a very popular course in what it is doing, let it be warned that the people of this country are not foolish. They know the economic difficulties that have been floated by everybody from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) down. I do not think that the Treasurer is an idiot. He has proved that he understands just how dangerous our economic situation is. The people of Australia recognise it, too. They realise that we cannot afford the multi-million dollar cost of conservation that is now intended for stages 1 and 2.

TALK.START.PARA: —We want jobs and export income.
—We desperately need export income for this country not to be a worse banana republic than it is now. In the Australian today Des Keegan said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke senses the country is going against him and that he must do something.

Mr Hawke, I believe, recognises, as does the Treasurer, the economic danger that this country is facing. He would love to have an election about this time, and I am sure that if the Pope were not coming he would have one. He cannot have one while the Pope is here, so there will not be an election this year. He knows very well the economic situation into which this country is getting, and next year it will be a disaster. We do not need a Treasurer to tell us that; everybody in this country is beginning to recognise it.

If we do not allow sensible exploration, what would be the result? We would lock up forever about 13,000 square kilometres of land with a high mineral potential. Australia would never know just what the mineral deposits are, so we would forgo the economic, employment and other benefits that mining in the park could bring. We would deny ourselves a source of raw materials which we need and which could add to our balance of payments. We would deny the Aboriginals access to the economic benefits that would flow from that area. They are just some of the things that would happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are allowing other countries to get in front of us.

—That is right. Canada would not be in the position with uranium which it is now had we gone ahead at a sensible pace. I must say that in that instance the Government of which I was a member should take some blame for not pushing ahead a little more rapidly. I draw everybody's attention to what the South Australian Minister of Mines and Energy said. In a recent speech he said that there should be an examination of what is available under the ground. His attitude is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to foster multiple land use concepts and to ensure that no land is alienated from exploration without careful consideration of the subsurface mineral/petroleum potential, relevant economic factors and the existing and potential subsurface rights.

In other words, the Cabinet in South Australia, a Labor State, recognises that there has to be a balance in life. That is something that we are not hearing from many of the people in this country at the moment, particularly the conservationists. We cannot ever satisfy them. If we give them stage 1, they want stage 2. If we give them stage 2, they want stage 3. Senator Vigor is a prime example of someone wanting that extension. I am waiting for somebody to say that he wants stages 4, 5 and 6. I do not know quite where this national park will end, because someone will step over a tussock and say: `Oh, an endangered species' or `an endangered frog' or something. It is about time the people of this country were told that we cannot afford this ratbag group that is trying to stop all production in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is going to join the Katherine Gorge, the whole country.

—I do not believe it would stop there because these people will never be satisfied. One cannot satisfy them. I am running out of time, but I recap by saying that the plan does not deal with mining as it is meant to under the Act.
