It does not pay attention to the rights of the miners and the leases that already existed and that pre-dated the park. It does not pay attention to the needs and the rights of the Aborigines of the area; nor does it cater for tourists as it should and nor does it cater for the rest of Australia economically as it should. On those bases alone-if anybody would like any more information I have a lot more-this plan should be disallowed.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak tonight in opposition to this disallowance motion in order to answer some of the arguments and misconceptions which we have heard from the Opposition in the course of this fairly lengthy debate, which I am sure is much longer than are most motion of disallowance debates.
—Or than is necessary.

—Yes, quite. I want to note first that we are not discussing stage 3 in this debate because it is not included in the plan of management, although reference is made in that plan to stage 3, to the Gimbat and Goodparla leases, because the reference is relevant to the present stages 1 and 2. For example, waterflows from stage 3 provide much of the inflow for the wetlands lower down. Because I am the Chair of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, which is at present inquiring into the Kakadu region, I have followed the progress of this plan of management since last year. I have become aware of many misconceptions about the plan-about what it is and what it does, what it is not and what it does not do, and what are the normal procedures in drawing up such a plan. I think Opposition senators should take a look at the terms of the 1975 National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, which remained through the days of the Fraser Government, and notice that the objectives of this plan of management are taken directly from that. I think it would be instructive for them to look at that Act to see its terms.
—Did you study the eight-year environmental impact before mining started?
—Yes, I have studied all that.
—I bet you didn't, because there have been a lot of environmental problems naturally.

—I have read that; I have read the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry or Fox inquiry. Never fear, Senator Jessop, I have done my homework. Would that some of our colleagues had done as much. There have been suggestions that the plan of management should have been delayed until the Senate Committee had finished its inquiry. That view ignores the fact that the first plan of management ran out in December last year, 1985, and that the Committee will not be reporting until 1987-rather a long gap. At any rate, the plan of management is just that-a plan of management. It was subject to a lengthy process of consultation, quite openly done, and, as we can see, open to possible disallowance in either House of Parliament-a fact which the Northern Territory Government did not seem to realise as late as two weeks ago. I know conservative governments are not very familiar with methods of public consultation because they are not very keen on that. Maybe that is why.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of speakers have referred to the relatively small area which would be occupied by any potential mining in stages 1 or 2. In fact, Senator Collard referred to `a speck'. But it is not just a matter of percentages, even if one accepted that description. For example, certainly the Ranger mine, both from the air and from the ground, is far from being a speck. A mine has an infrastructure. It has roads; it has equipment which has to be left somewhere; it has to have sheds, storage, possibly accommodation, site works and perhaps treatment works. Also, we are not concerned just with the areas. The effect of even a speck-if it were a speck-may, for example, allow pollution of river systems and therefore the effects can range over a very large area. It is important to recognise the role of the whole park river system in maintaining those wetlands which everyone on both sides of the chamber acknowledged as worthy of conservation. Frankly, I do not see how we can conserve those wetlands if we do extensive damage to the headlands of the waters that feed them. Senator Collard said that the wetlands cover at maximum level only about 16 per cent of stages 1 and 2. But a great deal of that water comes from parts of stage 3.

Some members of the Opposition seem to have little knowledge or appreciation of national parks in general. They profess to be surprised, for example, that they are managed in the way they are. Yet this plan of management has many of its details, in fact its whole philosophy, in common with parks with which I have had dealings in other parts of Australia and, indeed, in other parts of the world. There has been a lot of talk about multiple land use, which is defined in different ways by different people. The Northern Territory Government, the mining industry representatives and some Opposition speakers, at one extreme, seem to believe there should be no limits to the level of land use in Kakadu National Park, no limit to the multiplicity of the land use, as long as small areas which they perceive as beauty spots are excepted. I remind honourable senators that beauty is in the eye of the observer. What Senator Townley saw as boring, frequently I saw as beautiful, and maybe the opposite would apply somewhere else in the world. To others `multiple land use' means controlled tourist access and traditional use by the Aboriginal traditional owners. At the other extreme, there may be people who do want to deny all access to outsiders. It is a view that I have been accused, wrongly, of holding. But I honestly have not heard anyone put that view. Yet we have comments from a number of speakers opposite that supporters of national parks want to lock them away forever from everyone. I sometimes think that those people believe that the minerals will rot if they are not mined now. National parks are not locked away; parks are for people.

I have said that what is beautiful to some is not beautiful to others. Also it depends on when and how one travels, where one travels and who is one's guide, as I found travelling with mining industry representatives and with national park rangers, who both saw and interpreted the park in different ways. This brings me to the over-quoted term `clapped out buffalo country'. Two weeks ago the Committee was at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation station in the Kakadu region where we saw the dramatic results of fencing buffaloes out of such an area. The regrowth in a few years was amazing and gave us some idea of what the whole Kakadu National Park area would be like if the buffaloes were removed. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, in my view, is doing a Herculean job in rehabilitating the land by eradicating the buffaloes which, incidentally, present a health hazard as well as an environmental disaster.

Much use has been made in this debate of the word `pristine', and it has not usually, incidentally, been used by the conservationists. Again, like `multiple land use', the word has been used to distort the argument. With the possible exception of Antarctica, there are probably no pristine areas in the world in the sense in which Senator Durack, at least, used the word-of being free from human use. I know of no person or group who would argue that Kakadu National Park is or should be pristine in that sense. But it is the nearest we can get to an ecosystem or land form which is still basically as it was tens of thousands of years ago-and the rock art bears testimony to that. That is what we want to preserve.

Senator Crichton-Browne raised the question of an inventory, a matter that has been raised a number of times. He seemed to assume that this can be done only by exploration by the mining companies, a view one might expect from the party of privatisation. An inventory can be done by the Government, just as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service are at present making an inventory of the flora, fauna, Aboriginal art, rainfall patterns and all other aspects of the area.

Senator Townley referred fairly briefly to a survey, but I would like to deal with it a little more deeply than he did. The survey was conducted, I understand, for the Australian Mining Industry Council, which drew it to my notice. For some years I worked for the gallup poll organisation and I have some experience in conducting polls and the way questions are asked to obtain particular answers. This is an obvious example. I note first that the sample size, the number of people interviewed, was only 1,150, a fairly small number if one is trying to get an Australia-wide view of what the population thinks. Gallup poll in the days I worked for that organisation did a minimum of 2,000 interviews, and I understand that still about that number is considered as a minimum to be valid. Let us look at the questions. The first question asked:
Are you in favour or against carefully controlled exploration in Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory to establish its mineral potential?
The second question asked:

Provided areas of scenic and other significance were not disturbed, would you be in favour or against the mining under stringent environmental conditions of any large deposits of gold, platinum or other minerals found in Kakadu National Park?

I do not think I need to explain just how biased those questions are. In fact, one of the representatives of the Mining Industry Council as much as admitted to me that they were meant to get a particular answer. They got the answer they predicted, and anyone who has any knowledge of social science would know that that was what they would get.
I want to set the record straight on my own position on a matter raised by Senator Kilgariff. I quote from Hansard on 20 October, where he said:
Senator Zakharov, who is trying to interject, has been up there and knows full well what the Aboriginals believe in
I thank him for that. He continued:

They say, `Let us have a fair go to be able to develop ourselves'. They say that they do not have to live on government handouts, which is what the honourable senator wants them to do. She wants them to be subjected to the Federal Government so that their very existence is a handout to handout situation from day to day whereby they are not allowed to develop.

That is certainly not my position. I know that the Aboriginal people I have spoken with in the area and elsewhere, including representatives of the traditional owners, know that that is not my position. Indeed, I am very concerned that Aboriginals should make their own decisions and be given time and opportunity to do so. Unlike Senator Crichton-Browne, I do not want to canvass this matter here because it is a matter into which the Committee is still inquiring, but I want to remove the slur that was cast on me by Senator Kilgariff. I conclude by quoting the then Deputy Prime Minister, Doug Anthony, speaking in 1977, I think, but I could be wrong as to the date. When speaking about the setting up of the national park, he said:
The second major element of the machinery for regulation and control is the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. We will establish a major national park in the region.
Then comes the important part:
The Director of National Parks and Wildlife, a statutory officer responsible to the Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development, will have extensive powers over the region as a whole.
Yet the same coalition of which Doug Anthony was a member now criticises that view and also the powers given then to the Director of the ANPWS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators on both sides of the chamber for contributing to what has been a long but interesting debate-such is the interest of senators from all parties in the Kakadu National Park, but more importantly in the philosophy behind national parks and the use of such parks and of mineral areas. When I moved this motion on 20 October, I said that we had national parks for four main reasons. I quote once again from page 1575 of the Senate Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, to preserve as widely as possible the genetic pool of our flora and fauna; secondly, to preserve for aesthetic reasons locations of unique natural beauty; thirdly, to preserve for posterity areas of historical and cultural significance; and, fourthly, for recreational purposes.

I do not think anybody at any stage disagreed with that, and there is common ground on both sides of the chamber on those definitions. Everybody who has spoken in this debate basically has agreed with those definitions in that as far as they pertain to the Kakadu National Park pertain to the wetlands, the escarpment and the Aboriginal rock galleries. The basic argument had been about that and the Opposition has at no time denied that they are areas of significance and should be preserved. I said that in my initial speech and just about every Opposition senator who spoke after me took up the same line-that the areas of significance, the wetlands, the escarpment and the Aboriginal rock galleries, should be sacrosanct.

The debate then gets on to what I call the buffer areas, or what the original Act called the conservation zones. Those who are interested in the Kakadu National Park and in this debate should recognise that outside those areas an arbitrary line is drawn, namely, the boundary of the Kakadu National Park. Between that arbitrary line and the areas of significance is the buffer area or conservation zone. It is those buffer areas which are the focus of attention in this debate. The Opposition is saying that those areas should be available for multi-purpose use under strict environmental control. Senator Zakharov in her speech rightly pointed to the use, or misuse, of the term `pristine', a word that is used on many occasions. I agree with her. As a matter of fact, I mentioned the same thing in my remarks. Senator Zakharov also said, and I hope that I do not misquote her, that the area of Kakadu has been as it is for thousands of years. I disagree, and indeed Professor Ovington in addressing a Senate Committee on the term `pristine' mentioned the same thing. He then went on, and I quote again from page 1577 of the Senate Hansard of 20 October 1986.
People forget that Kakadu has been managed as a land area by Aboriginals for perhaps 40,000 years. Their impact is there.
I repeat that:
Their impact is there.
So it is that, no matter what we may think, nothing stands still. The human race has had an impact, for better or for worse, on our environment for countless thousands of years.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the difference is that the Aborigines do not affect the environment like Anglo-Saxons do.
—That is a matter for debate. We are learning from the fact that the Aborigines fired the land quite regularly, and that was their method of husbanding the earth.
—They don't destroy anything.

—Senator Gietzelt is so wrong. They fired the earth-I am not saying they should not have done so-for different reasons, such as flushing out game. But one can go now to areas which were fired for centuries and which when white man came to Australia were grasslands. Many of those areas are now forests, and indeed are becoming rainforest country, which would not have happened with the regular firing by Aborigines. So let me not hear it said that that practice did not have a `detrimental' effect. Mankind has always had an effect on the environment. This has to be said: Mankind is not an interloper in the environment, he is and always has been a part of the environment. He has an effect on it for better or worse. Unfortunately we could all point to instances when we would say that in a short time those effects have been for the worst. I am not arguing about that.
—We chop down trees.

—Yes, we chop down trees and previous generations have chopped down trees because we have needed the timber. If we do not chop them down other nations will chop them down using the slash and burn method because the timber is needed.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to prolong this debate-it has been a good one-but the main threads of the Opposition's argument on the proposed Kakadu plan of management are as follows: Firstly, as has already been pointed out, the plan is defective not only because it does not make provision for exploration in mining, but also because it does not allow for proper and adequate tourist development. It ignores the wishes of the traditional land owners-the Aborigines-and it ignores the wishes of the Northern Territory Government. Secondly, the original concept of the Kakadu National Park was for multiple land usage, including mining. The first plan of management and the Act recognised this. This plan does not. Thirdly, the outstanding features of the park-the wetlands, the escarpment and the Aboriginal rock galleries-should and will be preserved. The rest of the park is essentially just a buffer zone and these areas should have a multiple usage purpose. If mining were to proceed in all the existing mining leases it would affect only about one per cent of the total area-that is, of stages 1, 2 and 3.

Recently the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) visited Kakadu. We have had the recent statements from the man whom we might call `born again Bob', the conservationists' friend and occasional `greenie'. Those statements would have to be some of the most cynical that have been uttered for a long time. I do not object to the Prime Minister doing Faustian deals with sections or factions of the Australian Labor Party in order to preserve his hide. The Prime Minister's soul would be poor currency indeed. I do not object to his selling the ALP's soul as it has very little else to offer. But on behalf of this nation, I object strongly to the Prime Minister selling this country down the drain for a handful of votes.

The Prime Minister said that it would be `an obscenity to mine Kakadu'. The only obscene thing is the spectacle of the Prime Minister grovelling to sectional interests in order to hold his shaky grip on office. It is also an obscenity to seem to say that this generation cannot at the same time use and preserve. That is the challenge that faces this generation and subsequent generations. The challenge is to act in line with definitions of `conservation' which were laid down in the national conservation strategy for Australia. I quoted these definitions in my original speech, recorded at page 1577 of the Senate Hansard of 20 October. I will use them again now. `Conservation' is defined as:

. . . the management of the human use of the biosphere so that it may yield the greatest sustainable benefit to the present generation while maintaining its potential to meet the needs and aspirations of future generations.
`Development' is defined as:
. . . the modification of the biosphere and the application of human, financial, living and non-living resources to satisfy human needs and to improve the quality of human life.

Those are two very good definitions and that is the challenge that is facing our generation. It is an obscenity to expect us to believe that this generation is not capable of using and at the same time preserving.

Many people think that a national park can be a picture frame in time which can be preserved in that state for all time. That is nonsense. The park was never the same as it is now and even if we were not here it would never be the same in the future. It is constantly changing. The challenge for us, if we wish to do so, is to minimise the impact of human involvement in that area. Now, of course, we have that other well known guardian of Labor moral direction, Senator Richardson, who seems to be worried that he has left his ministerial run too late. He is becoming so worried that he might miss out on a State funeral that he too is putting his soul up to the highest bidder. With two souls in one week the market is becoming rather saturated.

I draw the attention of both the Government and Senator Richardson to the editorial in today's Australian which is headed `The duty of the Government is governing'. That is what governments are elected to do-to govern. In other words, they must make best use of the resources that are there and at the same time they must preserve them. That is the challenge which faces us, each and every one of us. We cannot go back in time. At the end of the day with all the arguments for conservation-and these are quite valid arguments-governments have to govern. Politicians have to take decisions to provide food, fibre, jobs and export earnings and all the rest of it. The fact that they have to do that does not mean they should not, at the same time, take into consideration the preservation needs of particular areas.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Collard's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1986-87[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1986-87APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1986-87]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's record on the economy is that in the last 3 1/2 years some 670,000 extra employment positions have been created. Here I note that the last time I spoke on economic matters in this place-in fact at the beginning of the debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2)-we had created some 650,000 jobs, so another 20,000 have been created in that interval. That compares with the Government's promise of 500,000 new jobs in its first three years of office. The unemployment rate has been reduced from a peak of 10.4 per cent in 1983 to 8.4 per cent for the month of October 1986. Those figures were released just last week. The Government has brought the inflation rate down from the 11 1/2 per cent it inherited from Mr Howard to 8.9 per cent now.

SPEECH.PARA: The major problem facing the Australian economy is the deficit on the current account of the balance of payments. That is the classic external constraint on growth in the Australian economy. It is a constraint that has been documented for many decades and it is here again with us in the present period. In the last financial year, 1985-86, the current account deficit, which basically is defined as the balance of trade taken together with the so-called invisible items in the balance of payments, has risen to some $13,000m or 5.9 per cent of gross domestic product compared with a figure of $10.8 billion for the previous financial year. Of course, the big deterioration has been in the balance of trade, that is, physical trade. That moved from a position of surplus in 1983-84 to a position of deficit to the tune of $3,400m in 1985-86. The deficit means that Australia has borrowed overseas to finance the current consumption of imports in the Australian economy and also to pay off Australia's accumulated external debt.

I should correct the record this evening about Australia's overseas debt. From listening to speeches from Opposition spokespersons, one would get the impression that overseas debt is the province of government in Australia, that it is essentially government debt. That is not true. That is far from the record and is very inaccurate. The fact is that at 31 March this year-these are the latest figures on external debt that I have been able to obtain-the total gross external debt was some $80,000m. Of that amount, $46,000m was debt incurred by the private sector. So the majority of gross external debt was private sector debt. All government debt, not just Commonwealth Government debt-the Commonwealth is always being blamed for this debt by honourable senators opposite-totalled some $34,000m. That government debt includes the debt of conservative States like Queensland and Tasmania. It does not just include Commonwealth Government debt. So it is quite possible to calculate that, of Australia's net external debt of some $62,000m, the maximum share of government debt is some 35 per cent; in other words, barely more than one-third of the total net external debt is public debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't it worry you that most of the private debt is in the stock exchanges of Australia?

—I am certainly very worried about the way in which private sector activity has been occurring and the patterns of private sector investment. All Australians should be concerned about that. The Government's economic strategy is to moderate domestic spending while increasing net external demand, which is defined as exports less imports. The aim is to lower and moderate domestic demand, to lower the overflow of economic activity into imports. The Budget, which is financed by the appropriation Bills we are debating tonight, calculates that net exports will constitute some 1 3/4 percentage points of the projected growth in gross domestic product this year, with the domestic sector contribution only one-half of a per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget has made substantial reductions to government expenditure and in the growth rate of government expenditure. I find that unpalatable but it is very difficult to avoid in the current circumstances of very poor prices received for the products that we sell abroad. This will dampen domestic demand further, but will of course help cut imports. The reduced growth in public expenditure will also help to reduce borrowings and in that way also help to reduce Australia's future public debt liabilities. It is very important to note that the Commonwealth Budget for 1986-87 has made a very substantial reduction in the Budget deficit. The deficit last financial year of some $5,700m has been cut to $3,500m this financial year, which is a very substantial cut. The deficit for this financial year will amount to some 1.4 per cent of gross domestic product. That compares very favourably with the enormous prospective Budget deficit that we inherited from Mr Howard for the 1983-84 financial year. That prospective deficit of $9.6 billion would have amounted to a shocking 5 per cent of gross domestic product had no action been taken by the Hawke Labor Government.

The zero real growth in government expenditure this year is aimed to bring about reduced government borrowing. It is also aimed at cutting pressures on Australia's domestic capital markets, and the objective in doing that is to cut pressures on interest rates and the economy in general, and, hopefully, to reduce interest rates in the market-place. The objective in doing that is to boost investment by the public and private sectors of the economy. Of course, investment is a key to general economic recovery and is certainly a key to the manufacturing export growth that we so desperately need.

Australia's government fiscal policy and monetary policy are being backed by other policies. The Government has embarked upon policies to hit costs and contain inflation. The Prices Surveillance Authority has been beefed up recently. It will have a wider scope of activities and a greater compass of activities involving scrutiny of prices and proposed price increases by producers in the market-place.

In framing the 1986-87 Budget, the Government has aimed to spread more evenly and more equitably the burden of readjustment of the economy to the difficult economic circumstances in which we find ourselves. We do not want to leave the adjustment of the economy to the laws of the economic jungle. It is important to note that the Budget contains some very progressive measures. For example, it disallows tax deferral advantages for a number of companies which were adjusting their reporting dates. From that, the saving to revenue in the current financial year will be $220m-a large and significant amount of revenue for the Budget.

The Budget increases the unemployment benefit rate for 18- to 20-year-olds by $3 per week from 1 January. There will be a $1 per week increase in pensions and benefits per child, and a $1 per week increase in the rate of family income supplement per child as of this month. They are very important measures. There is also a youth homeless allowance of $23 per week, to be paid to some young persons already receiving education allowances or unemployment benefits who are unable to live at home for various reasons. That particular measure will add $9m to expenditure this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you not admit that there is a dramatic cut in social welfare expenditure?

—Like many other members of the community, I have had my breath taken away this year by the Australian Democrats' discovery of social welfare as an issue. I have never heard the Democrats talk about social welfare in this place until this year. It is one of the issues that they discover--
—We have been talking about it for six years.

—That is not so. The Democrats have discovered social welfare as an issue only this year. It is one of the issues that they hope to put into a coalition of issues to try to get enough votes to win quotas at the next election. I feel appalled that Senator Siddons can be suggesting otherwise to me, a member of the Labor Party-which gives very high priority to social welfare activities and policies, and has done so for many decades-when the Democrats have discovered social welfare as an issue only this year.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Budget there is new funding for the adult training program. Extra funds this financial year will enable over 7,000 adult unemployed persons to receive training during the current financial year as compared with 6,000 in the last financial year. That is a very important move. It is a very worthwhile activity. The focus in recent years in Australia has been to provide training opportunities for younger persons in the labour force, but I think it is now recognised that there is a core of adult unemployed persons who really need training. It is important to note that the funds for that have been voted in this Budget.

This Budget includes revenues, perhaps for the first time in our history, from the capital gains tax. The 1986-87 Budget is framed on a basis that it will incorporate revenues from the capital gains tax. That has been a tremendous economic reform and reform of taxation laws, and it is a real milestone to see capital gains tax revenue going into the Budget this financial year. The revenue in the Budget also includes that arising from the disallowance of the so-called free lunch. That is something that Senator Archer and his colleagues repeatedly championed in this place last year-the ability of very wealthy people to have subsidised lunches at the expense of taxpayers. The savings from the removal of that rort will be about $300m this financial year. The Budget includes, most significantly, the first revenue from the fringe benefits tax. Those three devices-the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the disallowance of the so-called free lunch-are very important financing mechanisms for the Government's significant personal income tax reductions, which start in just over a fortnight's time, on 1 December. Without the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax and the removal of the so-called business lunch, this Government would not be able to deliver the very significant reductions in personal income tax to start on 1 December.

It is important to note that the tax threshold will be increased in that package from the current $4,595 to $5,100. The highest tax rate in the top bracket will be reduced from 60c in the dollar to 55c, going down to 49c in July next year, and the 48c and 46c rates will be reduced to 40c in the dollar. So there are tremendous reductions in the marginal tax rates in our income tax system. The bottom rates will be reduced to 24c in the dollar. The best that Mr Howard could manage in his five Budgets from 1978 to 1982 was a bottom marginal rate of 30c in the dollar. Clearly, on that indicator, with a tax rate of 24c in the dollar this Government has made great strides in reducing the tax burden on ordinary Australians.

The Budget forecast that gross domestic product-Australia's gross income-will grow by some 2.5 per cent this financial year, with employment growing by a further 1 3/4 per cent-not as high as it was last financial year, but still a significant increase in employment. It is important to bear in mind that since the Budget was brought down there have been some quite positive events in the economic area and in financial markets. The Australian dollar has increased in value by several percentage points and seems to have stabilised in the mid-sixties in United States cents. There have been significant reductions in interest rates throughout the economy. The prime rates charged by the banks for their large borrowers have been coming down across the board. The interest rate on bank bills, which banks themselves issue to borrow funds for lending by themselves, has fallen from 18.7 per cent in early September to 15.9 per cent yesterday. We have there a reduction in that key interest rate in the economy of over 2 3/4 percentage points-a very large reduction in a major interest rate in the economy. The unemployment rate seems to have flattened out at about 8.3 per cent or 8.4 per cent. We have now had four months in a row, from July to October 1986, with unemployment rates, on a seasonally adjusted basis, of 8.3 or 8.4 per cent.

One of the most interesting aspects of the economy at the moment, a matter that is dear to the hearts of Liberal and National Party senators, is share market prices. That is the sort of indicator they like to use on their soap boxes at meetings when talking about levels of economic activity. They, unlike members of the Australian Labor Party, use share market prices as a measure of what is going on in the economy. Despite all the doom and gloom being poured out by Mr Howard and his supporters about the economy, it is interesting to note that during 1986 the all ordinaries index of Australian share market prices has recorded some 42 record highs-not two or 22, but 42 record highs. The market is up 36 per cent so far in 1986. On the basis of the rhetoric and dogma of members of the Opposition, they would have to say that the economy is going well, that there is no doom and gloom and that, on the basis of that indicator they use so regularly, the economy is going forward. It is also interesting to note that as a result of those very large rises in share market prices, which themselves were the result of larger numbers of transactions in the market-place, the Government will collect more money from the capital gains tax than it budgeted for because more assets have been unlocked from exemption from the capital gains tax. That clearly shows that investors are not worried or fazed by the Government's capital gains tax and undermines the claims made by the Opposition spokespersons that the capital gains tax is an important disincentive to investment.

The expansionary economic policy and growth of the last three years have been checked by the classic balance of payments constraints facing the Australian economy and we now have the opportunity as a result of an adjustment to the value of our dollar to have a competitive edge-an edge that will provide, at least on paper, a boost to the manufacturing industry. The challenge still lies ahead to translate the devaluation of the Australian dollar into growth in manufacturing exports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to these Appropriation Bills before the Senate I think it is fair to say that it is no secret that this country is presently in the grip of an alarming economic decline-a decline which in the opinion of the Opposition is being assisted by the policies of the Labor Government. Australia's problems have their origin largely in the narrow range of its export base and the fact that much of the country's manufacturing industry is uncompetitive. Rural and mining products accounted for approximately 77 per cent of Australia's exports during 1985-86, of which our six largest exports-coal, wool, wheat, iron ore, meat and petroleum-accounted for more than half. On the other hand, manufacturing exports represented around 20 per cent of our total exports. We see the difficulties this presents when we compare it with world trade figures, which show that around 65 per cent of world trade is manufacture based. If we add to that the fact that prices for most rural and mineral commodities for various reasons have fallen sharply during the 1980s we see why our export earnings have declined and our import outlays have increased. The Australian of Thursday 23 October contained an article headed `Survey pessimistic on exports'. It said, with reference to an important Government survey:

SPEECH.PARA: The survey results, released yesterday in a report prepared by the Bureau of Industry Economics, suggest that a significant increase in manufactured exports is unlikely in the short term and that even if all the economic fundamentals are correct, it might be several years before there is a surge in export-related investment.

Business managers interviewed in the survey indicated that overseas concerns about reliability of supply, continued competition by many newly industrialised countries and weakening overseas markets inhibited the growth of manufactured exports.

Low profitability, due to high labour costs and low productivity, and low perceived rates of return, due to high interest rates and high corporate tax rates, are the main reasons cited for a poor investment response.

I believe the Budget should have aimed at broadening our export base while at the same time introducing meaningful expenditure cuts. In fact, the Government has further worsened our balance of trade while imposing further charges to boost Government receipts. Major revenue increases will come from increased taxation. Surprise, surprise! There is to be further taxation on petroleum products, a rise in the Medicare levy, the introduction of the horrific fringe benefits tax, rises in sales tax on health foods such as citrus juices and milk products, and the bank account debits tax. Despite the tax cuts from 1 December, net pay as you earn taxation will still rise by more than 10 per cent.

There is no doubt whatsoever in my mind that these changes will reduce household disposable income, something which I am sure will not go down too well with Australian consumers, who are seeing their shopping bills go up. From December people on the average wage will receive a tax cut of about $9 a week, but the Australian Consumers Association has assessed the impact of increased indirect charges at between $15 and $20 a week-a net income cut of $6 to $11 a week. Our inflation rate is running at about 8.9 per cent, which is three times higher than the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average and nearly eight times more than that of our major trading partner, Japan. Government now consumes 44 per cent of Australia's national income, so the average Australian who starts working on 1 January has to work until about mid-June to pay for government. Total taxes in 1985 were 85 times greater than the total profit of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd from oil, gas, coal, iron, steel, gold and other minerals. In that year 86 per cent of Esso Australia Ltd's income from oil production from the Bass Strait went to government taxes and levies.

The fringe benefits tax will go down in Australian political history as one of the most unbelievably misguided initiatives ever produced by a Federal government. The tax is to be imposed on businesses at a time when they can least afford it. There is a a lot of talk about broadening our manufacturing export base on the one hand, but businesses are being hit with the fringe benefits tax on the other. That makes a mockery of the supposed Budget strategy. At a time when this country needs incentives, the Government brings out disincentives. At a time when we need growth in the business sector, the Government introduces anti-growth policies. At a time when unemployment is one of the major problems facing this country, the Government chooses to stifle employment opportunities. Its idea of course is to tax everybody and bring them all down to the same level.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about how your son and husband have been robbing the taxpayers of Queensland for the last two decades.

—I believe that this is not an opportunity for the Minister continually to bash my son's property. I answered his allegations on this matter, quite properly, in a television interview recently. I am discussing the present situation of this Government as far as the Appropriation Bills are concerned. The Government's idea is to tax employers so much that they have no incentive to provide jobs and job opportunities. I consider that the fringe benefits tax is a totally ridiculous idea, and I am not alone in this view. There are many people throughout Australia who believe the same thing. If we look at the election results in New South Wales--
—All the tax dodgers in the country are on your side, starting from your husband, who got dragged into the High Court and was made to pay his taxes.
—Order, Senator Walsh! I ask you to withdraw the reflection on the leader of the Government in Queensland.
—Certainly, Mr Acting Deputy President.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am glad to have the protection of the Chair. The fringe benefits tax is a totally ridiculous idea. There will be no value to the business community in its implementation. I know that it will raise a lot of money for the Government, but at what cost to the businesses and farming communities of this country? It is an administrative nightmare and, to make it even more ludicrous, many employers still do not fully know what they are liable for and, I hasten to add, nor does the Australian Taxation Office. The cost involved in providing the records required by the Tax Office will be horrific. At the moment we can really only visualise some of the problems that there will be, but when and if the Tax Office decides what it wants from the employers I believe that it will truly become a nightmare. I would like to quote from a document produced by the Confederation of Australian Industry which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a rough estimate of just the time cost of complying with the tax might be gleaned from the fact that each minute of time devoted to complying with the tax in all non-farm private sector firms in Australia would mean that over the year around 160,000 working days have been lost to the economy in complying with the tax. And that is just for a single minute of compliance time. Multiply this by the many hours of time throughout each and every firm that will have to be wasted in this way and the magnitude of the economic loss involved with this tax will be apparent.

What makes me really annoyed is the fact that this tax proves just how out of touch this Government is with business and the farming community. It is simply not possible to draw hundreds of millions of dollars out of firms and farms across the economy without leading to further economic decline. A leading article in the Australian a few weeks ago stated:

The fringe benefits tax will particularly hit those Australians mainly concentrated in vital export industries who are attempting to develop the outback in Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory. In order to attract a work force to these remote areas it is necessary to offer subsidised housing and transport. These are not the kind of fringe benefits which should be taxed as they are essential elements of working in the outback, not rorts designed to avoid tax.
The tax will severely undermine business confidence and profitability. This also means less opportunity for growth in the business and farming sectors and fewer employment opportunities.

I would like to speak about a matter which I consider to be very important and which, sadly, has been neglected by this Government. I speak tonight about the family unit, which is the cornerstone of our society. I cannot recall any piece of legislation which I consider has been designed to promote or enhance the stability of family life in this country being introduced in the past three years of this Government. We have not had any increases in the family allowance for four years. The Medicare levy has been increased, a means test has been applied to families with 16- and 17-year-olds and with incomes above $39,000, irrespective of other dependants and the high costs of maintaining and educating children in higher secondary education. Prescription charges are to double from a maximum of $5 to $10. I spoke recently about the sales tax which has been applied to citrus juices and flavoured milk, both of which, of course, are health beverages and much consumed in the average family home. Extremely high interest rates and a very high inflation rate are making it almost impossible for young people to buy homes and for those who can afford to do so it means very high monthly mortgage repayments and sometimes, sad to say, even repossession.

The Government is quite prepared to put a lot of money into making divorce faster, easier and less traumatic but in the last Budget it allocated only $100,000 towards marriage education-something which I believe is of paramount importance. Even after the 1 December tax cuts and taking into account the Medicare levy, the dependent spouse rebate, the family allowance and the effects of inflation, families with a single breadwinner and two dependent children will still be $23.50 a week worse off than they were at the time of the last election in 1984. We are daily seeing the decline of the single income family. The Government cannot convince me that there are not thousands of mothers in Australia who would love to be able to spend more time in the home with their growing families but who are unable to because of financial worries.

I would like to see the introduction of income splitting for the single income family for taxation purposes. I can see a great deal of merit in such an initiative and I feel that it would benefit the average family in a way which would mean far more than any other initiative that I have seen in my five years in this place as a senator representing Queensland. We want to remember also that two-income families already benefit from a much higher tax free threshold than do single income families. The Sun newspaper of 20 August last reported that women in the work force:
. . . will be assisted with the development of a $1 million Affirmative Action Agency to supervise the implementation of Affirmative Action employment principles in the private sector.

What about affirmative action programs by the Government to raise the status of women in the home? I feel I have a responsibility on behalf of thousands and thousands of Australian families to ask the Government to consider the plight of the single income family. This basic unit of society is fast becoming an endangered species. Perhaps I should introduce some sort of private member's Bill to have the single income family put on the World Heritage List to ensure its continued existence. Certainly I am worried about the enormous pressures that are being put on the average working men and women who are trying to provide a secure and happy future for their children in this country. It seems to me that the Government is taxing everything that moves, including our nation's future-our children-and I believe that it has to stop. This Government is further eroding the stability of the country's basic unit of society, the family, and I for one mourn its decline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1986-87, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1986-87 which are before the Senate, I wish to direct my remarks to a number of issues-one more general and the others specific. First, I would like to make some general remarks on the financial policies of this Government as they affect the people of the outback. While there has been widespread community opposition to the fringe benefits tax, nowhere will the effects of this tax be more damaging than in the outback. The fringe benefits tax will bite hard in remote communities where conditions are such that employers often need to offer benefits as conditions of employment in order to attract skilled workers. In mining and other remote communities such as pastoral homesteads, Aboriginal settlements and pioneer tourist projects where educational facilities beyond primary school level are often non-existent, employers commonly offer assistance with educational expenses for the children of employees. This is a recognition of a child's right to an education and that right should not be jeopardised by the nature or location of his or her parents' employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Often assistance with air fares to the employee's home State is included as part of a package. This is a recognition of the fact that many skilled workers come to the Territory having left behind family and friends and they should be assisted in maintaining those family contacts. Subsidised housing is also a legitimate and common element of employment packages in the outback. These are not the lurks and perks of the wealthy tax evaders to which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have so often adverted. They are benefits paid to ordinary men and women as an inducement for them to work in an often harsh environment without the amenities which are taken for granted in more populous areas.

I referred on a previous occasion to a survey commissioned by a number of Territory business associations, including the Master Builders Association of the Northern Territory, the Motor Traders Association, the Northern Territory Confederation of Industry and Commerce Inc., the Northern Territory branch of the Mines and Metals Association, the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association, the Northern Territory branch of the Australian Small Business Association, the Real Estate Institute of the Northern Territory Inc., and the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines (Inc.). The survey which was carried out showed that the long standing award provisions of employment are now deemed to be fringe benefits, taxable in the hands of employers. These provisions are awards of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and were not introduced or contemplated as tax avoidance schemes. The survey sample was of 13.2 per cent of the private sector work force and thus was a reliable sample. The benefits subject to the tax were calculated as being worth some $60m and the tax payable would be around $26m. I should say here that these figures are pre-review, but the magnitude of the employers' tax liability will still be of monumental proportions because the concessions being made by Mr Keating are miserable. Employers will now have to pay tax on 50 per cent of the cost of remote area housing rather than the previous liability of 60 per cent. This will still impose enormous burdens upon employers.

It is estimated that the impact of the FBT in the Northern Territory will be to increase private sector costs by 5 per cent. With Territorians already paying unreasonably high prices for food, clothing and other necessities, to add to this burden by pushing up prices, which will be the net result of the FBT is unjustifiable.

No one in the outback has been hoodwinked into believing that this tax is aimed at tax evaders. The people of the outback are not tax cheats and yet are being hit by this tax which one can only assume is a desperate attempt by a desperate Treasurer to milk Australians for a bit more income to pay for exorbitant government spending. To give one more example of how this tax will hit Territorians, it will have a devastating effect upon Aboriginal community education. The Northern Territory Education Department provides an on-site service to a large number of remote communities. It is estimated that in the instance of, say, the Maningrida school in Arn- hem Land, which is accessible only by sea and air, the FBT liability will amount to almost $70,000. What is being taxed is not fringe benefits but compensation to teachers and other staff for service in a harsh and remote environment.

Things such as remote locality fares, freight free perishables in areas which can be supplied only by air, free or subsidised services on out- stations and homeland centres and very basic departmental housing are being attacked by the Treasurer as rorts. No wonder the Federal Government is shovelling massive amounts of money, estimated between $2m and $5m, on these flash advertising campaigns to try to convince the electorate that this tax is justifiable. Thankfully, the electorate will not fall for this glossy public relations exercise because ordinary men and women can see that they are being clobbered by Hawke and Keating. In the long run there will be no winners under this tax except the Department of the Treasury. I wonder whether even it will be a winner because the cost of recovery, the staffing et cetera that is required to administer this tax collecting will be enormous.

I will pass to another matter which I think is extremely important. I wish to make some comments upon the way in which government tenders are called and dealt with by the Department of Administrative Services. During the Estimates Committee hearings I participated in the hearings of Estimates Committee F. The matter to which I wish to refer is recorded on pages 384 and 385 of the Hansard transcript of that Committee's hearings. During that session I asked some questions of a Mr Quinn of the Department of Territories concerning the procedure by which tenders are called for the supply of goods to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. I asked Mr Quinn about the reasons for the failure of Mr John Clunies-Ross, Sr, to secure shipping contracts to supply the islands in spite of the extremely competitive freight rates which he was then offering. The departmental officer stated:
It was a decision by Ministers that Mr Clunies-Ross's company not be considered in the tender process a couple of years ago.

In response to my question `Are you able to say why the Ministers refused him this contract?' Mr Quinn said `No'. At this point the Minister attending the Committee stepped in and said that he was disallowing the question. It appears that he had shut the gate after the horse had bolted because it seems, from what has been revealed by the answers of Mr Quinn to my questions, that a directive from Ministers had been given that a specific company was to be excluded from consideration of government tenders. The whole matter raises serious questions about the right, if any, of the Ministers concerned to take this sort of decision.

I have since discussed the matter with Mr Clunies-Ross who, as honourable senators may know, was bankrupted a few years ago. He informed me that not only were his companies excluded from consideration for tenders for supply of goods to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, but the tender documents put out by the Department were marked to state specifically that the Clunies-Ross companies' tenders would not be accepted. Mr Clunies-Ross told me that it was made clear to him from discussions with departmental officers and the Minister at the time, Mr Uren, that this black ban was connected with the campaign to get Mr Clunies-Ross off the home island in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

It seems fairly clear from the information available that the Minister was not taking the decision to exclude Clunies-Ross from tendering on any commercial basis. Clunies-Ross could offer very competitive rates as he had a lot of shipping business between Singapore and Perth. Because his ships were largely empty on the voyage to Singapore he could charge substantially less than the competition, which he had been doing. I am not aware under what authority the Minister gave his directive to the departmental officers. As far as I am aware, under the finance regulations contracts shall not be entered into until tenders have been publicly invited, except in certain exceptional circumstances. I do not think this was the situation in this particular case. As far as I can see, Clunies-Ross was a member of the public. The specific exclusion imposed by the Minister seems to amount to a clear contravention of the finance regulations. If some other authority for this decision can be pointed to, I would be interested to see it, but I do not see how the decision can be morally justified.

It appears that an Australian citizen has been victimised by a Minister and the fortunes of the Clunies-Ross shipping company were certainly not helped by the actions of the Minister. Arguably, the implementation of the Minister's decision may well have assisted Clunies-Ross along the path to bankruptcy. I understand that when Clunies-Ross endeavoured to get justice the Ombudsman said that he could not investigate the matter because it was a directive of the Minister. It appears that ugly big government has destroyed another Australian because he was in the way of a government whim. I would be most grateful if the present Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) would care to clarify exactly how this situation arose and on what basis the Minister's decision was made. This is not the action of a democratic government but that of a harsh dictatorship. Surely Clunies-Ross must have some grounds for retribution.

The final issue which I wish to address is that of funding of Aboriginal services. The funding to which I refer is not simply that which falls within the portfolio of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, but funding through the very many other departments which provide services to Aboriginal people, such as the departments of Social Security, Health, Housing, Community Services and Employment and Industrial Relations. Funds are provided not only through these Commonwealth departments, but also through the departments of State and Territory governments and a great number of semi-government and statutory authorities.

I must say from the outset that my remarks tonight should not be taken as an attack or an expression of opposition to the funding of Aboriginal services because far from opposing such funding I am very much in favour of it. It is a necessity of life, a responsibility of fellow Australians. The purpose of my remarks tonight is to bring attention to what I regard as a misdirection of funds, the result being that those Aboriginal people who most need assistance are often the ones who receive the least. I refer to responsible funding and controlled expenditure. Appropriation Bill (No. 1) which is before the chamber shows that the allocation for the administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Institute of Aboriginal Studies is in excess of $271m. Appropriation Bill (No. 2) shows further allocations to the Department totalling $39m. There we see the allocation of in excess of $300m within the confines of the Department. When one adds the funds within other Commonwealth portfolios, some of which are very heavily involved in funding Aboriginal services, and within the Territory and State departments and the various other bodies, one is looking at a much greater figure. I venture to suggest that it could be as much as double the Aboriginal Affairs budget-so it has been estimated by other authorities-and total spending could be in the vicinity of, say, $600m or more.

Whichever way one looks at it, a lot of money is being spent on Aboriginal people. I think the question which must be asked is: What has it achieved? The answer, as far as I am concerned, is: Not nearly as much as it should have. I think the time has come for us to take a good long look not at how much is spent but at how government funds are spent on the welfare and the future of Aboriginal people. Massive amounts of money are being pumped into Aboriginal funding, but the money is not filtering through to those who need it most. Instead it is being eaten up in administrative costs, with only a very small proportion eventually getting to the people on the ground. While it is all very well for the Federal Government to say to its supporters or to grandstand overseas saying that it spends so many millions of dollars on Aboriginal people, it does not mean much in terms of the results of that expenditure. It probably gives the Federal Government and others a warm inner glow and a clear conscience to be able to talk about how much it spends, but success in improving the conditions of Aboriginal people should be measured in terms of actual results rather than the amount of money which is being spent.

There is a need for a total review of the way in which Aboriginal funding is distributed. As I said before, there are an estimated 1,000 or even 1,200 departments, councils, commissions, offices, institutes, organisations, associations, committees, centres, funds, programs, boards, agencies, authorities, bureaus, schemes and services. The estimate of the number involved is not mine but rather is of the people who are involved in funding. It is apparent-common sense-that if there are hundreds of organisations there will be hundreds of administrators, hangers-on and leeches who are using up funds before those funds even get a chance to get to those on the ground.

A full review of the functions which are performed by those various bodies needs to be undertaken to ensure that there is not duplication and waste which, if avoided, would free up funds to go to an effective and useful purpose for the benefit of Aboriginal people. The way things are at present, there is great scope for waste, duplication and double dipping. There is no check on who is paying what to whom and for what purpose. I am well aware that duplication of payments of social security benefits occurs to a great extent. While I am not having a go at the individuals who are receiving it-in this instance, anyway-I believe a lot of the trouble stems from lack of co-ordination of various programs.

I am also not entirely sure that the priorities of those organisations are beyond question. The expenditure of $52,000 for an autobiography of Charles Perkins is not easy to justify when one considers that Aboriginal children are still suffering from malnutrition and living in the dust. There is no question that the money is being spent, but it is not being spent where it should be. I urge a total review of how funds are being spent, and I recommend that the starting point be the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, which is a mammoth organisation. The officers on the ground in remote areas do not have the capacity to carry out their duties and keep tabs on what is going on, despite the huge numbers within this Department and a huge payroll.

What about the Aboriginal Development Commission? Was this not to be the operational head of Aboriginal services in Australia? It appears that it is being squeezed out as the massive bureaucracy of the Department takes over. The whole role of government support for Aboriginal people needs to be reviewed if there is to be any hope of bringing about an improvement in their lot. It is all very well to be able to say `Well, yes, child mortality rates are declining', but on the other hand the life expectancy of Aboriginal people is reducing, due to various problems with alcohol, petrol sniffing, road accidents and violence. It is ironic that we are saving more Aboriginal babies, only to see them die later prematurely as the victims of these epidemic, social and health problems. One has to be cynical when one considers the vast amounts of money spent and the reality of living conditions for very many Aboriginal people.

The problem of petrol sniffing has been highlighted in the media recently, and it is clear that positive action is needed to deal with it. There has been far too much high flying, with conferences and meetings, and too little work on the ground. Positive action is called for. The Senate, as honourable senators will recall, established a select committee to look into this question, and it dealt with it very conclusively and, I believe, exhaustively, yet one wonders what action has been taken on its recommendations. Consider how we would react if a member of our families were carrying a tin can of petrol around his neck. We would take it away from him. The same should be done in the communities. These children are in low physical and mental condition. They need to be built up and treated as patients, for they are very sick people. They need to be cared for before reaching, say, the Alice Springs Hospital where there are now some 22 patients, mainly from northern South Australia. Death has occurred, and the hospital is overwhelmed and incapable of carrying out its normal operations.

These Aboriginal youth require adequate food as well as something to keep them occupied. Many of their problems stem from boredom. They need sports programs, educational programs and the like, but there is much more to be done before they get to that stage. Co-operation between teachers, health workers, Aboriginal councils and Aboriginal parents is important. They all have to participate. The children need to be fed regular rations. We have to have kitchens set up, and we need supervision and discipline in a form of an out-of-doors hospital. The people who are encouraging the habit should be able to be removed if a complaint against them is lodged by the Aboriginal council. There must be more control of the accessibility of petrol. I believe the tribal elders have to be encouraged to get the younger people involved in tribal culture and bushcraft, having in mind that I am talking of remote areas; I am not talking about the towns. There is very little petrol sniffing in the towns. It will take a tremendous and well-organised effort.

There has been a lot of talk for years about putting programs in place, but nothing has been done; there has been no positive action. Some will criticise what I am proposing and say that to take such positive steps to stop the sniffing is discrimination. How ridiculous! How foolish! This is a positive action to assist these people. The country is becoming very sick when it is said that there should be no prohibition on the use of, say, food vouchers which are intended for food purchases but which are used to buy tobacco and liquor instead. The vouchers are not allowed to be labelled to say that they cannot be used by buy tobacco and liquor because that, it is said, is discriminating.

We are seeing the destruction of the fabric of the Aboriginal society because in the outback tribal law is breaking down; the elders are losing control; and an increasing number of young Aboriginal people are now in a void. If we are to achieve anything, we must stop talking all this nonsense and apply ourselves to the problem. As I have said, money is not all important. Nevertheless, Aboriginal funds are staying at the top of the tree where they are consumed by the gigantic bureaucracies which have been built up, so very little is getting down to the grass roots level where it rightly should be spent. Indeed, we live in the era of the haves and have-nots. The Federal Government has to learn that splashing money around is not the answer. In some situations it can make things worse. I was interested to see an article in the Australian on Friday, 7 November-last Friday. It was a comment by Senator Fred Chaney under the headline `Wise ways with charity'. His thoughts were directed to the sponsorship by the Anglican Church in Western Australia of a seminar called `Reconciliation 1988: Aborigines and Other Australians'. Part of the article, I think, is very pertinent. Senator Chaney said:
The discussion will be-
the discussion referred to is the seminar-

less than productive, however, if it is not conducted with an understanding of what is likely to be required of all those who seek continued taxpayer support in light of the economic constraints facing all Australians-namely frugality and effectiveness.
He went on to say:

Frugality is essential when the whole community feels frugality is being thrust upon it. People in paid employment, many of whom are facing their own difficulties in making ends meet, will demand greater responsibility from government in the use of their tax dollars and from those who receive those dollars.
Effectiveness will need to be demonstrated because waste of diminishing resources increasingly will be regarded as intolerable.
He continued:

Economic reality dictates the need for even more Federal Government spending restraint than we have had so far. In those circumstances, and particularly with respect to welfare spending, we need to know which government programs are succeeding. Where problems are being solved, rather than new ones created, there is ground for public sympathy and further government funding.

I think those are quite wise words. To continue, I give just one brief example of how the maladministration or non-administration of funds can become a problem. I received a letter from an Alice Springs constituent recently. He is a small building contractor who built some houses for an Aboriginal community. The value of his work was $37,000. He did the work in July and has not been paid since. It seems that the community adviser has run up debts, including this one, to the value of $100,000 on the basis that money would be coming from somewhere. Well, the money was not there. Although the particular community is involved in an employment scheme, it did not have the funds to pay off debts of this magnitude and the debt should never have been incurred. I mention this instance as one example of what can and does happen when it is assumed, as it is by some organisations and individuals, that the various Aboriginal funding bodies are some sort of bottomless pit into which one need only dig to come up with another bucket of money. This should not be the way in which funding for Aboriginal people is approached, either by the people themselves or by those authorising the funding. There is, too, the situation in which, without exaggeration, millions of dollars have been lifted out of Aboriginal organisations, councils, co-operatives, et cetera, particularly by non-Aboriginals who have preyed on Aboriginal communities.

In closing, I do not think any reasonable person would begrudge the funding of Aboriginal services. But I believe we are entitled as a nation to ask ourselves: Are we going about this in the right way? Personally, I do not think we are, and I believe that the way in which many Aboriginal people continue to live is evidence of the failure, at least in part, of what is being done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments on what has been said, particularly by Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who I think mentioned a couple of points which need to be looked at. First of all, she spoke of the fringe benefits tax, saying that that robbed incentives. I want to come back to that. She then spoke about the family and the effect of taxation and government policies on families. I think the areas she dealt with are very significant areas because they go to what government, in a certain sense, is all about. They go, first of all, to the social impact that policies may have on the community and, secondly, to the economic effects that government and the taxes it imposes may have on the people who produce income. Those two areas, of course, are very significant areas. Whether the senator gave the right answers to those problems that she raised is another matter. Indeed, the Appropriation Bills open up a wide range of issues. That has been well illustrated by the speakers who have gone before me in the sorts of areas that they have looked at, and no doubt that proposition will be illustrated even further by those who come after me.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the central theme to all the debates remains the same-it concerns the issues that government deals with. In recent times the debates that this chamber-and, indeed, both chambers-have been most devoted to are those that revolve around the economy. It seems to me that there are dangers in that sort of debate if it becomes exclusive, because it puts aside the sorts of areas that Senator Peter Baume, who is in the chamber, is interested in, such as moral, social and cultural issues which, in my view, are above and beyond the sorts of issues that are raised by economic debates. If the economy forms the only parameters given to debates, we tend to get a very soul-less, uninspired approach to things. People are treated like automatons because they are looked upon as units in some sort of economic sum. It is as if by increasing one particular aspect of the economy and taking away from another particular aspect salvation will come, and the whole treatment is very much one of looking at people not as they really are, as thinking, feeling, throbbing human beings, but as robots whose purpose is to man the office, shop floor and whatever else people consider they should be made to man.

To a certain degree, that, I think, is the problem with this question of youth employment. One of the problems that we seem to have overlooked is the fact that children, young people and people in their early twenties are human beings with souls, aspirations and ambitions. Yet much of the debate we have gone on with says that these people should be forced into work and made to obtain jobs when in fact we do not have jobs to give them unless in some way we manufacture them. Surely if there were enough jobs in the community they would be filled up by the people who are presently unemployed, not only the young people but the older people as well. The fact that they are not and the fact that we have these young people in the situation many of them are in leads us more and more to label them with that rather dreadful term `dole bludger'. In doing that, I think we are being restricted too much, as I said, by the economic parameters and by that desire to get the economy going, while looking at the economy in terms of the number of people who have to get jobs, the number of jobs available, and the amount of money in the community. Looking at the economy in those terms we say: `If we can adjust this, if we can put these people here, this youth there and this young lady here, all will be well' without specifying actual and specific jobs that are available. While we are doing that we impose upon them quite severe, ruthless and unfeeling hardship. Of course there are people-as there must be, looking at the sort of evidence that has been brought into this chamber-who should be working and who are not. But to use them as an example to deduce or bring out a general rule is, as I said, quite ruthless and unfeeling and something we should think about as we use that as a form of debate in this House.

Another approach which I think illustrates these points is this: There is a solemn declaration made again and again in this chamber that if we reduce wages the good times will come, as if to more or less present Australia with the cargo cult approach which existed in Papua New Guinea for a while. It was believed that planes would drop goods down from heaven, that they would be provided without effort to the people below, and that all would live happily ever afterwards. It seems that we often have that sort of approach in this chamber. The idea is put about that if wages are reduced, if we do this or that, in some way the good times will come without any further effort being made. However, that ignores the problems in our industry structure and our work culture that have operated in the past. It must be borne in mind that initiative does not come simply by making rewards greater, but by inculcating such an attitude into society, which up to now has not adopted that initiative in the industrial sphere.

I want to say a few words about the approach that is involved in depressing the amount of money that is available. One understands that times are hard and that money is not as plentiful as it used to be. One also understands that there has to be some lowering in living standards for many people. But the fact that wages and incomes are reduced does not make any less unhappy those who as a result of reduced wages must lower the quality of food they buy or surrender their houses because they cannot pay the mortgage. This will not prevent the disappointment felt by children who are unable to go on school excursions, nor will it overcome the frustrated ambitions of many youths who cannot go on to university or other tertiary education and who otherwise might have been able to do so. One cannot overcome the fact that the quality of life in general is prejudiced by the decrease in availability of money and that the father and mother cannot bring into the house the sort of income they want to provide for their families. Therefore, great suffering and hardship is caused to the people concerned.

When we talk here of the economic parameters, economic reality and the need to lower wages, we must remember that in so doing we are asking people to make great sacrifices. It is being said that those at the lower end of the scale, those who get less wages than others, will have difficulties in buying food, in housing, in looking after their children, and in enjoying the sort of life they enjoyed in the past. It seems to me that as a group perhaps we are not as compassionate as we might be in talking about the rigours that we as a parliament want to impose on people. We tend to talk in the rhetoric of the adversarial system, as if in some way we are conducting a court case in which one side puts up a proposition and the other side puts the contrary view. There is a division in the rhetoric in this chamber between capital and labour-almost a classical marxist approach. We do not use those words, but that is often what we mean. It is best illustrated in the analysis that is sometimes made about the way we should react to unions. It is said that if unions were in some way suppressed, if unions and their bosses could be crushed, that would enable the free market forces to flow. In that way, it is said, youth unemployment problems would be solved, business would become profitable, incentives would grow, and all would be well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the Labor Party was sold on the free market forces philosophy. Would you please tell us?

—No. If one goes to the latest Australian Council of Trade Unions wages resolution-I do not say that this is the Government's approach but it is a proposition put forward by a very important part of the labour movement-one sees that the ACTU does not believe in that principle. What has been put even in the two-tier system is contrary to what has been said by Senator Siddons.
