On the two-tier system it is said that a flat rate to be decided by some formula that will be devised should be paid across the board and added to existing wages. In that way those people who are in danger of tumbling into poverty, disaster and distress will be protected to some extent from price rises. That is the first tier. The second tier, which is over and beyond that and subject to certain formulas that must be worked out, provides for more money to be added to the flat rate in respect of some people. That extra sum will be worked out within certain parameters and certain factors will be taken into account, such as people's ability to pay. In those circumstances justice will be done not only to the person paying but to the person receiving. I know that Senator Lewis is the last person in this chamber who would want to see people go without adequate pay for the work they do.
—You could have fooled me.
—Senator Lewis is a man with a great heart once one gets to know him well. He is not the sort of person who would stand aside and see wages so depressed that people could not live properly.
—It is your Government that wants to have this downgrading of wages all the time.

—Senator Lewis, that is not correct. We as a government want so to adjust wages as to enable people to live as decent human beings, to have enough income to exercise their economic, spiritual, moral, cultural and social aspirations. At the same time, the people who employ those workers and who hopefully provide the managerial skills will be enabled not only to let the desert flourish but also to let the economy flourish at every level, whether in manufacturing, in the rural sector or in the tertiary economy. The ACTU document is worth quoting in this context because it is interesting and inspiring. The document said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ACTU would be prepared to accede to a maximum under this heading-
that is dealing with the two-tier system-

provided that the principles were acceptable and sufficiently flexible to allow widespread application; the government's economic and social policy was facilitating the achievement of the objectives of the Prices and Incomes Accord-
let us remember that this is not only an incomes accord, but a prices accord, too-

there is an acceptable increase in the general adjustment; no reduction in working conditions: award or over award such as 17.5 per cent annual loading, junior rates, penalty rates and unilateral extension of part-time and casual work; a continuation of the superannuation campaign.

That document is saying that we as representatives of the work force are willing to be reasonable, provided that those who pay the wages are prepared to be reasonable. It is an indication that the trade union movement is willing to be more than reasonable to meet the present needs of the economy. The country needs the unions because if we do not have them we would go back to the days so eloquently described by Charles Dickens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney is still in the nineteenth century-laissez-faire politics by another name.

—That is not right. An agreement is being sought, and this is the difference in the policies of the Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party. The Labor Party agrees to a negotiation at a particular level, but between equals-that is, between the ACTU, the unions and management. However, the Opposition puts forward a policy that such negotiations should take place between those in a very powerful position and those in a weak position-namely, between the employer and the employee direct. I have heard Opposition members put forward such suggestions and these are very much a nineteenth century approach to the question of just and proper wage levels.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to raise a problem concerning a nursing home approval for the Lilydale Bush Nursing Home in Victoria. The Lilydale Bush Nursing Home is being set up with the support of the Lilydale and District Hospital on the outskirts of the suburban area of Melbourne. The Lilydale Hospital sought approval for capital funding from the Commonwealth Government for the building of the nursing home and this approval was granted in principle. I do not know when the approval was granted, but I take it from a letter that was written by the Department of Community Services that it must have been some time ago because the letter is in response to a request for additional time to establish the nursing home accommodation. The approval, granted by the Department of Community Services, has committed the Commonwealth to make a fixed capital grant of $600,000 towards the cost of building the nursing home.

SPEECH.PARA: Once the approval in principle was received from the Department of Community Services, the promoters of the nursing home called for tenders to build the facility. They were told that it was in order to proceed to call tenders. Eight tenders were received and the lowest was $1.8m, which the Lilydale and District Hospital sought to accept. The tenders were put on the basis of a design which I am told had been approved by the Department when the application was first made for a capital grant. The tenders were then submitted to the Department of Community Services, as is required, with a request that the lowest tender be accepted. It is now some four to five weeks later and I am told by the promoters of the nursing home that they have received no official advice from the Department as to the fate of their application. They still do not know whether they can proceed on the basis of the tenders they have received and they have been told that unless building starts by 31 December they could lose the $600,000 capital grant.

Unofficially the promoters have heard from the Government that the cost of the nursing home at $1.8m is too high on a per capita basis and that the grant will not be approved until the cost is reduced. A member of my staff has spoken to one of the officers of the Department, who has confirmed that advice. The question is: Why is this the case? A number of reasons could be suggested for the Department of Community Services taking this attitude-that it will not approve the grant because the cost of building the facility is said to be too high. The first could be that a comparison has been drawn between building a nursing home in the Lilydale area and what is said to be the more standard cost of building a nursing home in an inner suburban area. The Department may feel that it is too expensive. Perhaps the Department is using inner suburban figures. But if there were eight tenders submitted and if the Bush Nursing Association has tried to take the lowest of $1.8m on a design approved by the Department, I need to have explained to me why the cost is said to be too high. How can it be other than the going commercial rate in the area? That has to be the going commercial rate.

Another suggestion that has been made is that the Department is using this easy or underhand way to slide out of its commitment in principle to grant capital funding to the nursing home. That argument has been put forward in the context of the move to give more emphasis to hostel rather than nursing home accommodation. I have been told by the Department that that is not the case and my office has so told the promoters. I hope that I have been correctly advised. I am concerned about a letter which was received by Mr L. G. Ashcroft, the Chief Executive Officer of the Lilydale and District Hospital, dated 4 July and signed by R. G. Lewis, Senior Assistant Director of the Residential Programs Branch of the Department of Community Services. This letter says, in part:

However in view of the extreme delay in proceeding with the construction of the proposed nursing home accommodation it is unlikely that any further extensions will be granted if the building has not commenced before the expiry date--
That is, 31 December. The letter continues:
In such circumstances your approval for capital funding would also lapse.

It seems quite likely that any instruction to redesign the facility and call for new tenders would take the promoters beyond the 31 December deadline. It is a real catch-22 situation. The promoters called for tenders, they received eight and they selected the lowest tender. They asked the Department to approve it. They cannot start the building until approval is received. The Department has told them unofficially that it will not approve it because the tender is too high and it has also told them that if they do not start building by 31 December they will lose their grant. They are in a terrible position because they do not know what to do. They do not know what they can do. They simply want to get the building under way so that they do not lose the capital funding which has been offered. It seems quite likely that any redesigning or retendering that the Department may require will mean that the promoters cannot comply with the deadline. The Department must address that issue if its protestations of trying to help are to be believed out there in Lilydale.

I am told that the real reason for the delay in approving the capital grant is the total cost of the nursing home. I am told that the Department will not allow public funds to be used to finance the building of nursing homes that are considered too lavish or too expensive. This is a grey area; it is a question of values. I was told that the Department had had experiences with certain buildings which it referred to as `Taj Mahals' and that it did not wish to approve those. I am not satisfied that this kind of scrutiny is necessarily proper. If the Department makes an approval in principle for the building of a nursing home, if it approves the plans, if it has the plans out to tender, if eight tenders are received, surely to goodness that is adequate for these people to get the lowest tender approved and be allowed to proceed with the building. At the moment they face an absolutely impossible position in that they cannot get approval to build, they cannot afford the time to go to retender and they look like losing their capital grant of $600,000 through action which they simply cannot see their way through.

The question arises whether this refusal to fund facilities which the Department considers too expensive is an unnecessary interference with the building of nursing homes by groups such as this one at Lilydale. Where such groups wish to take appropriate action to build a nursing home they have to find the balance of the funds, after all. It is not the Department that has to find the money. The Department's subsidy is fixed. This sort of thing probably slows down approvals, adds to the amount of bureaucracy that is necessary in the process and makes the whole process more difficult. I have raised this matter informally with the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) and I ask him again to look at this matter urgently because it is a real catch-22 situation in which this group of Australians find themselves. They simply want to get the facility built, they do not want to muck around, and they need some help from the Department if they are to go ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume has made it clear that he has already drawn the attention of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) to this matter. No doubt his speech will add further fuel to the fire that he is stoking. I think that we can leave it to the normal processes to take their course in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.38 p.m.
